rel=\"alternate\"; title=\"JSON\"; type=\"application/json\", <https://saveourostriches.com/?p=10201>; rel=shortlink","etag":"\"7007-1748017219;br\"","x-litespeed-cache":"hit","content-encoding":"br","vary":"Accept-Encoding","content-length":"27202","date":"Tue, 27 May 2025 06:31:30 GMT","server":"LiteSpeed","platform":"hostinger","panel":"hpanel","content-security-policy":"upgrade-insecure-requests","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"Press Release - Feb 25, 2025: Urgent Call to Save 400 Healthy Ostriches from Government Slaughter Amidst Questionable Avian Flu Fears\nEdgewood, British Columbia — February 25, 2025 — Universal Ostrich Farm update regarding the Canadian government’s persistent efforts to slaughter 400 healthy ostriches located on a remote rural farm in Edgewood, British Columbia. This drastic action was ordered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) in the wake of the ongoing “Avian Flu” hysteria.\nLegal Update\nOn February 17, 2025, Justice Michael Battista of the Federal Court of Canada issued a ruling in response to motions filed by the Department of Justice (DOJ) seeking clarification of his January 31, 2025, Stay Order. Justice Battista affirmed that his initial decision was in line with the law and that CFIA had failed to present any new information or overlooked key aspects. In his February 17 decision, Justice Battista emphasized, “The Stay Order reflects the Court’s intention,” and concluded, “There is no ambiguity in the Stay Order. It clearly stayed the operation of the Respondent’s Notice dated December 31, 2024, until a decision is rendered in the underlying application for judicial review.” In short: CFIA, you cannot kill the ostriches until the judicial review is heard and decided.\nBackground and Timeline\nIn late December 2024, a large flock of wild ducks landed on a pond shared by over 450 ostriches on Universal Ostrich Farm in Edgewood. Over the following two weeks, some of the ostriches became sick, and 67 died. A similar event occurred on the farm in 2020, where a small number of ostriches fell ill and died, but the cause was identified as an opportunistic pathogen, Pseudomonas, not Avian Flu. With guidance from their vet, the family treated the birds, and the sick ones recovered.\nConcerned by the onset of similar symptoms, farm owners Karen Espersen and Dave Balinski contacted their vet, but he was unavailable due to the Christmas holiday. They began treating the affected ostriches as they did in 2020, and the birds began to recover.\nOn December 30, 2024, CFIA agents arrived at the farm, tested two dead carcasses, but did not perform autopsies or take tissue samples. They only swabbed the two dead birds for PCR testing, which only tests for Avian Flu, neglecting other potential pathogens like Pseudomonas. The following day, CFIA informed the farm owners that the birds tested positive for Avian Flu and issued a “kill order” for all 400 remaining ostriches.\nDespite sharing their scientific research demonstrating the ostriches’ robust immunity and potential to develop antibodies, including those that may combat COVID-related illnesses, the farm owners’ pleas to CFIA fell on deaf ears. On January 10, 2025, CFIA reaffirmed the kill order, demanding the birds be slaughtered by February 1, 2025.\nLegal and Scientific Standpoint\nThe farm owners reached out to stakeholders and the public for help. They retained Michael Carter, of the law firm Cleveland Doan, on January 22, 2025, who, along with other lawyers, experts, scientists, and veterinarians, worked tirelessly to challenge the CFIA’s decision to kill the ostriches. Appearing in the Federal Court of Canada, on January 31, 2025, Justice Battista granted a Stay of Execution to prevent the mass slaughter. A global team of scientists rallied behind the ostriches, recognizing their potential not only as a source of natural immunity against avian flu but the opportunity to have a living laboratory to study “best immunity” strategies, and antibody science.\nLawyers for the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed two motions four days later: one to expedite the judicial review hearing, and the other seeking clarification of Justice Battista’s Stay Order. The CFIA argued that the injunction applied only to the farm owners, preventing them from killing the 400 ostriches. They sought clarification that the order would permit the CFIA to proceed with the kill. To further complicate matters and impose additional legal costs on the family, the CFIA also filed an appeal of the Stay Order.\nOn February 18, 2025, Justice Battista ruled on these motions, affirming that the Stay Order remains in effect — meaning no ostriches are to be killed until the judicial review is heard. Justice Battista also agreed to expedite the review, as requested by the CFIA. He appointed a case management judge to oversee the scheduling, with deadlines for document exchanges and a tentative hearing date set for a two-day judicial review from April 14-17, 2025, in the Federal Court of Canada.\nKatie Pasitnay, spokesperson for Universal Ostrich Farm, stated:\n“This is not just about saving 400 birds. It’s about science, public health, and the government’s failure to embrace logic over outdated policies. We are fighting to protect these animals, the valuable research they represent, and the rights of the family who has dedicated years of effort to their care.”\nKey Facts:\nLast ostrich death: January 14, 2025 (more than 40 days ago).\nAvian Flu incubation: CFIA states it has a 14-day maximum incubation period.\nThe sick ostriches have fully recovered.\nNearly 90% of the herd remains unaffected.\nThe ostriches now have natural immunity and should be used to breed avian flu-resistant ostriches and further research into antibodies.\nYet, the CFIA insists on eradicating these genetically valuable birds instead of recognizing their immunity as a potential asset for future vaccine development.\nUpcoming Court Dates:\nAs the case continues, support for Universal Ostrich Farm and the scientific community’s calls for the preservation of these birds grows. The outcome of the judicial review will be a pivotal moment in determining the future of these ostriches, if they have one, and the role they may play in global health research.\nThe date for the hearing of the appeal has not been set.\nFor media inquiries or to show support, please submit all requests to:\nKatie Pasitney, Universal Ostrich Farm spokeswoman – Katie is the daughter of Karen Espersen, one of the owners of Universal Ostriches and has become the public face of this battle appearing on numerous talk shows across Canada and the United States. Katie has grown up with some of these ostriches, and considers them to be family members.\nLegal Team\nMichael Carter, Lead Counsel for the legal team – Michael is with the law firm Cleveland Doan. Michael has worked tirelessly and has put together a unique team of lawyers, scientists and experts.\nGo To: SaveOurOstriches.com for more info and videos of CFIA agents in full hazmat suits declaring that these big beautiful, healthy ostriches must be “eradicated.”\nWatch CFIA Inspection Videos here.\nThank you to all your support and love\nHelp us save these beautiful healthy babies\nHappy and beautiful - YouTube\nTrevor's Story Meet Trevor - YouTube","markdown":"# Press Release - Feb 25, 2025: Urgent Call to Save 400 Healthy Ostriches from Government Slaughter Amidst Questionable Avian Flu Fears\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/25-02-25-image-1-1024x768.png)\n\nEdgewood, British Columbia — February 25, 2025 — Universal Ostrich Farm update regarding the Canadian government’s persistent efforts to slaughter 400 healthy ostriches located on a remote rural farm in Edgewood, British Columbia. This drastic action was ordered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) in the wake of the ongoing “Avian Flu” hysteria.\n\n**Legal Update**\n\nOn February 17, 2025, Justice Michael Battista of the Federal Court of Canada issued a ruling in response to motions filed by the Department of Justice (DOJ) seeking clarification of his January 31, 2025, Stay Order. Justice Battista affirmed that his initial decision was in line with the law and that CFIA had failed to present any new information or overlooked key aspects. In his February 17 decision, Justice Battista emphasized, “The Stay Order reflects the Court’s intention,” and concluded, “There is no ambiguity in the Stay Order. It clearly stayed the operation of the Respondent’s Notice dated December 31, 2024, until a decision is rendered in the underlying application for judicial review.” In short: CFIA, you cannot kill the ostriches until the judicial review is heard and decided.\n\n**Background and Timeline**\n\nIn late December 2024, a large flock of wild ducks landed on a pond shared by over 450 ostriches on Universal Ostrich Farm in Edgewood. Over the following two weeks, some of the ostriches became sick, and 67 died. A similar event occurred on the farm in 2020, where a small number of ostriches fell ill and died, but the cause was identified as an opportunistic pathogen, Pseudomonas, not Avian Flu. With guidance from their vet, the family treated the birds, and the sick ones recovered.\n\nConcerned by the onset of similar symptoms, farm owners Karen Espersen and Dave Balinski contacted their vet, but he was unavailable due to the Christmas holiday. They began treating the affected ostriches as they did in 2020, and the birds began to recover.\n\nOn December 30, 2024, CFIA agents arrived at the farm, tested two dead carcasses, but did not perform autopsies or take tissue samples. They only swabbed the two dead birds for PCR testing, which only tests for Avian Flu, neglecting other potential pathogens like Pseudomonas. The following day, CFIA informed the farm owners that the birds tested positive for Avian Flu and issued a “kill order” for all 400 remaining ostriches.\n\nDespite sharing their scientific research demonstrating the ostriches’ robust immunity and potential to develop antibodies, including those that may combat COVID-related illnesses, the farm owners’ pleas to CFIA fell on deaf ears. On January 10, 2025, CFIA reaffirmed the kill order, demanding the birds be slaughtered by February 1, 2025.\n\n**Legal and Scientific Standpoint**\n\nThe farm owners reached out to stakeholders and the public for help. They retained Michael Carter, of the law firm Cleveland Doan, on January 22, 2025, who, along with other lawyers, experts, scientists, and veterinarians, worked tirelessly to challenge the CFIA’s decision to kill the ostriches. Appearing in the Federal Court of Canada, on January 31, 2025, Justice Battista granted a Stay of Execution to prevent the mass slaughter. A global team of scientists rallied behind the ostriches, recognizing their potential not only as a source of natural immunity against avian flu but the opportunity to have a living laboratory to study “best immunity” strategies, and antibody science.\n\nLawyers for the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed two motions four days later: one to expedite the judicial review hearing, and the other seeking clarification of Justice Battista’s Stay Order. The CFIA argued that the injunction applied only to the farm owners, preventing them from killing the 400 ostriches. They sought clarification that the order would permit the CFIA to proceed with the kill. To further complicate matters and impose additional legal costs on the family, the CFIA also filed an appeal of the Stay Order.\n\nOn February 18, 2025, Justice Battista ruled on these motions, affirming that the Stay Order remains in effect — meaning no ostriches are to be killed until the judicial review is heard. Justice Battista also agreed to expedite the review, as requested by the CFIA. He appointed a case management judge to oversee the scheduling, with deadlines for document exchanges and a tentative hearing date set for a two-day judicial review from April 14-17, 2025, in the Federal Court of Canada.\n\nKatie Pasitnay, spokesperson for Universal Ostrich Farm, stated:\n\n“This is not just about saving 400 birds. It’s about science, public health, and the government’s failure to embrace logic over outdated policies. We are fighting to protect these animals, the valuable research they represent, and the rights of the family who has dedicated years of effort to their care.”\n\n**Key Facts:**\n\n*   Last ostrich death: January 14, 2025 (more than 40 days ago).\n*   Avian Flu incubation: CFIA states it has a 14-day maximum incubation period.\n*   The sick ostriches have fully recovered.\n*   Nearly 90% of the herd remains unaffected.\n*   The ostriches now have natural immunity and should be used to breed avian flu-resistant ostriches and further research into antibodies.\n*   Yet, the CFIA insists on eradicating these genetically valuable birds instead of recognizing their immunity as a potential asset for future vaccine development.\n\n**Upcoming Court Dates:**\n\nAs the case continues, support for Universal Ostrich Farm and the scientific community’s calls for the preservation of these birds grows. The outcome of the judicial review will be a pivotal moment in determining the future of these ostriches, if they have one, and the role they may play in global health research.\n\nThe date for the hearing of the appeal has not been set.\n\n**For media inquiries or to show support, please submit all requests to:**\n\nKatie Pasitney, Universal Ostrich Farm spokeswoman – Katie is the daughter of Karen Espersen, one of the owners of Universal Ostriches and has become the public face of this battle appearing on numerous talk shows across Canada and the United States. Katie has grown up with some of these ostriches, and considers them to be family members.\n\n**Legal Team**\n\nMichael Carter, Lead Counsel for the legal team – Michael is with the law firm Cleveland Doan. Michael has worked tirelessly and has put together a unique team of lawyers, scientists and experts.\n\nGo To: SaveOurOstriches.com for more info and videos of CFIA agents in full hazmat suits declaring that these big beautiful, healthy ostriches must be “eradicated.”\n\nWatch CFIA Inspection Videos [here](https://saveourostriches.com/cfia-inspection-videos/).\n\nThank you to all your support and love  \nHelp us save these beautiful healthy babies\n\nHappy and beautiful - YouTube\n\n[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MaoMTh-aCcM&embeds_referring_euri=https%3A%2F%2Fsaveourostriches.com%2F)\n\nTrevor's Story Meet Trevor - YouTube\n\n[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fk9Sl39x8dA&embeds_referring_euri=https%3A%2F%2Fsaveourostriches.com%2F)","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

ma=2592000, h3-29=\":443\"; ma=2592000, h3-Q050=\":443\"; ma=2592000, h3-Q046=\":443\"; ma=2592000, h3-Q043=\":443\"; ma=2592000, quic=\":443\"; ma=2592000; v=\"43, 46\"","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"Firearms group slams CFIA after feds consider asking hunters to kill 400 ostriches on BC family farm - Western Standard\nWestern Standard · Jarryd Jäger · Feb 18, 2025 \nThe Canadian Shooting Sports Association has slammed the Canadian Food Inspection Agency following revelations that the federal agency considered hiring hunters to kill 400 ostriches on a family farm in Edgewood, British Columbia.\nThe fate of the flock at Universal Ostrich Farm is uncertain as the battle between the owners and the federal government makes its way through the courts.\nAccording to the CSSA, an internal CFIA discussion leaked to the farm’s owners Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski showed that the agency asked “Can we get hunters to kill these birds for us?”\nThe move came after Justice Michael Battista ruled that Ottawa couldn’t force Espersen and Bilinski to kill the birds themselves until a judicial review was carried out. In an appeal, the federal government questioned whether the ruling also applied to the CFIA or outside actors.\n“No, CFIA, we will not do your dirty work for you,” the CSSA wrote in a statement. “Hunters are ethical men and women who humanely harvest wildlife to feed their families. They are not contract killers for government agencies.”\nThe group argued that the CFIA “has no evidence that the 400 ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms are sick,” explaining that agents only “performed PCR tests on two dead birds after 16 hours — not by conducting an autopsy or taking tissue samples, the ‘gold standard’ in testing — and used PCR tests to rationalize killing this entire flock of majestic birds.”\nThe CSSA called the cull order a “prime example of government overreach, bad science, and bureaucratic negligence,” adding that “instead of executing a flawed mass cull, CFIA should adopt modern disease management strategies and respect farmers’ rights.”\nThey urged anyone considering killing ostriches on the CFIA’s behalf to think twice, noting that “there are serious criminal penalties for injuring, endangering or killing animals or birds, as well as for discharging firearms where that activity is prohibited.”\nThe CFIA had originally ordered the birds killed by February 1 after two of their deceased herd-mates tested positive for H5N1, better known as avian flu. It was only on January 31 that the emergency injunction was filed, calling for a judicial review to be completed before any animal was slaughtered.\nShare this Story:\nTwitter Embed\nCSSA slams CFIA after feds consider asking hunters to kill 400 ostriches on BC family farm","markdown":"# Firearms group slams CFIA after feds consider asking hunters to kill 400 ostriches on BC family farm - Western Standard\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/image-2-1024x580.png)\n\n[**Western Standard**](https://www.westernstandard.news/news/firearms-group-slams-cfia-after-feds-consider-asking-hunters-to-kill-400-ostriches-on-bc-family-farm/62274) · [](https://www.westernstandard.news/author/jjaeger)[Jarryd Jäger](https://www.westernstandard.news/author/jjaeger) · Feb 18, 2025\n\nThe Canadian Shooting Sports Association has slammed the Canadian Food Inspection Agency following revelations that the federal agency considered hiring hunters to kill 400 ostriches on a family farm in Edgewood, British Columbia.\n\nThe fate of the flock at Universal Ostrich Farm is uncertain as the battle between the owners and the federal government makes its way through the courts.\n\nAccording to the CSSA, an internal CFIA discussion leaked to the farm’s owners Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski showed that the agency asked “Can we get hunters to kill these birds for us?”\n\nThe move came after Justice Michael Battista ruled that Ottawa couldn’t force Espersen and Bilinski to kill the birds themselves until a judicial review was carried out. In an appeal, the federal government questioned whether the ruling also applied to the CFIA or outside actors.\n\n“No, CFIA, we will not do your dirty work for you,” the CSSA wrote in a [statement](https://cssa-cila.org/no-cfia-hunters-wont-kill-400-ostriches-for-you/). “Hunters are ethical men and women who humanely harvest wildlife to feed their families. They are not contract killers for government agencies.”\n\nThe group argued that the CFIA “has no evidence that the 400 ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms are sick,” explaining that agents only “performed PCR tests on two dead birds after 16 hours — not by conducting an autopsy or taking tissue samples, the ‘gold standard’ in testing — and used PCR tests to rationalize killing this entire flock of majestic birds.”\n\nThe CSSA called the cull order a “prime example of government overreach, bad science, and bureaucratic negligence,” adding that “instead of executing a flawed mass cull, CFIA should adopt modern disease management strategies and respect farmers’ rights.”\n\nThey urged anyone considering killing ostriches on the CFIA’s behalf to think twice, noting that “there are serious criminal penalties for injuring, endangering or killing animals or birds, as well as for discharging firearms where that activity is prohibited.”\n\nThe CFIA had originally ordered the birds killed by February 1 after two of their deceased herd-mates tested positive for H5N1, better known as avian flu. It was only on January 31 that the emergency injunction was filed, calling for a judicial review to be completed before any animal was slaughtered.\n\n## Share this Story:\n\nTwitter Embed\n\n[](https://twitter.com/WSOnlineNews/status/1891915240448598209?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1891915240448598209%7Ctwgr%5E04b2e3d272a16e2cace2ec6ae5a5f15ef2b0b50a%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fsaveourostriches.com%2Fnews%2Ffirearms-group-slams-cfia-after-feds-consider-asking-hunters-to-kill-400-ostriches-on-bc-family-farm%2F)\n\nCSSA slams CFIA after feds consider asking hunters to kill 400 ostriches on BC family farm","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

If the farmers did not comply, the CFIA threatened to send someone to cull the ostriches instead.\nThese are non-commercial ostriches, are not sold for meat, and are flightless. So why would the CFIA insist on culling a herd that could naturally reach immunity?\nUniversal Ostrich Farms has been operational since 1995, and these ostriches, which can live up to 75 years, are part of an international program involving three countries, Canada, the U.S. and Japan. The ostriches have been integral in providing high-quality antibodies that have been successfully extracted from ostrich eggs which can be used to produce effective treatments for various diseases. \nIn a 2022 social media post, the government of Japan stated, “High-quality antibodies have been successfully extracted from ostrich eggs by Kyoto Prefectural University president Dr. Tsukamoto. Ostriches are hardy animals with strong immune systems, and at 1/4000 the cost of antibodies from other animals, their high-quality antibodies are easier to mass-produce, meaning they may show the way forward for the modern world.”\nGiven these promising prospects, why would the CFIA insist on culling this herd, which could potentially contribute to the eradication of diseases with their antibodies? Wouldn’t they want to preserve the valuable science and research that have been established with these ostriches?\nOn January 31st, a federal judge, Justice Battista issued a “stay” on the culling, giving the farmers time to seek a judicial review. Share this everywhere, this must be stopped!","markdown":"# Canadian Government orders the killing of 400 ostriches after refusing to test live birds\n\n![zD3NfsifKz](https://api.republic.us/assets/images/f8/f82535_zD3NfsifKz.png)\n\n[**Re:Public**](https://republic.us/people-news/19961) · Feb 20, 2025\n\nKatie Pasitney, daughter of Karen Espersen, owner of Universal Ostrich Farms in the remote town of Edgewood, British Columbia, has been ordered to cull their entire herd of 400 ostriches. If they don’t cull them, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency will.\n\nThe ordeal began in December 2024 when an anonymous person tipped off the CFIA that there was illness at the Universal Ostrich Farms. Some of the ostriches were sick, but the illness had run its course.\n\nThe farm was contacted by the CFIA and agreed to allow them to come test their ostriches. When the CFIA arrived with PCR tests to test 2 dead ostriches. The farmers asked if they were going to test the live ostriches, as a control group.\n\nThe CFIA came out with PCR tests and tested two dead ostriches. The farmers requested that they also test two live ostriches. They believed it was a reasonable approach to better understanding the illness, by using healthy ostriches as the “control group.”\n\nHowever, CFIA **_refused_** to test the live birds. They conducted the tests and called the next day to inform them that the two dead ostriches had tested positive for H5N1. As a result, the CFIA ordered them to quarantine their ostriches and cull the entire herd by February 1, 2025. If the farmers did not comply, the CFIA threatened to send someone to cull the ostriches instead.\n\nThese are non-commercial ostriches, are not sold for meat, and are flightless. They live on a remote farm where the likelihood of infecting another animal is extremely low. The ostriches that naturally die are harvested for oil, feathers, and skin. So why would the CFIA insist on culling a herd that could naturally reach immunity?\n\nUniversal Ostrich Farms has been operational since 1995, and these ostriches, which can live up to 75 years, are part of an international program involving three countries, Canada, the U.S. and Japan. The ostriches have been integral in providing high-quality antibodies that have been successfully extracted from ostrich eggs which can be used to produce effective treatments for various diseases.   \n\nIn a 2022 social media post, the government of Japan stated, “High-quality antibodies have been successfully extracted from ostrich eggs by Kyoto Prefectural University president Dr. Tsukamoto. Ostriches are hardy animals with strong immune systems, and at 1/4000 the cost of antibodies from other animals, their high-quality antibodies are easier to mass-produce, meaning they may show the way forward for the modern world.”\n\nGiven these promising prospects, why would the CFIA insist on culling this herd, which could potentially contribute to the eradication of diseases with their antibodies? Wouldn’t they want to preserve the valuable science and research that have been established with these ostriches?\n\nOn January 31st, a federal judge, Justice Battista issued a “stay” on the culling, giving the farmers time to seek a judicial review. On February 6, CFIA added 19 additional measures to the quarantine order. \n\nAs of February 19, 2025, the ostriches have gone 35 days without illness or death, remain in good health, and have achieved herd immunity.\n\nTheir case is scheduled for a judicial review within 10 days. Speaking with Katie, she urges the public “Help us save our animals, so we can help protect yours”. This is a tragedy not just for Katie and her family at Universal Ostrich Farms, but on humanity, as it threatens the loss of critical scientific progress.\n\nTo see the recent interview with Katie and an update on the legal battle check out the interview with Colonel MacGregor at [Our Country Our Choice.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yeDhEBwCbAM)\n\nIf you would like to help by lending your voice or contributing financially, please visit [SaveOurOstriches.com](https://bcrising.ca/save-our-ostriches/) \n\nUrgent call: Save the Ostriches!! - YouTube\n\n[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yeDhEBwCbAM&embeds_referring_euri=https%3A%2F%2Fsaveourostriches.com%2F)\n\n## Share This Story:\n\nTwitter Embed\n\n[](https://twitter.com/DougAMacgregor/status/1892674201825280319?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1892674201825280319%7Ctwgr%5E6a5690ec939e0f02f38677df8bece5a5f53266ec%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fsaveourostriches.com%2Fnews%2Fcanadian-govt-orders-killing-400-ostriches%2F)\n\nBREAKING: Canadian Government orders the k-lling of 400 Ostriches after refusing to test live birds. 400 Ostriches for You - CSSA\nCSSA, Feb 18, 2025 \nNowhere in CSSA’s mandate will you find the word “Ostrich” yet we find ourselves defending a flock of 400 Ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms in Edgewood, British Columbia, from an unjust government kill order.[i]\n“CFIA (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) expected us to walk out and kill every one of our 400 birds ourselves, with our own hands,” said ​ Karen Espersen, co-owner of Universal Ostrich Farms. “If we refused, they’d bring in a third-party execution team. This is not science—it’s cruelty wrapped in red tape.”​\n“They are not stamping out a virus. They are stamping out natural immunity. They don’t want people to realize that survival is possible,”​ said Katie Pasitney, Karen Esperson’s daughter.\nThe CFIA doesn’t have the resources to slaughter and dispose of 400 ostriches, so they want hunters to kill these majestic birds for them.\nAn internal CFIA discussion leaked to Universal Ostrich Farms posed the question, “Can we get hunters to kill these birds for us?”\nCFIA’s desire to ask third parties to kill 400 ostriches on CFIA’s behalf is corroborated by their appeal of the emergency injunction stopping the slaughter. CFIA asserts that the injunction applies only to the owners of Universal Ostrich Farms, and not to CFIA or agents acting on its behalf.[ii]\nNo, CFIA, we will not do your dirty work for you\nHunters are ethical men and women who humanely harvest wildlife to feed their families. They are not contract killers for government agencies.\nCFIA has no evidence that the 400 ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms are sick. CFIA performed PCR tests on two dead birds after 16 hours – not by conducting an autopsy or taking tissue samples, the “gold standard” in testing – and used PCR tests to rationalize killing this entire flock of majestic birds.\nThe ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms are not used for human consumption. They are research birds, crucial to a groundbreaking collaboration with Japan’s Kyoto Prefectural University, where the university’s president, Dr. Yasuhiro Tsukamoto, has successfully extracted antibodies from the birds’ eggs in an effort to create a vaccination against avian flu.[iii]\nA Warning To Anyone Considering Killing Ostriches on CFIA’s Behalf\nThis is not a fight that any regular citizen wants to get involved with. \nThere are serious criminal penalties for injuring, endangering or killing animals or birds, as well as for discharging firearms where that activity is prohibited.\nCriminal Code section 445.1 (1) deals with injuring or endangering animals.[iv]\nEvery one commits an offence who\nwilfully causes or, being the owner, wilfully permits to be caused unnecessary pain, suffering or injury to an animal or a bird;\n[deleted]\nwilfully, without reasonable excuse, administers a poisonous or an injurious drug or substance to a domestic animal or bird or an animal or a bird wild by nature that is kept in captivity or, being the owner of such an animal or a bird, wilfully permits a poisonous or an injurious drug or substance to be administered to it;\nBritish Columbia’s hunting regulations state\nIt’s unlawful to hunt or discharge a firearm within 100 metres of a church, school building, school yard, playground, regional district park, dwelling house, or farm or ranch building that is occupied by persons or domestic animals.[v]\nIt is also unlawful to discharge a firearm across or to discharge a firearm or hunt within the road allowances of any two lane public road in B.C.[vi]\nCSSA denounces CFIA’s belief it can turn ethical hunters into “government contract killers”.\nCSSA also call on our friends at the National Firearms Association and Canadian Coalition for Firearms Rights to join us in denouncing the CFIA’s actions in this case.\nBeyond The Headline\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) ordered the owners of Universal Ostrich Farms to kill their entire herd of 400 ostriches.\n“We asked if we could independently test our birds, and they said no,” explained Karen Espersen, co-owner of Universal Ostrich Farms. “We asked if we could quarantine. They said no. We asked if we could vaccinate. They said no. They don’t want solutions, they want a cull.”\nCFIA opposed independent testing so vehemently that they threatened Universal Ostrich Farms with penalties of 6 months in jail and/or a $200,000 fine for each independent test.\nThat’s not the actions of a government agency seeking the truth. Those are the actions of a government agency intent on killing an entire flock of ostriches even if those birds are 100% healthy.\n“Saving the ostriches has united the ethical scientific community and the concerned voices of people across the globe. These big, beautiful birds have shifted the conversation on science and are now bringing truth to it,” Kari Simpson says.\nDownload the Timeline of Events here: https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/CSSA/PDF/Ostrich/Universal-Ostrich-Farms-Detailed-Timeline-of-Events.pdf\nIN DETAIL: Why the Cull Order is Unjustified and Problematic\n1. Lack of Proper Testing and Scientific Rigor\nThe only evidence CFIA used to justify the cull was two positive throat swabs from already dead birds​.\nGold standard testing for Avian Influenza requires tissue sampling and full necropsies—neither of which were conducted.\nThe farm experienced Pseudomonas infections in 2020, which present similar symptoms to Avian Influenza​.\nWithout proper tissue tests, the CFIA cannot conclusively determine that H5N1 caused the ostrich deaths.\n2. Ostriches Had Developed Natural Immunity\nThe farm initially suffered some deaths, but the remaining ostriches recovered​.\nScientific research from Kyoto Prefectural University in Japan shows ostriches can generate antibodies against various diseases, including COVID-19​.\nIf the herd developed natural immunity, these birds could hold valuable genetic insights for disease resistance.\nDestroying a naturally immune flock is counterproductive to scientific advancements in avian disease mitigation.\n3. CFIA’s “Stamping Out” Policy is Outdated and Harmful\nCFIA follows a “stamping out” policy, which requires culling all birds on infected premises.\nCFIA’s “stamping out” policy cannot prevent infected wild bird populations, like mallard ducks, from infecting farm birds like ostriches, chickens, and turkeys.\nThe World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH) allows alternative strategies, such as controlled quarantine and vaccination​.\nMany other countries have opted for vaccination programs instead of mass culling.\n4. Economic and Ethical Devastation\nUniversal Ostrich Farms is a 25-year-old business with a unique genetic breeding program​.\nDestroying the flock would result in irreversible genetic loss, damaging future research and breeding efforts.\nThe cull order violates basic animal welfare principles, as the ostriches are healthy and show no signs of illness.\nThe public backlash against this order is enormous, with thousands supporting the farm’s legal battle​.\n5. Legal and Political Overreach\nThe Canadian government is prioritizing trade relationships over ethical animal management.\nThe Premises ID Program and traceability laws grant excessive power to the government over private livestock ownership​.\nCFIA’s inconsistent application of regulations (e.g., revoking “distinct unit” status without explanation) raises serious concerns about due process​.\n6. Government is Wrong to Order the Cull\nScientific failure – CFIA did not conduct proper necropsies before ordering mass slaughter.\nNatural immunity ignored – The herd likely developed resistance to the disease, which is scientifically valuable.\nAlternative solutions exist – Countries like France and Japan use vaccinations instead of mass culling.\nDevastating economic impact – The farm will be permanently destroyed if the cull proceeds.\nLegal overreach – CFIA’s decision violates the principles of fair administrative action.\nThis case is a prime example of government overreach, bad science, and bureaucratic negligence. Instead of executing a flawed mass cull, CFIA should adopt modern disease management strategies and respect farmers’ rights.\n[i] https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/CSSA/PDF/Ostrich/Cull-Order-Dec-31-2024.pdf\n[ii] https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/CSSA/PDF/Ostrich/UOF-v-CFIA—T-294-25—Order-Final-311.pdf\n[iii] https://www.rebelnews.com/save_the_ostriches\n[iv] https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-46/section-445.1.html\n[v] https://www2.gov.bc.ca/assets/gov/sports-recreation-arts-and-culture/outdoor-recreation/fishing-and-hunting/hunting/regulations/hunting-trapping-synopsis.pdf, Page 12\n[vi] ibid\nShare this Story:\nFacebook\nNO CFIA, HUNTERS ARE NOT YOUR EXECUTIONERS\nThe Canadian Shooting Sports Association stands firmly against the CFIA's desperate attempt to recruit hunters for their unjustified ostrich cull in BC.\nThese 400 ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms are research animals helping develop vaccines against avian flu. CFIA's kill order is based on inadequate testing of just two birds - no proper autopsies, no tissue samples, just quick swabs.\n...\nAs representatives of Canada's ethical hunting community, we state unequivocally: Our members are skilled conservationists who respect wildlife and hunting laws. We feed our families through legal, ethical harvest of wild game. We are NOT hired guns for bureaucratic overreach.\nLEGAL NOTICE: Any individual who participates in this unauthorized cull risks serious criminal charges under Section 445.1 of the Criminal Code and BC hunting regulations.\n#CSSA #DefendingRights #StopTheCull #CanadianHunters\nSee more\nFacebook","markdown":"# No CFIA, Hunters Won’t Kill 400 Ostriches for You - CSSA\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/image-2-1024x538.png)\n\n[**CSSA**](https://cssa-cila.org/no-cfia-hunters-wont-kill-400-ostriches-for-you/), Feb 18, 2025\n\nNowhere in CSSA’s mandate will you find the word “Ostrich” yet we find ourselves defending a flock of 400 Ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms in Edgewood, British Columbia, from an unjust government kill order.[\\[i\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_edn1)\n\n“CFIA (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) expected us to walk out and kill every one of our 400 birds ourselves, with our own hands,” said ​ Karen Espersen, co-owner of Universal Ostrich Farms. “If we refused, they’d bring in a third-party execution team. This is not science—it’s cruelty wrapped in red tape.”​\n\n“They are not stamping out a virus. They are stamping out natural immunity. They don’t want people to realize that survival is possible,”​ said Katie Pasitney, Karen Esperson’s daughter.\n\nThe CFIA doesn’t have the resources to slaughter and dispose of 400 ostriches, so they want hunters to kill these majestic birds for them.\n\nAn internal CFIA discussion leaked to Universal Ostrich Farms posed the question, “_Can we get hunters to kill these birds for us?_”\n\nCFIA’s desire to ask third parties to kill 400 ostriches on CFIA’s behalf is corroborated by their appeal of the emergency injunction stopping the slaughter. CFIA asserts that the injunction applies only to the owners of Universal Ostrich Farms, and not to CFIA or agents acting on its behalf.[\\[ii\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_edn2)\n\n### No, CFIA, we will not do your dirty work for you\n\nHunters are ethical men and women who humanely harvest wildlife to feed their families. They are not contract killers for government agencies.\n\nCFIA has **no evidence** that the 400 ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms are sick. CFIA performed PCR tests on two dead birds after 16 hours – not by **conducting an autopsy or taking tissue samples**, the “gold standard” in testing – and used PCR tests to rationalize killing this entire flock of majestic birds.\n\nThe ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms are not used for human consumption. They are research birds, crucial to a groundbreaking collaboration with Japan’s Kyoto Prefectural University, where the university’s president, Dr. Yasuhiro Tsukamoto, has successfully extracted antibodies from the birds’ eggs in an effort to create a vaccination against avian flu.[\\[iii\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_edn3)\n\n### A Warning To Anyone Considering Killing Ostriches on CFIA’s Behalf\n\nThis is not a fight that any regular citizen wants to get involved with. \n\nThere are serious criminal penalties for injuring, endangering or killing animals or birds, as well as for discharging firearms where that activity is prohibited.\n\n*   Criminal Code section 445.1 (1) deals with injuring or endangering animals.[\\[iv\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_edn4)\n    *   Every one commits an offence who\n*   wilfully causes or, being the owner, wilfully permits to be caused unnecessary pain, suffering or injury to an animal or a bird;\n*   \\[deleted\\]\n*   wilfully, without reasonable excuse, administers a poisonous or an injurious drug or substance to a domestic animal or bird or an animal or a bird wild by nature that is kept in captivity or, being the owner of such an animal or a bird, wilfully permits a poisonous or an injurious drug or substance to be administered to it;\n*   British Columbia’s hunting regulations state\n    *   **It’s unlawful to hunt or discharge a firearm within 100 metres of** **a** church, school building, school yard, playground, regional district park, dwelling house, or **farm or ranch building that is occupied by persons or domestic animals**.[\\[v\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_edn5)\n    *   It is also unlawful to discharge a firearm across or to discharge a firearm or hunt within the road allowances of **any two lane** **public road in B.C.**[\\[vi\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_edn6)\n\nCSSA denounces CFIA’s belief it can turn ethical hunters into “government contract killers”.\n\nCSSA also call on our friends at the National Firearms Association and Canadian Coalition for Firearms Rights to join us in denouncing the CFIA’s actions in this case.\n\n### Beyond The Headline\n\nThe **Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA)** ordered the owners of Universal Ostrich Farms to kill their entire herd of 400 ostriches.\n\n“We asked if we could independently test our birds, and they said no,” explained Karen Espersen, co-owner of Universal Ostrich Farms. “We asked if we could quarantine. They said no. We asked if we could vaccinate. They said no. They don’t want solutions, they want a cull.”\n\nCFIA opposed independent testing so vehemently that they threatened Universal Ostrich Farms with penalties of 6 months in jail and/or a $200,000 fine **for each independent test**.\n\nThat’s not the actions of a government agency seeking the truth. Those are the actions of a government agency intent on killing an entire flock of ostriches even if those birds are 100% healthy.\n\n“Saving the ostriches has united the ethical scientific community and the concerned voices of people across the globe. These big, beautiful birds have shifted the conversation on science and are now bringing truth to it,” Kari Simpson says.\n\n*   Download the Timeline of Events here: [https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/CSSA/PDF/Ostrich/Universal-Ostrich-Farms-Detailed-Timeline-of-Events.pdf](https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/CSSA/PDF/Ostrich/Universal-Ostrich-Farms-Detailed-Timeline-of-Events.pdf)\n\n### IN DETAIL: Why the Cull Order is Unjustified and Problematic\n\n#### 1\\. Lack of Proper Testing and Scientific Rigor\n\n*   The **only evidence CFIA used to justify the cull** was **two positive throat swabs from already dead birds**​.\n*   **Gold standard testing for Avian Influenza** requires **tissue sampling and full necropsies**—neither of which were conducted.\n*   The farm experienced **Pseudomonas infections in 2020**, which present **similar symptoms to Avian Influenza**​.\n*   Without proper **tissue tests, the CFIA cannot conclusively determine that H5N1 caused the ostrich deaths**.\n\n* * *\n\n#### 2\\. Ostriches Had Developed Natural Immunity\n\n*   The farm **initially suffered some deaths, but the remaining ostriches recovered**​.\n*   Scientific research from Kyoto Prefectural University in Japan shows ostriches **can generate antibodies against various diseases**, including COVID-19​.\n*   **If the herd developed natural immunity**, these birds could **hold valuable genetic insights** for disease resistance.\n*   **Destroying a naturally immune flock is counterproductive to scientific advancements in avian disease mitigation**.\n\n* * *\n\n#### 3\\. CFIA’s “Stamping Out” Policy is Outdated and Harmful\n\n*   CFIA follows a **“stamping out” policy**, which **requires culling all birds on infected premises**.\n*   CFIA’s **“stamping out”** policy **cannot prevent infected wild bird populations**, like mallard ducks, from infecting farm birds like ostriches, chickens, and turkeys.\n*   The **World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH)** allows **alternative strategies, such as controlled quarantine and vaccination**​.\n*   Many other countries have **opted for vaccination programs instead of mass culling**.\n\n* * *\n\n#### 4\\. Economic and Ethical Devastation\n\n*   Universal Ostrich Farms is a **25-year-old business with a unique genetic breeding program**​.\n*   **Destroying the flock would result in irreversible genetic loss**, damaging **future research and breeding efforts**.\n*   The cull order **violates basic animal welfare principles**, as the ostriches **are healthy and show no signs of illness**.\n*   The **public backlash against this order is enormous**, with **thousands supporting the farm’s legal battle**​.\n\n* * *\n\n#### 5\\. Legal and Political Overreach\n\n*   The **Canadian government is prioritizing trade relationships over ethical animal management**.\n*   The Premises ID Program and traceability laws **grant excessive power to the government over private livestock ownership**​.\n*   CFIA’s **inconsistent application of regulations** (e.g., revoking “distinct unit” status without explanation) **raises serious concerns about due process**​.\n\n* * *\n\n#### 6\\. Government is Wrong to Order the Cull\n\n1.  **Scientific failure** – CFIA did **not conduct proper necropsies** before ordering mass slaughter.\n2.  **Natural immunity ignored** – The herd likely **developed resistance to the disease**, which is **scientifically valuable**.\n3.  **Alternative solutions exist** – Countries like France and Japan **use vaccinations** instead of mass culling.\n4.  **Devastating economic impact** – The farm **will be permanently destroyed** if the cull proceeds.\n5.  **Legal overreach** – CFIA’s decision **violates the principles of fair administrative action**.\n\nThis case is a **prime example of government overreach, bad science, and bureaucratic negligence**. Instead of **executing a flawed mass cull**, CFIA should **adopt modern disease management strategies and respect farmers’ rights**.\n\n* * *\n\n[\\[i\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_ednref1) [https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/CSSA/PDF/Ostrich/Cull-Order-Dec-31-2024.pdf](https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/CSSA/PDF/Ostrich/Cull-Order-Dec-31-2024.pdf)\n\n[\\[ii\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_ednref2) [https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/CSSA/PDF/Ostrich/UOF-v-CFIA—T-294-25—Order-Final-311.pdf](https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/CSSA/PDF/Ostrich/UOF-v-CFIA---T-294-25---Order-Final-311.pdf)\n\n[\\[iii\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_ednref3) [https://www.rebelnews.com/save\\_the\\_ostriches](https://www.rebelnews.com/save_the_ostriches)\n\n[\\[iv\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_ednref4) [https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-46/section-445.1.html](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-46/section-445.1.html)\n\n[\\[v\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_ednref5) [https://www2.gov.bc.ca/assets/gov/sports-recreation-arts-and-culture/outdoor-recreation/fishing-and-hunting/hunting/regulations/hunting-trapping-synopsis.pdf](https://www2.gov.bc.ca/assets/gov/sports-recreation-arts-and-culture/outdoor-recreation/fishing-and-hunting/hunting/regulations/hunting-trapping-synopsis.pdf), Page 12\n\n[\\[vi\\]](applewebdata://EF239583-7FE5-4F5D-B821-54DB6B295BE8#_ednref6) ibid\n\n## Share this NO CFIA, HUNTERS ARE NOT YOUR EXECUTIONERS\n\nThe Canadian Shooting Sports Association stands firmly against the CFIA's desperate attempt to recruit hunters for their unjustified ostrich cull in BC.\n\nThese 400 ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms are research animals helping develop vaccines against avian flu. CFIA's kill order is based on inadequate testing of just two birds - no proper autopsies, no tissue samples, just quick swabs.\n\n...\n\nAs representatives of Canada's ethical hunting community, we state unequivocally: Our members are skilled conservationists who respect wildlife and hunting laws. We feed our families through legal, ethical harvest of wild game. We are NOT hired guns for bureaucratic overreach.\n\n![⚠](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/26a0.svg) LEGAL NOTICE: Any individual who participates in this unauthorized cull risks serious criminal charges under Section 445.1 of the Criminal Code and BC hunting regulations.\n\n[#CSSA](https://saveourostriches.com/hashtag/cssa?__eep__=6&fref=mentions&ref=embed_post) [#DefendingRights](https://saveourostriches.com/hashtag/defendingrights?__eep__=6&fref=mentions&ref=embed_post) [#StopTheCull](https://saveourostriches.com/hashtag/stopthecull?__eep__=6&fref=mentions&ref=embed_post) [#CanadianHunters](https://saveourostriches.com/hashtag/canadianhunters?__eep__=6&fref=mentions&ref=embed_post)\n\n[See more](https://saveourostriches.com/cdnshootingsports/posts/1047241550768535?ref=embed_post)\n\nFacebook\n\n[![](https://static.xx.fbcdn.net/rsrc.php/v4/yw/r/wguUF-i5kBB.png)](https://saveourostriches.com/SaveOurOstriches/posts/122099925878772897?ref=embed_post)","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

that halted cull of 400 ostriches on BC family farm\nWestern Standard · Jarryd Jäger · Feb 12, 2025\nThe federal government has appealed a court ruling that temporarily halted the culling of 400 ostriches on a family farm in British Columbia.\nLawyers for the Department of Justice acting on behalf of Canadian Food Inspection Agency also asked for an expedited hearing of the judicial review and clarification of the injunction order issued by Justice Michael Battista.\nThe owners of Universal Ostrich Farm, Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski, have vowed to keep fighting.\n“It is obvious, in addition to the emotional assault, the deliberate infliction of psychological pain and suffering, bankrupting us by destroying our business, the CFIA is now amping up their legal assault against us in the hope we will finally break,” spokesperson Katie Pasitney said.\nIn their appeal, the government argued that Battista “erred in law and in principle, and/or seriously misapprehended the facts in “finding that irreparable harm … would flow to the Respondent if an injunction were not granted.”\nThe government also suggested that the justice made a mistake by “erroneously concluding that not issuing the injunction would render the underlying application moot,” as well as by suggesting that the farm had “a range of options under the Health of Animals Act to address its concerns regarding public safety.” Lawyers for the DOJ held on to their belief that “there were no options other than disposal of the ostriches,”\nBattista was also accused of “failing to account for or seriously misapprehending the facts concerning public interest factors that overwhelmingly favoured not issuing an injunction.”\nThe CFIA ordered the birds killed by February 1 after two of their deceased herd-mates tested positive for H5N1, better known as avian flu. It was only on January 31 that the emergency injunction was filed, calling for a judicial review to be completed before any animal was slaughtered.\nThe government has called into question whether the injunction only applies to the family, or if the CFIA can cull the birds themselves.\nThe saga began in December, when an avian flu outbreak was declared at the farm. Espersen said she believed the disease was brought to their property by a flock of migrating ducks, who took shelter in the barn.\nInitially, the farm saw as many as four ostriches dying per day, but eventually the deaths petered out. Pasitney said this was evidence that the birds had acquired herd immunity.\nNonetheless, when the CFIA got wind of the outbreak in December, they sent a team out to investigate, and after testing two carcasses, determined that the entire herd had to be culled. This was incomprehensible to the owners and their families, who have developed strong relationships with each individual bird.\nShare this Story:\nTwitter Embed\nFeds appeal court ruling that paused Standard**](https://www.westernstandard.news/news/firearms-group-slams-cfia-after-feds-consider-asking-hunters-to-kill-400-ostriches-on-bc-family-farm/62274) · [](https://www.westernstandard.news/author/jjaeger)[Jarryd Jäger](https://www.westernstandard.news/author/jjaeger) · Feb 12, 2025\n\nThe federal government has appealed a court ruling that temporarily halted the culling of 400 ostriches on a family farm in British Columbia.\n\nLawyers for the Department of Justice acting on behalf of Canadian Food Inspection Agency also asked for an expedited hearing of the judicial review and clarification of the injunction order issued by Justice Michael Battista.\n\nThe owners of Universal Ostrich Farm, Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski, have vowed to keep fighting.\n\n“It is obvious, in addition to the emotional assault, the deliberate infliction of psychological pain and suffering, bankrupting us by destroying our business, the CFIA is now amping up their legal assault against us in the hope we will finally break,” spokesperson Katie Pasitney said.\n\nIn their appeal, the government argued that Battista “erred in law and in principle, and/or seriously misapprehended the facts in “finding that irreparable harm … would flow to the Respondent if an injunction were not granted.”\n\nThe government also suggested that the justice made a mistake by “erroneously concluding that not issuing the injunction would render the underlying application moot,” as well as by suggesting that the farm had “a range of options under the Health of Animals Act to address its concerns regarding public safety.” Lawyers for the DOJ held on to their belief that “there were no options other than disposal of the ostriches,”\n\nBattista was also accused of “failing to account for or seriously misapprehending the facts concerning public interest factors that overwhelmingly favoured not issuing an injunction.”\n\nThe CFIA ordered the birds killed by February 1 after two of their deceased herd-mates tested positive for H5N1, better known as avian flu. It was only on January 31 that the emergency injunction was filed, calling for a judicial review to be completed before any animal was slaughtered.\n\nThe government has called into question whether the injunction only applies to the family, or if the CFIA can cull the birds themselves.\n\nThe saga began in December, when an avian flu outbreak was declared at the farm. Espersen said she believed the disease was brought to their property by a flock of migrating ducks, who took shelter in the barn.\n\nInitially, the farm saw as many as four ostriches dying per day, but eventually the deaths petered out. Pasitney said this was evidence that the birds had acquired herd immunity.\n\nNonetheless, when the CFIA got wind of the outbreak in December, they sent a team out to investigate, and after testing two carcasses, determined that the entire herd had to be culled. This was incomprehensible to the owners and their families, who have developed strong relationships with each individual bird.\n\n## Share this Story:\n\nTwitter Embed\n\n[](https://twitter.com/WSOnlineNews/status/1889815598177103903?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1889815598177103903%7Ctwgr%5Ead6f0eeed3072db0fd527e3f426b4afe715b4994%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fsaveourostriches.com%2Fnews%2Ffeds-appeal-court-ruling-that-halted-cull-of-400-ostriches-on-bc-family-farm%2F)\n\nFeds appeal court ruling that paused cull of 400 ostriches on BC family farm","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

It threatens to destroy a family-run ostrich farm spanning decades … all in the name of protecting public health.\nFounded in 1995, Universal Ostrich Farm sells bird oil, feathers and skins to international markets. Their eggs are also shipped to a university in Japan, where scientists work to develop an H5N1 vaccine to combat avian flu pandemics.\n“If we allow them to do this when we have science sitting here, and we have the ability to help mitigate the migratory risk of the avian flu and stabilize it worldwide, and if we can’t stop that here with our 400, there’s no saving anyone else’s farms,” B.C. farmer Katie Pasitney told Rebel News.\nAfter an H5N1 outbreak on the farm last fall, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) ordered all the birds on the farm be killed, reported the Vancouver Sun. If the family cannot kill the birds themselves by February 1, 2025, the agency intends to hire a third party to carry out the cull.\n“This is the opening up [of] Pandora’s box and my eyes to government [overreach],” said Pasitney, the adult daughter of the farm’s owner. \nHaving grown up with these birds, she describes in detail how they found themselves awaiting the death order, a measure she considers senseless and unjust. If the CFIA refuses to revise their culling order for the apparently healthy flock, it could set a dangerous precedent for farmers across Canada.\nPasitney says farmers have the right to raise their livestock how they want without government interference. “If they are allowed to do this to our 400-pound animals, you’re next.”\nAgency officials recently canceled an in-person visit to the quarantine zone this month on account of a peaceful protest away from the effected animals. They followed up with a threat to involve the RCMP.\n“We can’t shoot them [the ostriches]. That will cause mass panic. We can’t gas them because we don’t have an enclosed space like a chicken farm. Maybe we slit their throats, but they run at 65 kilometres an hour,” Pasitney told the Sun in a prior interview.\n“These are just farmers trying to make the world a better place,” she said. “We need to stand together as farmers, as mothers, [and] fathers … and we need to protect what we have left for our children.”\nShare This Story\nTwitter Embed\nSAVE THE OSTRICHES! Help stop the Canadian government's cruel killing order Hundreds of healthy, immune ostriches are set to be slaughtered by government mandate while groundbreaking research and a family farm’s livelihood hang in the balance.","markdown":"# Power-hungry feds threaten science, livelihoods with order to cull ostriches – Rebel News\n\n**[Rebel News](https://www.rebelnews.com/power_hungry_feds_order_culling_of_ostrich_farm)** · Drea Humphrey · January 24, 2025\n\nIn case you missed it, the federal government has order the culling of some 400 ostriches, after an avian flu outbreak. It threatens to destroy a family-run ostrich farm spanning decades … all in the name of protecting public health.\n\nFounded in 1995, Universal Ostrich Farm sells bird oil, feathers and skins to international markets. Their eggs are also shipped to a university in Japan, where scientists work to develop an H5N1 vaccine to combat avian flu pandemics.\n\n“If we allow them to do this when we have science sitting here, and we have the ability to help mitigate the migratory risk of the avian flu and stabilize it worldwide, and if we can’t stop that here with our 400, there’s no saving anyone else’s farms,” B.C. farmer Katie Pasitney told _Rebel News_.\n\nAfter an H5N1 outbreak on the farm last fall, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) ordered all the birds on the farm be killed, [reported](https://vancouversun.com/news/bc-ostrich-farm-ordered-to-kill-400-birds-after-avian-flu-outbreak) the _Vancouver Sun_. If the family cannot kill the birds themselves by February 1, 2025, the agency intends to hire a third party to carry out the cull.\n\n“This is the opening up \\[of\\] Pandora’s box and my eyes to government \\[overreach\\],” said Pasitney, the adult daughter of the farm’s owner. \n\nHaving grown up with these birds, she describes in detail how they found themselves awaiting the death order, a measure she considers senseless and unjust. If the CFIA refuses to revise their culling order for the apparently healthy flock, it could set a dangerous precedent for farmers across Canada.\n\nPasitney says farmers have the right to raise their livestock how they want without government interference. “If they are allowed to do this to our 400-pound animals, you’re next.”\n\nAgency officials recently canceled an in-person visit to the quarantine zone this month on account of a peaceful protest away from the effected animals. They followed up with a threat to involve the RCMP.\n\n“We can’t shoot them \\[the ostriches\\]. That will cause mass panic. We can’t gas them because we don’t have an enclosed space like a chicken farm. Maybe we slit their throats, but they run at 65 kilometres an hour,” Pasitney told the _Sun_ in a prior interview.\n\n“These are just farmers trying to make the world a better place,” she said. “We need to stand together as farmers, as mothers, \\[and\\] fathers … and we need to protect what we have left for our children.”\n\n## Share This Story\n\nTwitter Embed\n\n[](https://twitter.com/RebelNewsOnline/status/1882926430578729253?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1882926430578729253%7Ctwgr%5E6c01071cedd2136ebbe17a9e5d7969bd99db4076%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fsaveourostriches.com%2Fnews%2Fpower-hungry-feds-threaten-science-livelihoods-with-order-to-cull-ostriches%2F)\n\n![🚨](https://abs-0.twimg.com/emoji/v2/svg/1f6a8.svg)SAVE THE OSTRICHES! He’s like a big, friendly puppy, always following us around and loving every bit of attention he can get. At Universal Ostrich Farms, he’s happiest when he’s by our side, just enjoying the company. His life? Pretty amazing, if you ask him.\nHelp Save Arnold\nMeet Arnold, He’s healthy, happy, and loved by everyone at Universal Ostrich Farms. His wisdom and gentle nature make him a respected member of the herd.\nHelp Save Q-Tip\nMeet Q-Tip. He’s the head of the pecking order and takes his role very seriously. Always looking out for his herd, Q-Tips’ motto is simple: “I rule and protect my family.” He’s the one in charge at Universal Ostrich Farms, and everyone knows it.\nHelp Save Anna\nMeet Anna. She’s feisty, confident, and always full of attitude at Universal Ostrich Farms. With her cool demeanor and bold personality, Anna stands out among the flock, never afraid to show off her unique style and energy.\nHelp Save Priscilla\nMeet Priscilla. Confident and strong in spirit, she prefers to stay out of the spotlight, quietly watching over those she cares about. Fiercely protective of her family and friends, Priscilla’s loyalty runs deep. Her steady yet powerful presence makes her both lovable and highly respected among the herd.\nHelp Save Kickaroo\nMeet Kickaroo. Kickaroo is full of energy and when she gets very excited, she loves to kick her legs. Kickaroo’s lively spirit makes her a favourite at Universal Ostrich Farms. Always on the move, Kickaroo brings nonstop energy to the flock. Her playful kicks and vibrant personality make her a standout among the ostriches.\nHelp Save Bonnie\nMeet Bonnie. She’s serious and a bit shy, but don’t let that fool you—Bonnie has plenty of attitude. Loyal and steadfast, she’s always there for her herd, keeping a watchful eye while quietly observing everything around her.\nHelp Save Frank\nFrank is no ordinary ostrich—he’s the heart and soul of Universal Ostrich Farms. With his distinctive fluffy feathers and a personality as big as his heart, Frank has become the farm’s beloved mascot. Known for his protective nature, Frank is especially close to Lulu, always keeping a watchful eye over her. When he’s not strutting around to impress the other ostriches, Frank is the first to stand up for what’s right, especially when it comes to protecting the farm and the animals he loves.\nHelp Save Erica\nMeet Erica. Erica is fiercely loyal to her family, and her dedication to their well-being makes her a key member of the farm. Kind and considerate, she’s known for looking out for others and offering a steady, reliable presence. Her strong, unwavering spirit ensures that everyone around her feels safe and supported.\nHelp Save Speckles\nMeet Speckles. He’s a serious guy who can stare into your soul and make you question your life choices. Fiercely loyal and loving with his whole heart, Speckles may seem intense, but he’s definitely a softie at heart. A farm favorite, he’s the kind of ostrich who’ll stand guard and make sure everything is running smoothly on the farm.\nHelp Save Lulu\nLulu is the gentle and graceful companion of Frank at Universal Ostrich Farms. Known for her sleek feathers and gentle nature, she brings a sense of peace to the farm. Lulu’s strong spirit and quiet confidence make her a cherished member of the farm.\nHelp Save Shelly\nMeet Shelly. As one of the older ostriches, she’s well-loved and cared for at Universal Ostrich Farms. Shelly has a playful side, often seen dancing and fluffing her feathers with joy. Her graceful movements and warm personality make her a cherished member of the ostrich family.\nHelp Save Kari\nMeet Kari. She’s big and bold, with a boisterous personality that’s impossible to ignore. Strong and steadfast, Kari stands her ground when it counts, always unwavering in her resolve. Her commanding presence and confidence make her a standout member of the herd.\nHelp Save Spike\nMeet Spike. Tough and protective, he’s the kind of ostrich who makes sure nobody messes with the herd. With a no-nonsense attitude and a fierce loyalty, Spike’s always on guard, ready to stand up for those he cares about. If you’re looking for someone to keep things in check, Spike’s your guy.\nHelp Save Spirit\nMeet Spirit. True to her name, she’s a beautiful and peaceful presence at Universal Ostrich Farms. With a serene demeanour and gentle nature, Spirit moves through life with quiet grace. Her calm and soothing presence brings a sense of tranquility to the flock, making her a beloved member of the farm.\nHelp Save Precious\nMeet Precious. True to her name, she’s a gentle and endearing ostrich who is cherished by everyone at Universal Ostrich Farms. With her sweet nature and calm demeanor, Precious has a way of making everyone around her feel special.
