What is the goal here? To save healthy animals from an inhumane and unjustified death.\nOur shared mission is simple and powerful: to protect healthy animals, and ultimately people, from an unnecessary, inhumane fate. Let’s rise above the noise of accusations and focus on the real questions that deserve thoughtful answers. Farmers are juggling biosecurity measures, animal care, community concerns and so much more – this isn’t about avoiding hard conversations, it’s about supporting those who work tirelessly as farmers and for what is right.\nIf you read something you are not sure of or need clarification, please first refer to this living document at SaveOurOstriches.com. If questions still linger, feel free to email SaveOurOstriches@gmail.com before sharing possibly inaccurate information.\nAsking questions is much more productive than sharing unverified and misunderstood portions of information. Please consider that sharing false information and statements can be considered defamation, will damage the farm’s reputation and increase our farm’s exposure to harm.\nWhen we choose collaboration over conflict we are stopping ‘shaking the ants’ actions, and instead forging a stronger, kinder and united future for our animals, farmers, and community.\nOfficial Statement from Universal Ostrich Farms Inc.\nMay 21, 2025\nBackground \nFor over 30 years, business partners Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski have upheld the highest standards in animal welfare and scientific integrity. Below, we clarify our history, practices, and recent challenges to address misinformation and affirm our dedication to transparency. \nFounding and Operations: Incorporated in 2001, Universal Ostrich Farms Inc., led by Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski, has ethically raised ostriches for three decades with a focus on ethical breeding and care. \nStruthio Bioscience Inc: Launched in May 2022, this division partnered with Dr. Tsukamoto of Kyoto University to develop and purify ostrich-derived antibodies (IgY) for research and therapeutic applications. \nMission: To advance sustainable farming and contribute to scientific progress through safe, non-invasive antibody production. \nAntigen Research vs. Vaccination \nAntigen Exposure: In our projects we used only non-infectious antigens to stimulate antibody production in laying hens’ egg yolks while doing research. This is a standard process that is being used in natural avian antibody production. These fragments cannot cause disease. Antibodies are safely harvested from egg yolks without harming the birds. \nTerminology Clarified: \nInoculation – The deliberate introduction of a pure antigen (by injection or any way of entry to the body), without any additional substances, to induce immunity and antibody production. \nAntigen exposure – Is not a vaccine. It uses non-infectious fragments to prime immunity. \nVaccination – The process of administration of a vaccine. \nVaccine – A substance that contains disease causing preparation of killed, weakened, or part of a microorganism, as well as adjuvants, preservatives, and chemicals, to stimulate the immune system to protect against disease in the future. \nImmunization – The broad term for any process (natural or artificial) that readies the immune system to fight a potential invader. It represents both vaccination and inoculation processes. \nSafety: Our antigen exposure process is distinct from vaccination, using ostriches’ natural immune systems. We do NOT produce antibodies with live viruses or mRNA. \nFarm Operations and Health History \nCurrent Focus: Since 2020, we have focused on breeding, antibody research, and supporting new farmers that want to get into the agriculture industry. Meat processing ceased in the summer of 2019. \n2020 Pseudomonas Outbreak: In March 2020, a diagnosis of Pseudomonas bacterial infection confirmed by a lab and veterinarian, affected ≈3% of birds (10 birds total) with survivors developing natural and eventual herd immunity. No further outbreaks or disease occurred until December 2024. \nBird Sales: In June 2021, six birds (neither injected with antigens nor offspring of injected hens) were sold for breeding, not food, as breeders are too valuable for slaughter. No injected birds entered the food chain. \nCOVID-19 Antibody Research (2020–2021) \nCollaboration: Periods in April to October in both 2020 and 2021, we contracted out Immune BioSolutions for them to provide an antigen, which has been historically given to chickens, and to extract and purify the Universal Ostrich Farm antibodies under regular common non-disclosure confidentiality clauses on COVID-19 antibody research. Separately, Immune BioSolutions received a $13.44 Million grant from the Canadian government for their own work. Universal Ostrich Farms and Struthio BioScience did not receive any payment, funding or benefit from Immune BioSolutions nor directly from the Government. Instead, the farm’s contract was abruptly terminated, without any reason presented to the farm.\nAntigen Use: Immune BioSolutions provided pre-tested antigens to stimulate antibodies in hens (not roosters). These were 98% effective at neutralizing antibodies against COVID-19 and its variants, with ostrich antibodies outperforming chicken antibodies by 30–40%. \nProject Termination: The contract with the farm abruptly halted as mentioned above, with no reasons provided. Immune BioSolutions retained some of the farm’s most effective antibodies. Again, no payments came to the farm from Immune BioSolutions. \nJapanese Research \nJapanese Collaboration: Unrelated to Universal Ostrich Farm, Dr. Tsukamoto, a Japanese government-funded Kyoto University president, tested Covid-19 antibody-infused mask liners in Japan. This was Tsukamoto’s OWN research with his own ostriches, as he has his own farm. He offered H5N1 antibodies to the Canadian government in 2025, receiving no response. Universal Ostrich Farm did not produce or sell masks and have no ties to the World Economic Forum (WEF). What, if any, affiliations that Dr. Tsukamoto may have with WEF is unknown to us and our farm. \nDecember 2024–January 2025 Health Events \nInitial Case: On December 10, 2024, a 3-year-old ostrich hen developed pneumonia-like symptoms, presenting the same symptoms as 2020 (see above). This hen was treated using the same protocols prescribed by the vet in 2020. The hen fully recovered and is alive and well today. \nOutbreak: From December 14, 2024, to January 14, 2025, 69 young male and female breeders died, most of them under four years old. These young breeders were born or acquired after 2020, therefore they were lacking the 2020 Pseudomonas immunity. The 69 died over 31 days (~2/day). Each sick bird was immediately quarantined and many recovered with treatments. \nDistinction from HPAI: Unlike High Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI), which is said to kill entire avian flocks in 24 hours, this farm’s illness resulted in only approximately 15% of deaths which occurred over 31 days as it slowly ran its course until reaching full herd immunity on January 14th. According to CFIA lab documents, this illness involves a new hybrid of Low Pathogenic (LPAI) and High Pathogenic (HPAI) Avian Influenza, confirmed by PCR testing done by CFIA, in their internal and self-regulated labs. The LPAI portion of this hybrid is important in indicating that this illness is much less deadly, as per CFIA. \nCFIA Testing and Cull Order \nCFIA Involvement: Following an anonymous tip on December 28th , 2024, CFIA called the farm and agreed, based on symptoms, this did not sound like avian influenza. CFIA told the farm to call when they had 2 new carcasses available for testing. On December 29th , the farm called CFIA as there were 2 more deaths. \nCFIA tested the two carcasses on December 30, 2024, with preliminary H5 results from an internal self-regulated CFIA/Ministry of Agriculture lab in Abbotsford, BC. A cull order was signed and issued 41 minutes after the PCR test results were known, before N1 confirmation from the Winnipeg internal self-regulated CFIA lab results were known on January 10, 2025.\nNo details of the testing, handling, and shipment of the test samples have been disclosed, even upon multiple requests by the farm. This chain of custody is normally provided to ensure proper procedures are followed to avoid flawed results. Additionally, CFIA orders state that NO testing, including third party testing can be done. In fact, the farm is under order that they cannot treat or test their own animals, which the farm normally does themselves. \nTesting Restrictions: Independent “gold-standard” tissue testing and any other testing of any kind is prohibited, with threats of $200,000 fines and/or six months in jail for conducting our own tests, as per Health of Animals Act Section 66.b. Thus, only PCR testing was done by CFIA on two carcasses. It is commonly believed that PCR testing is limited and contradictory. PCR is not the gold standard testing method and is not recommended as a diagnostic tool. \nExemption and Rejection: A “rare genetics” exemption was promised by a CFIA officer in writing on January 2, 2025 but was rejected 8 days later, on January 10, In a CFIA “Distinct Unit Package” exemption request form. The farm was told if any answers were NO that they would immediately get denied an exemption. BUT, the form was intended for commercial poultry thus nothing on the form was relevant for a non-commercial Ostrich farm. \nLegal Actions and Court Outcomes \nInjunction: On January 31, 2025 Universal Ostrich farm won an injunction to pause a February 1 cull order, compelling CFIA to justify its decision via Judicial Review based limited to only data known from December 31, 2024, to January 10, 2025.\nJudicial Review: On April 15–16, 2025, a Federal Court in Vancouver reviewed all evidence pertaining to the Notice to Dispose Order issued on December 31st, 2024 and the Exemption Denial dated January 10th, 2025. The Judgement and Reasons were posted on May 13, 2025, exactly 27 days after the hearing ended. Under administrative law, Justice Zinn’s hands were tied.\nAs Judge Zinn quoted in his decision in Paragraph 3:\n“This is not an appeal. The Court is not stepping into the shoes of the Agency and making the decisions that the Court feels ought to have been made. Instead, the focus of the review is on the Agency’s reasoning and process.” \nContinuing to Paragraph 5: \n“Courts must respect Parliament’s choice to assign decision-making power to administrative bodies. This respect comes from the principle of separation of powers a cornerstone of Canadian public law” \nThe Judge couldn’t consider anything after January 10th , including the fact that Universal Ostrich Farm has had no illness or deaths since January 14, 2025. \nAs the Judge revealed, it was not within his power to determine what was right or wrong. The court’s rule was limited to whether the CFIA exercised their policies and acted within reasonable fairness. It is the CFIA’s policies that need to be challenged and changed, and that cannot be done in a judicial review. A separate action needs to be filed for this. \nRDCK Statement: On May 15, 2025, supported by intense public pressure, the Regional District of Central Kootenay (RDCK) voted unanimously that CFIA test all healthy ostriches before considering the 400 healthy carcasses weighing ~140,000 pounds, proposed for disposal at the RDCK Ootischenia Landfill near Castlegar, BC. \nCurrent Status: Judge Zinn upheld CFIA’s narrow arguments allowing a potential cull of 400 ostriches despite their perfect health status with no illness or deaths for four months. \nCompensation and Fines \nCompensation Uncertainty: CFIA lists up to $3,000 per poultry bird online as per a January 27, 2025, news release, but no ostrich-specific value is defined. No compensation communication has been received as of May 20, 2025, and $3,000 per bird is far below their true value. The ongoing market value of an ostrich rooster is $7500 CDN each. The value of an antibody-producing hen is $93,000 CDN each. Compensation can be voided by CFIA as per below. Worth noting, are you are aware, that us all, as taxpayers pay for all CFIA actions, wages and costs. This includes all culling processes, compensation to farmers, court, travel, etc. \nFines: Two unjustified $10,000 fines threaten to eliminate any compensation. Both fines were challenged and documents filed to CFIA. We are working to have these overturned. CFIA told a reporter that compensation is only when farms are compliant – taking them to court is far from compliant. \nCommitment to Transparency \nUniversal Ostrich Farms Inc. remains dedicated to ethical farming, rigorous science, and public safety. Our antibody research has shown immense potential, yet we face significant challenges from regulatory overreach and misinformation. We call for fair, science-based assessments and urge citizens to hold authorities accountable with the same scrutiny. For further inquiries, contact Universal Ostrich Farms Inc. or SaveOurOstriches.com directly. \nSigned, \nKaren Espersen & Dave Bilinski \nUniversal Ostrich Farms Inc.","markdown":"# Official Statement from Universal Ostrich Farms Inc., May 21, 2025\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/DaveAndKaren-1024x768.png)\n\nWhile questions are always welcome, imagine the progress we would all make if every citizen held the government to this same level of scrutiny. What is the goal here? To save healthy animals from an inhumane and unjustified death.\n\nOur shared mission is simple and powerful: to protect healthy animals, and ultimately people, from an unnecessary, inhumane fate. Let’s rise above the noise of accusations and focus on the real questions that deserve thoughtful answers. Farmers are juggling biosecurity measures, animal care, community concerns and so much more – this isn’t about avoiding hard conversations, it’s about supporting those who work tirelessly as farmers and for what is right.\n\n    If you read something you are not sure of or need clarification, please first refer to this living document at SaveOurOstriches.com. If questions still linger, feel free to email SaveOurOstriches@gmail.com before sharing possibly inaccurate information.\n\nAsking questions is much more productive than sharing unverified and misunderstood portions of information.  Please consider that sharing false information and statements can be considered defamation, will damage the farm’s reputation and increase our farm’s exposure to harm.\n\nWhen we choose collaboration over conflict we are stopping ‘shaking the ants’ actions, and instead forging a stronger, kinder and united future for our animals, farmers, and community.\n\n## **Official Statement from Universal Ostrich Farms Inc.**\n\nMay 21, 2025\n\n### **Background**  \n\nFor over 30 years, business partners Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski have upheld the highest standards in animal welfare and scientific integrity. Below, we clarify our history, practices, and recent challenges to address misinformation and affirm our dedication to transparency.  \n\n **Founding and Operations:** Incorporated in 2001, Universal Ostrich Farms Inc., led by Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski, has ethically raised ostriches for three decades with a focus on ethical breeding and care.   \n\n **Struthio Bioscience Inc:** Launched in May 2022, this division partnered with Dr. Tsukamoto of Kyoto University to develop and purify ostrich-derived antibodies (IgY) for research and therapeutic applications.   \n\n**Mission:** To advance sustainable farming and contribute to scientific progress through safe, non-invasive antibody production.  \n\n### **Antigen Research vs. Vaccination**  \n\n**Antigen Exposure:** In our projects we used only non-infectious antigens to stimulate antibody production in laying hens’ egg yolks while doing research. This is a standard process that is being used in natural avian antibody production. These fragments cannot cause disease. Antibodies are safely harvested from egg yolks without harming the birds.   \n\n**Terminology Clarified:**   \n\n*   **Inoculation** – The deliberate **introduction of a pure antigen** (by injection or any way of entry to the body), without any additional substances, to induce immunity and antibody production.  \n*   **Antigen exposure** – Is not a vaccine. It uses non-infectious fragments to prime immunity.  \n*   **Vaccination** – The process of administration of a **vaccine**.  \n*   **Vaccine** – A substance that contains disease causing preparation of killed, weakened, or part of a microorganism, as well as adjuvants, preservatives, and chemicals, to stimulate the immune system to protect against disease in the future.  \n*   **Immunization** – The broad term for any process (natural or artificial) that readies the immune system to fight a potential invader. It represents both vaccination and inoculation processes.   \n\n**Safety:** Our antigen exposure process is distinct from vaccination, using ostriches’ natural immune systems. We do NOT produce antibodies with live viruses or mRNA.  \n\n### **Farm Operations and Health History** \n\n**Current Focus:** Since 2020, we have focused on breeding, antibody research, and supporting new farmers that want to get into the agriculture industry. Meat processing ceased in the summer of 2019.  \n\n **2020 Pseudomonas Outbreak:** In March 2020, a diagnosis of Pseudomonas bacterial infection confirmed by a lab and veterinarian, affected ≈3% of birds (10 birds total) with survivors developing natural and eventual herd immunity. No further outbreaks or disease occurred until December 2024.   \n\n **Bird Sales:** In June 2021, six birds (neither injected with antigens nor offspring of injected hens) were sold for breeding, not food, as breeders are too valuable for slaughter. No injected birds entered the food chain.  \n\n### **COVID-19 Antibody Research (2020–2021)**  \n\n**Collaboration:** Periods in April to October in both 2020 and 2021, we contracted out Immune BioSolutions for them to provide an antigen, which has been historically given to chickens, and to extract and purify the Universal Ostrich Farm antibodies under regular common non-disclosure confidentiality clauses on COVID-19 antibody research. Separately, Immune BioSolutions received a $13.44 Million grant from the Canadian government for their own work. Universal Ostrich Farms and Struthio BioScience did not receive any payment, funding or benefit from Immune BioSolutions nor directly from the Government. Instead, the farm’s contract was abruptly terminated, without any reason presented to the farm.\n\n**Antigen Use:** Immune BioSolutions provided pre-tested antigens to stimulate antibodies in hens (not roosters). These were 98% effective at neutralizing antibodies against COVID-19 and its variants, with ostrich antibodies outperforming chicken antibodies by 30–40%.  \n\n**Project Termination:** The contract with the farm abruptly halted as mentioned above, with no reasons provided. Immune BioSolutions retained some of the farm’s most effective antibodies.  Again, no payments came to the farm from Immune BioSolutions. \n\n### **Japanese Research**  \n\n**Japanese Collaboration:**  Unrelated to Universal Ostrich Farm, Dr. Tsukamoto, a Japanese government-funded Kyoto University president, tested Covid-19 antibody-infused mask liners in Japan. This was Tsukamoto’s OWN research with his own ostriches, as he has his own farm. He offered H5N1 antibodies to the Canadian government in 2025, receiving no response. Universal Ostrich Farm **did not produce or sell masks** and have no ties to the World Economic Forum (WEF). What, if any, affiliations that Dr. Tsukamoto may have with WEF is unknown to us and our farm.  \n\n### **December 2024–January 2025 Health Events**  \n\n**Initial Case:** On December 10, 2024, a 3-year-old ostrich hen developed pneumonia-like symptoms, presenting the same symptoms as 2020 (see above). This hen was treated using the same protocols prescribed by the vet in 2020. The hen fully recovered and is alive and well today.   \n\n **Outbreak:** From December 14, 2024, to January 14, 2025, 69 young male and female breeders died, most of them under four years old. These young breeders were born or acquired after 2020, therefore they were lacking the 2020 Pseudomonas immunity. The 69 died over 31 days (~2/day). Each sick bird was immediately quarantined and many recovered with treatments.   \n\n **Distinction from HPAI:** Unlike High Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI), which is said to kill entire avian flocks in 24 hours, this farm’s illness resulted in only approximately 15% of deaths which occurred over 31 days as it slowly ran its course until reaching full herd immunity on January 14th. According to CFIA lab documents, this illness involves a new hybrid of Low Pathogenic (LPAI) and High Pathogenic (HPAI) Avian Influenza, confirmed by PCR testing done by CFIA, in their internal and self-regulated labs.  The LPAI portion of this hybrid is important in indicating that this illness is much less deadly, as per CFIA. \n\n### **CFIA Testing and Cull Order**  \n\n**CFIA Involvement:** Following an anonymous tip on December 28th , 2024, CFIA called the farm and agreed, based on symptoms, this did not sound like avian influenza. CFIA told the farm to call when they had 2 new carcasses available for testing. On December 29th , the farm called CFIA as there were 2 more deaths.  \n\nCFIA tested the two carcasses on December 30, 2024, with preliminary H5 results from an internal self-regulated CFIA/Ministry of Agriculture lab in Abbotsford, BC. A cull order was signed and issued 41 minutes after the PCR test results were known, before N1 confirmation from the Winnipeg internal self-regulated CFIA lab results were known on January 10, 2025.\n\nNo details of the testing, handling, and shipment of the test samples have been disclosed, even upon multiple requests by the farm. This chain of custody is normally provided to ensure proper procedures are followed to avoid flawed results. Additionally, CFIA orders state that NO testing, including third party testing can be done. In fact, the farm is under order that they cannot treat or test their own animals, which the farm normally does themselves.  \n\n**Testing Restrictions:** Independent “gold-standard” tissue testing and any other testing of any kind is prohibited, with threats of $200,000 fines and/or six months in jail for conducting our own tests, as per Health of Animals Act Section 66.b.  Thus, only PCR testing was done by CFIA on two carcasses. It is commonly believed that PCR testing is limited and contradictory. PCR is not the gold standard testing method and is not recommended as a diagnostic tool. \n\n**Exemption and Rejection:** A “rare genetics” exemption was promised by a CFIA officer in writing on January 2, 2025 but was rejected 8 days later, on January 10, In a CFIA “Distinct Unit Package” exemption request form. The farm was told if any answers were NO that they would immediately get denied an exemption. BUT, the form was intended for commercial poultry thus nothing on the form was relevant for a non-commercial Ostrich farm. \n\n### **Legal Actions and Court Outcomes**  \n\n**Injunction:** On January 31, 2025 Universal Ostrich farm won an injunction to pause a February 1 cull order, compelling CFIA to justify its decision via Judicial Review based limited to only data known from December 31, 2024, to January 10, 2025.\n\n**Judicial Review:** On April 15–16, 2025, a Federal Court in Vancouver reviewed all evidence pertaining to the Notice to Dispose Order issued on December 31st, 2024 and the Exemption Denial dated January 10th, 2025. The Judgement and Reasons were posted on May 13, 2025, exactly 27 days after the hearing ended. Under administrative law, Justice Zinn’s hands were tied.\n\nAs Judge Zinn quoted in his decision in Paragraph 3:  \n“This is not an appeal. The Court is not stepping into the shoes of the Agency and making the decisions that the Court feels ought to have been made. Instead, the focus of the review is on the Agency’s reasoning and process.” \n\nContinuing to Paragraph 5:    \n“Courts must respect Parliament’s choice to assign decision-making power to administrative bodies. This respect comes from the principle of separation of powers a cornerstone of Canadian public law”  \n\n The Judge couldn’t consider anything after January 10th , including the fact that Universal Ostrich Farm has had no illness or deaths since January 14, 2025.  \n\n As the Judge revealed, it was not within his power to determine what was right or wrong. The court’s rule was limited to whether the CFIA exercised their policies and acted within reasonable fairness. It is the CFIA’s policies that need to be challenged and changed, and that cannot be done in a judicial review.  A separate action needs to be filed for this. \n\n**RDCK Statement:** On May 15, 2025, supported by intense public pressure, the Regional District of Central Kootenay (RDCK) voted unanimously that CFIA test all healthy ostriches before considering the 400 healthy carcasses weighing ~140,000 pounds, proposed for disposal at the RDCK Ootischenia Landfill near Castlegar, BC.  \n\n**Current Status:** Judge Zinn upheld CFIA’s narrow arguments allowing a potential cull of 400 ostriches despite their perfect health status with no illness or deaths for four months.  \n\n### **Compensation and Fines**  \n\n**Compensation Uncertainty:** CFIA lists up to $3,000 per poultry bird online as per a January 27, 2025, news release, but no ostrich-specific value is defined. No compensation communication has been received as of May 20, 2025, and $3,000 per bird is far below their true value. The ongoing market value of an ostrich rooster is $7500 CDN each. The value of an antibody-producing hen is $93,000 CDN each. Compensation can be voided by CFIA as per below. Worth noting, are you are aware, that us all, as taxpayers pay for all CFIA actions, wages and costs.  This includes all culling processes, compensation to farmers, court, travel, etc. \n\n **Fines:** Two unjustified $10,000 fines threaten to eliminate any compensation. Both fines were challenged and documents filed to CFIA. We are working to have these overturned. CFIA told a reporter that compensation is only when farms are compliant – taking them to court is far from compliant. \n\n### **Commitment to Transparency** \n\nUniversal Ostrich Farms Inc. remains dedicated to ethical farming, rigorous science, and public safety. Our antibody research has shown immense potential, yet we face significant challenges from regulatory overreach and misinformation. We call for fair, science-based assessments and urge citizens to hold authorities accountable with the same scrutiny. For further inquiries, contact Universal Ostrich Farms Inc. or SaveOurOstriches.com directly.  \n\n  **Signed**,    \nKaren Espersen & Dave Bilinski    \nUniversal Ostrich Farms Inc.","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

rel=\"alternate\"; title=\"JSON\"; type=\"application/json\", <https://saveourostriches.com/?p=11511>; rel=shortlink","etag":"\"6903-1747985226;br\"","x-litespeed-cache":"hit","content-encoding":"br","vary":"Accept-Encoding","content-length":"26903","date":"Tue, 27 May 2025 06:35:16 GMT","server":"LiteSpeed","platform":"hostinger","panel":"hpanel","content-security-policy":"upgrade-insecure-requests","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"CFIA says B.C. ostrich cull will go ahead despite regional district refusing to accept the carcasses, CBC News\nFederal agency says dates for cull will not be shared with public in advance\nCBC News | May 18, 2025\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) says it is going ahead with a cull of nearly 400 ostriches living in southeastern B.C. over fears of avian flu.\nIt doubled down on its decision on Saturday, despite the local regional district passing a motion earlier this week saying it will not accept the birds’ carcasses at local landfills after they are killed until the CFIA conducts more tests on the birds and makes those results public.\nThe federal agency told CBC News it’s aware of the motion.\n“The CFIA will begin the humane depopulation and disposal of birds at the infected premises with veterinary oversight. Operational plans and dates will not be shared with the public in advance,” the CFIA said in a statement.\n“We have a duty to protect Canadians from the serious potential risks that avian influenza presents to our people and our economy.”\nCommunity rallies for birds\nThe owners of Universal Ostrich Farm had been fighting the cull order in court but a federal judge recently ruled that the CFIA can proceed.\nKatie Pasitney, spokesperson for the farm owned by her parents, said she’s disappointed with the CFIA’s decision and wants the agency to retest the birds.\n“We can prove to you we pose no public health and safety risk,” she said in an interview Sunday.\n“There’s a family sitting here trying to do the right thing. We put our feet on the ground every morning. We pray, we open our hearts that there’s hope that the Canadian Food Inspection Agency would revisit their [decision].”\nUniversal Ostrich co-owner Karen Espersen posted a plea on Facebook for supporters to come ‘surround’ her farm in an effort to stop her birds from being culled. (Facebook/Karen Espersen)\nThe order to have the birds killed has attracted the attention of hundreds of supporters, who have made monetary donations to the farm’s legal fund and held rallies in favour of saving the ostriches.\nThe owners of Universal Ostrich, in Edgewood in southeastern B.C., argue the birds that have survived the outbreak are happy and healthy and could provide valuable insight into fighting the disease.\nThe farm said a total of 69 ostriches are reported to have been killed by avian flu but it said the last death came in January and in the time since none of the remaining birds have been exhibiting symptoms of disease.\nB.C ostrich farm ‘devastated’ after federal judge rules cull of nearly 400 birds can proceed\nB.C. premier ‘frustrated’ CFIA isn’t showing ‘flexibility’ on ostrich cull, landfill refuses to take carcasses\nA number of supporters have gathered at the farm in anticipation of a standoff with the CFIA. Videos and photos posted on social media show dozens of people, tents, caravans and vehicles on the property, with flags and banners draped on fences. \nOne of the protesters, Jim Kerr, said more than 200 people showed up on Saturday to oppose the cull, and the plan at this moment is to stay “peaceful, loving, and lawful.” \nBut Kerr said that doesn’t mean they will make it easy for the authorities if they come by, saying the group intends to “slow them down” or catch them doing anything that would be “deemed to be against the law.”\nOpponents of the cull have been shooting videos and livestreaming from the farm over the weekend, with one person saying on a video that they will take on a “much more serious long-term activism role.”\nA poster advertises a convoy to Universal Ostrich to protest the ordered cull. (Facebook/B.C. Rising)\nThe farmers’ cause has also been mentioned by U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who told a New York radio show last month he was “horrified by the idea that they are going to kill these animals.”\nThe CFIA said in a weekend statement that under the Health of Animals Act, if an owner refuses to meet the depopulation requirements outlined by the CFIA, the agency could move forward with depopulation itself or use a third-party contractor. \nThe authority says this could mean withholding part or all compensation for the depopulation from the owners. \nThe court decision says the farm could be compensated up to a maximum of $3,000 per ostrich.\nPremier ‘frustrated’ with CFIA\nB.C. Premier David Eby also weighed in on the matter on Wednesday, saying he was “frustrated” that the CFIA won’t make decisions on a case-by-case basis.\nMore than 8.7 million birds have been culled in B.C. at hundreds of farms, most of them commercial, since the first outbreak of a highly contagious form of the avian flu in the spring of 2022. \nThe cull at Universal Ostrich was first ordered on Dec. 31, 2024, after avian flu was detected in several birds at the farm.\nBut the farm managed to stave off that cull through a court injunction that allowed both sides to make their case before a federal judge in April.\nThough Federal Court Justice Russel Zinn wrote that e has “considerable sympathy” for the farmers, he also found that the CFIA ordered the cull after following proper procedure and its mandate to attempt to stop the spread of the deadly bird virus.\nWith files from CBC’s Brady Strachan, Andrew Kurjata and The Canadian Press\nShare This Story\nFacebook","markdown":"# CFIA says B.C. ostrich cull will go ahead despite regional district refusing to accept the carcasses, CBC News\n\n_Federal agency says dates for cull will not be shared with public in advance_\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/image-4.png)\n\n**[CBC News](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/cfia-says-ostrich-cull-will-go-ahead-1.7538341)** | May 18, 2025\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) says it is going ahead with a cull of nearly 400 ostriches living in southeastern B.C. over fears of avian flu.\n\nIt doubled down on its decision on Saturday, despite the local regional district passing a motion earlier this week saying it will not accept the birds’ carcasses at local landfills after they are killed until the CFIA conducts more tests on the birds and makes those results public.\n\nThe federal agency told CBC News it’s aware of the motion.\n\n“The CFIA will begin the humane depopulation and disposal of birds at the infected premises with veterinary oversight. Operational plans and dates will not be shared with the public in advance,” the CFIA said in a statement.\n\n“We have a duty to protect Canadians from the serious potential risks that avian influenza presents to our people and our economy.”\n\n## Community rallies for birds\n\nThe owners of Universal Ostrich Farm had been fighting the cull order in court but a federal judge recently ruled that the CFIA can proceed.\n\nKatie Pasitney, spokesperson for the farm owned by her parents, said she’s disappointed with the CFIA’s decision and wants the agency to retest the birds.\n\n“We can prove to you we pose no public health and safety risk,” she said in an interview Sunday.\n\n“There’s a family sitting here trying to do the right thing. We put our feet on the ground every morning. We pray, we open our hearts that there’s hope that the Canadian Food Inspection Agency would revisit their \\[decision\\].”\n\n![A woman with an ostrich.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7535390.1747265929!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/espersen.jpg?im=)\n\nUniversal Ostrich co-owner Karen Espersen posted a plea on Facebook for supporters to come ‘surround’ her farm in an effort to stop her birds from being culled. (Facebook/Karen Espersen)\n\nThe order to have the birds killed has attracted the attention of hundreds of supporters, who have made monetary donations to the farm’s legal fund and held rallies in favour of saving the ostriches.\n\nThe owners of Universal Ostrich, in Edgewood in southeastern B.C., argue the birds that have survived the outbreak are happy and healthy and could provide valuable insight into fighting the disease.\n\nThe farm said a total of 69 ostriches are reported to have been killed by avian flu but it said the last death came in January and in the time since none of the remaining birds have been exhibiting symptoms of disease.\n\n*   [B.C ostrich farm ‘devastated’ after federal judge rules cull of nearly 400 birds can proceed](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/ostriches-killed-avian-flu-1.7534114)\n*   [B.C. premier ‘frustrated’ CFIA isn’t showing ‘flexibility’ on ostrich cull, landfill refuses to take carcasses](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/ostrich-eby-conservatives-1.7536359)\n\nA number of supporters have gathered at the farm in anticipation of a standoff with the CFIA. Videos and photos posted on social media show dozens of people, tents, caravans and vehicles on the property, with flags and banners draped on fences.  \n\nOne of the protesters, Jim Kerr, said more than 200 people showed up on Saturday to oppose the cull, and the plan at this moment is to stay “peaceful, loving, and lawful.” \n\nBut Kerr said that doesn’t mean they will make it easy for the authorities if they come by, saying the group intends to “slow them down” or catch them doing anything that would be “deemed to be against the law.”\n\nOpponents of the cull have been shooting videos and livestreaming from the farm over the weekend, with one person saying on a video that they will take on a “much more serious long-term activism role.”\n\n![A poster showing pictures of ostriches that reads 'Save Our Ostriches.'](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7446799.1744663577!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/save-our-ostriches-convoy.jpg?im=)\n\nA poster advertises a convoy to Universal Ostrich to protest the ordered cull. (Facebook/B.C. Rising)\n\nThe farmers’ cause has also been mentioned by U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who told a New York radio show last month he was “horrified by the idea that they are going to kill these animals.”\n\nThe CFIA said in a weekend statement that under the Health of Animals Act, if an owner refuses to meet the depopulation requirements outlined by the CFIA, the agency could move forward with depopulation itself or use a third-party contractor. \n\nThe authority says this could mean withholding part or all compensation for the depopulation from the owners. \n\nThe court decision says the farm could be compensated up to a maximum of $3,000 per ostrich.\n\n## Premier ‘frustrated’ with CFIA\n\nB.C. Premier David Eby also weighed in on the matter on Wednesday, saying he was [“frustrated”](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/ostrich-eby-conservatives-1.7536359) that the CFIA won’t make decisions on a case-by-case basis.\n\nMore than 8.7 million birds have been culled in B.C. at hundreds of farms, most of them commercial, since the first outbreak of a highly contagious form of the avian flu in the spring of 2022. \n\nThe cull at Universal Ostrich was first ordered on Dec. 31, 2024, after avian flu was detected in several birds at the farm.\n\nBut the farm managed to stave off that cull through a court injunction that allowed both sides to make their case before a federal judge in April.\n\nThough Federal Court Justice Russel Zinn wrote that e has “considerable sympathy” for the farmers, he also found that the CFIA ordered the cull after following proper procedure and its mandate to attempt to stop the spread of the deadly bird virus.\n\n_With files from CBC’s Brady Strachan, Andrew Kurjata and The Canadian Press_\n\n## Share This Story\n\nFacebook\n\n[![app-facebook](https://static.xx.fbcdn.net/rsrc.php/v4/ym/r/-RBTFFfbsYr.png)](https://saveourostriches.com/SaveOurOstriches/posts/122130306908772897?ref=embed_post)\n\n[![](https://scontent-lga3-3.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t39.30808-6/499930065_122130306836772897_7831350143480738275_n.jpg?stp=dst-jpg_p526x296_tt6&_nc_cat=104&ccb=1-7&_nc_sid=e5c1b6&_nc_ohc=4zTt01hAVF0Q7kNvwGNLFiQ&_nc_oc=AdlvzRvY13CZTPXygnUBHlFdphveSVHzQOmxP2y8JDvUPa7st9yLPFMfBcFAl1eq_dg&_nc_zt=23&_nc_ht=scontent-lga3-3.xx&edm=AN6CN6oEAAAA&_nc_gid=rXxB7JW6bi1r73wzDal-NQ&oh=00_AfKfRBLqe9u1sr9cQhw8EsFftqkWoX8E_Twye5u9PeiuRA&oe=683B28B8)](https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=122130306830772897&set=a.122094163616772897&type=3&ref=embed_post)","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

rel=\"alternate\"; title=\"JSON\"; type=\"application/json\", <https://saveourostriches.com/?p=11263>; rel=shortlink","etag":"\"6920-1747988532;br\"","x-litespeed-cache":"hit","content-encoding":"br","vary":"Accept-Encoding","content-length":"24048","date":"Tue, 27 May 2025 06:35:17 GMT","server":"LiteSpeed","platform":"hostinger","panel":"hpanel","content-security-policy":"upgrade-insecure-requests","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"RDCK votes to refuse ostrich carcasses at landfills until testing updated, Nelson Star\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency has ordered that the birds be killed.\nNelson Star | May 15, 2025\nThe Regional District of Central Kootenay board voted on May 15 to not accept ostrich carcasses from a farm in Edgewood at any of its landfill sites until the birds are re-tested for the avian flu.\nThe motion requires the RDCK to reject the carcasses “until the number of birds confirmed infected with highly pathenogenic avian influenza and the number classified as exposed, based on testing performed after May 15, 2025, is confirmed from the Canadian Food Inspection Agency and/or Ministry of Agriculture and Food.”\nThe motion goes to request that “the CFIA provide this information directly to the public, in a timely and transparent manner, to support public understanding and trust.”\nThe CFIA recently ordered that nearly 400 ostriches on the Universal Ostrich farm must be killed, based on testing done on the birds for avian influenza in December.\nThe farm’s owner, Katie Pasitney, in an emotional appeal to the RDCK board, explained that her birds are now healthy and that new testing needs to be done.\nMany members of the public attended the meeting asking the board to put an end to the cull. RDCK vice-chair Aidan McLaren-Caux, who presided at the meeting, told them that the RDCK has no power to do that because the CFIA is an agency of the federal government.\nBut the RDCK is responsible for waste and has jurisdiction over the local landfill, he said.","markdown":"# RDCK votes to refuse ostrich carcasses at landfills until testing updated, Nelson Star\n\n_The Canadian Food Inspection Agency has ordered that the birds be killed_.\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/image-3.png)\n\n[**Nelson Star**](https://www.nelsonstar.com/local-news/rdck-votes-to-refuse-ostrich-carcasses-at-landfills-until-testing-updated-8011709) | May 15, 2025\n\nThe Regional District of Central Kootenay board voted on May 15 to not accept ostrich carcasses from a farm in Edgewood at any of its landfill sites until the birds are re-tested for the avian flu.\n\nThe motion requires the RDCK to reject the carcasses “until the number of birds confirmed infected with highly pathenogenic avian influenza and the number classified as exposed, based on testing performed after May 15, 2025, is confirmed from the Canadian Food Inspection Agency and/or Ministry of Agriculture and Food.”\n\nThe motion goes to request that “the CFIA provide this information directly to the public, in a timely and transparent manner, to support public understanding and trust.”\n\nThe CFIA [recently ordered](https://www.vernonmorningstar.com/local-news/mp-community-fighting-to-save-lives-of-400-edgewood-ostriches-8010227?utm_source=nelson%20star&utm_campaign=nelson%20star%3A%20outbound&utm_medium=referral) that nearly 400 ostriches on the Universal Ostrich farm must be killed, based on testing done on the birds for avian influenza in December.\n\nThe farm’s owner, Katie Pasitney, in an emotional appeal to the RDCK board, explained that her birds are now healthy and that new testing needs to be done.\n\nMany members of the public attended the meeting asking the board to put an end to the cull. RDCK vice-chair Aidan McLaren-Caux, who presided at the meeting, told them that the RDCK has no power to do that because the CFIA is an agency of the federal government.\n\nBut the RDCK is responsible for waste and has jurisdiction over the local landfill, he said.","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

rel=\"alternate\"; title=\"JSON\"; type=\"application/json\", <https://saveourostriches.com/?p=11246>; rel=shortlink","etag":"\"6901-1747985226;br\"","x-litespeed-cache":"hit","content-encoding":"br","vary":"Accept-Encoding","content-length":"26818","date":"Tue, 27 May 2025 06:35:17 GMT","server":"LiteSpeed","platform":"hostinger","panel":"hpanel","content-security-policy":"upgrade-insecure-requests","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"Supporters converge on B.C. ostrich farm as federal food agency confirms cull of flock, National Post\nA Federal Court ruling has rejected the farm’s bid to prevent the killings, which were ordered after an outbreak of avian flu\nNational Post | May 14, 2025 \nOperators of a British Columbia ostrich farm where 400 birds have been ordered culled said Wednesday that dozens of supporters have converged on the scene, as the federal agency in charge of the operation confirmed it would begin the “humane depopulation” of the animals.\nHowever, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency said it would not publicize operational plans or dates of the cull at Universal Ostrich Farms in Edgewood, B.C.\nWednesday’s statement came a day after a Federal Court ruling that rejected the farm’s bid to prevent the killings, which were ordered after an outbreak of avian flu.\n“The CFIA will begin the humane depopulation and disposal of birds at the infected premises with veterinary oversight,” the agency said.\nThe Regional District of Central Kootenay said it had already received provincial permission for its landfill in Castlegar, B.C., to handle the carcasses.\nKatie Pasitney, whose parents own the farm, said in an interview that the family will fight to save the ostriches through legal means, even as her mother called on supporters to surround the farm to prevent the cull.\nPasitney said Wednesday that about 40 supporters had arrived.\n“Banners, camping, their cars. We have some children staying here and a family … Everybody’s just coming here to take the opportunity to see these prehistoric, beautiful, healthy animals with the bad decision of a cull order being reinstated and (the birds) being at jeopardy of losing their healthy lives.”\nPasitney said they had received supportive calls and emails from across Canada and the United States, where the case has drawn attention.\nU.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. told a New York radio show last month he was “horrified by the idea that they are going to kill these animals.”\n“The reaction to the support has been completely overwhelming in a positive way,” Pasitney said.\nTwitter Embed\nIMPORTANT- I JUST GOT WORD OF THE JUDGES RULING AGAINST UNIVERSAL OSTRICH FARM!!!! MAD AND SAD My heart goes out to you, Katie Pasitney, and your family. I'm not sure when the CFIA intends to do the cull, but it is devastating to possibly see another farm wiped out by outdated Show more\nThe media could not be played.\nIn a video message posted on Facebook, Pasitney’s mother, Karen Espersen, urged supporters to block the cull.\n“We need people to come and surround our farm so CFIA cannot come kill these beautiful healthy animals,” she wrote alongside the video.\n“You never thought you’d have this happen,” she said in the video while walking through her flock, with ostriches pecking at her sweater as she spoke.\n“If we ever needed anybody’s help, it’s today. You see all these guys behind me? These beautiful, majestic birds, these are our pets. This is what the (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) says that they’re going to come — they’ve been approved … to come kill them.\n“We’ve taken years to be able to pet these guys, walk among these guys. We love these guys. They’re all happy and healthy. If we don’t stand for this … then what kind of world have we become?”\nA Federal Court judge on Tuesday rejected two judicial reviews filed by Universal Ostrich Farms after the agency ordered the flock killed in December, then denied a bid for an exemption in January.\nThe family said the animals that survived the outbreak have recovered, having developed what Pasitney says is “herd immunity” to the virus, making the birds more valuable to researchers alive than dead.\n“We’re 135 kilometres away from a major city, Vernon, British Columbia,” Pasitney said of the contamination risk posed by the family farm.\n“We are not around any commercial poultry facilities. We are not a farm of consumption. So, how are we going to save the world by killing all of our animals, rather than using them as a potential benefit?”\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency on Wednesday defended its decision to proceed with the cull.\n“Allowing a domestic poultry flock known to be exposed to highly pathogenic avian influenza to remain alive allows a potential source of the virus to persist,” the statement said. “It would increase the possibility of reassortment or mutation, particularly with birds raised in open pasture where there is ongoing exposure to wildlife.\n“This could also increase the human health risk.”\nDan Elliott, a spokesman for the Regional District of Central Kootenay, said they received a landfill certificate to possibly handle the dead ostriches in January, adding the district has not received any information on when a possible cull would happen.\n“In response to the need to manage avian influenza disease, the Regional District of Central Kootenay has received an operational certificate from the provincial Ministry of Environment and Parks to handle the disposal of the avian influenza infected waste if the culling of the ostriches goes ahead,” Elliott says.\nB.C. Premier David Eby said Wednesday at an unrelated news conference that the province had been frustrated by the actions of the Canadian Food Inspection Agency, and while they understand the need to contain the avian flu, there’s a lack of ability to evaluate on a case-by-case basis.\n“I hope the federal government looks very carefully at appropriate compensation to ensure they’re made whole, not that that can fill in for the massive loss that they’ve seen,” Eby said.\nThe Federal Court ruling said the family could be compensated up to $3,000 for each bird.\nAn animal law advocacy group has urged the federal government to pause the cull and consider “whether killing the birds still makes sense considering how much time has passed since the initial order was issued.”\n“Avian flu is a devastating disease that must be taken seriously, but these ostriches shouldn’t be forced to pay for the failures of a broken system,” says Kaitlyn Mitchell, director of legal advocacy with Animal Justice. “Avian flu outbreaks are exacerbated by rampant factory farming, yet it’s the individual birds who pay the ultimate price.”","markdown":"# Supporters converge on B.C. ostrich farm as federal flu.\n\n“The CFIA will begin the humane depopulation and disposal of birds at the infected premises with veterinary oversight,” the agency said.\n\nThe Regional District of Central Kootenay said it had already received provincial permission for its landfill in Castlegar, B.C., to handle the carcasses.\n\nKatie Pasitney, whose parents own the farm, said in an interview that the family will fight to save the ostriches through legal means, even as her mother called on supporters to surround the farm to prevent the cull.\n\nPasitney said Wednesday that about 40 supporters had arrived.\n\n“Banners, camping, their cars. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency issued an order to KILL nearly 400 HEALTHY ostriches in December 2024, on the fear that they might be infected with the Avian Flu. That was December 2024. Remember that date.\n\nThe farm took the “order to kill” to court and got an injunction preventing the implementation of the order to kill pending judicial review. A judicial review of the CFIA’s order was conducted and the day-before-yesterday, a Federal Court judge ratified the CFIA’s order to kill because it was “reasonable” and “based on the evidence available at the time” (paraphrasing slightly).\n\nNONE of the birds are currently sick. NONE have been sick FOR MONTHS. There is NO URGENCY. There is NO BASIS for the kill. ostrich carcass disposal and avoid ‘environmental risk’, Castanet News\nA community group is urging the regional district to refuse to accept at the Ootischenia Landfill (above) the nearly 400 ostriches that could be killed in the cull from Edgewood’s Universal Ostrich Farms.\nCastanet | May 14, 2025 \nAn environmental catastrophe is brewing if the regional district accepts disposal of the 400 soon-to-be-culled ostrich carcasses, a local community group says.\nThe Regional District of Central Kootenay (RDCK) said it had received an operational certificate from the provincial Environment Ministry for its landfill in Castlegar to handle the disposal of “avian influenza-infected waste,” if the culling of nearly 400 ostriches from Universal Ostrich Farms near Edgewood occurs.\nHowever, the group identifying themselves as the Kootenay Tribe are asking the RDCK to reject the Canadian Food Inspection Agency’s (CFIA) plan to dispose of the ostriches in the Ootischenia Landfill, following the CFIA’s clearance Tuesday to cull birds from the Edgewood farm.\nThe ostrich disposal risks environmental catastrophe, echoing the HB Mines landfill contamination that cost RDCK taxpayers millions of dollars, a statement from the Kootenay Tribe claimed.\n“The HB Mines debacle showed us the devastating cost of ignoring environmental risks and RDCK bad decision making,” the statement read.\n“Taxpayers have been paying millions of dollars in environmental fees for HB Mines; fees that residents were not involved in the decision to purchase, but have been paying the costs ever since for that environmental disaster.”\nThe carcasses would be classified as hazardous waste if disposed of, and there is no prior environmental impact assessment, the Tribe contended.\n“Risks include groundwater contamination from inadequate leachate management and hazardous gas emissions (methane, ammonia), as the landfill may lack capacity to handle such waste,” it read.\nAccording to The Canadian Press, RDCK communications coordinator Dan Elliott said they received the landfill certificate to possibly handle the dead ostriches in January, adding the district has not received any information on when a possible cull would happen.\n“In response to the need to manage avian influenza disease, the Regional District of Central Kootenay has received an operational certificate from the provincial Ministry of Environment and Parks to handle the disposal of the avian influenza infected waste if the culling of the ostriches goes ahead,” Elliott said.","markdown":"# RDCK urged to reject ostrich carcass disposal and avoid ‘environmental risk’, Castanet News\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/image-1.png)\n\nA community group is urging the regional district to refuse to accept at the Ootischenia Landfill (above) the nearly 400 ostriches that could be killed in the cull from Edgewood’s Universal Ostrich Farms.\n\n[**Castanet**](https://www.castanet.net/news/Castlegar/550479/RDCK-urged-to-reject-ostrich-carcass-disposal-and-avoid-environmental-risk-) | May 14, 2025\n\nAn environmental catastrophe is brewing if the regional district accepts disposal of the 400 soon-to-be-culled ostrich carcasses, a local community group says.\n\nThe Regional District of Central Kootenay (RDCK) said it had received an operational certificate from the provincial Environment Ministry for its landfill in Castlegar to handle the disposal of “avian influenza-infected waste,” if [the culling of nearly 400 ostriches](https://www.castanet.net/news/Nelson/550457/Court-ruling-upholding-order-to-kill-ostriches-prompts-plea-for-action-by-owners-to-surround-farm#550457) from Universal Ostrich Farms near Edgewood occurs.\n\nHowever, the group identifying themselves as the Kootenay Tribe are asking the RDCK to reject the Canadian Food Inspection Agency’s (CFIA) plan to dispose of the ostriches in the Ootischenia Landfill, following the CFIA’s clearance Tuesday to cull birds from the Edgewood farm.\n\nThe ostrich disposal risks environmental catastrophe, echoing the HB Mines landfill contamination that cost RDCK taxpayers millions of dollars, a statement from the Kootenay Tribe claimed.\n\n“The HB Mines debacle showed us the devastating cost of ignoring environmental risks and RDCK bad decision making,” the statement read.\n\n“Taxpayers have been paying millions of dollars in environmental fees for HB Mines; fees that residents were not involved in the decision to purchase, but have been paying the costs ever since for that environmental disaster.”\n\nThe carcasses would be classified as hazardous waste if disposed of, and there is no prior environmental impact assessment, the Tribe contended.\n\n“Risks include groundwater contamination from inadequate leachate management and hazardous gas emissions (methane, ammonia), as the landfill may lack capacity to handle such waste,” it read.\n\nAccording to _The Canadian Press_, RDCK communications coordinator Dan Elliott said they received the landfill certificate to possibly handle the dead ostriches in January, adding the district has not received any information on when a possible cull would happen.\n\n“In response to the need to manage avian influenza disease, the Regional District of Central Kootenay has received an operational certificate from the provincial Ministry of Environment and Parks to handle the disposal of the avian influenza infected waste if the culling of the ostriches goes ahead,” Elliott said.","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

GMT","server":"LiteSpeed","platform":"hostinger","panel":"hpanel","content-security-policy":"upgrade-insecure-requests","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"Protesters gather at B.C. farm as ostriches set to be killed over bird flu fears, CBC News\nCBC News | May 14, 2025 \nUniversal Ostrich lost court case seeking to overturn order from Canadian Food Inspection Agency\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) says the cull of a flock of ostriches in southwest B.C. will move forward in order to fight the threat of avian flu, but it won’t be providing details of the operation in advance.\nThe notice comes as supporters of the farm are gathering in Edgewood, B.C., to try to stop it.\nThe CFIA says it is moving ahead with the cull following a court ruling issued May 13 that found the agency had followed the proper procedures for making the decision to order the procedure, and that it has a broad mandate to make the decisions on behalf of the Canadian government.\nThough the judge in the case said he sympathized with the farm for the economic and emotional toll the loss of its birds would have, he also wrote in his decision that must be balanced against the greater public good associated with the CFIA’s mandate of working to stop the spread and mutation of the deadly bird disease.\nIn a response to the ruling, the CFIA confirmed in a written statement that it will move ahead with the “humane depopulation and disposal of birds at the infected premises with veterinary oversight.”\nThe statement said, “Operational plans and dates will not be shared with the public in advance.”\nOwner urges supporters to ‘surround’ farm\nMeanwhile, supporters of Universal Ostrich have begun gathering around the property to show their solidarity with the owners in the hopes of stopping the cull from moving forward.\nThe case has attracted significant attention from groups saying they believe the cull order is government overreach and has even received the attention of U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, who was asked about it during an interview on a New York radio show last month and told the host he was “horrified by the idea that they are going to kill these animals.”\nKatie Pasitney, whose mother is co-owner of the farm, has called for a peaceful protest and said they are looking for legal measures that can be taken to try to stop the decision from being carried out.\nIn a video message posted on Facebook, Pasitney’s mother, Karen Espersen, urged supporters to “come surround the farm” and “don’t let them do this to these beautiful animals.”\nA herd of ostriches is seen on a remote farm in Edgewood, B.C., in an undated photo supplied by Universal Ostrich Farms Inc. (Katie Pasitney/Canadian Press)\n“We’ve taken years to be able to pet these guys, walk among these guys,” she said, walking through the herd. “We love these guys. They’re all happy and healthy. If we don’t stand for this … then what kind of world have we become?”\nThe family says the animals that survived the outbreak have recovered and are happy and healthy, having developed what Pasitney claims is “herd immunity” to the virus, which makes the birds more valuable to researchers alive than dead.\nB.C ostrich farm ‘devastated’ after federal judge rules cull of nearly 400 birds can proceed\n3 MLAs are supporting a B.C. farming family whose 400 ostriches are to be culled\nShe has argued that the birds who remain should be retested to see if they still have the disease and, if not, should be allowed to live and be studied.\n“Let’s take their blood. Let’s do an analysis. Let’s do a control study,” she said in an interview with CBC News.\n“As long as we have migratory birds, we will have avian influenza, so eradicating all of our livestock and hurting our farmers… is not the solution.”\nOn Wednesday, she said about 40 supporters had already arrived, with the possibility of more to come.\nAnimal rights group weighs in\nThe farm is also supporting a letter-writing campaign targeted at the Regional District of Central Kootenay, urging it not to accept dead ostriches at local landfills.\nRegional District of Central Kootenay spokesman Dan Elliott says it received the landfill certificate to possibly handle the dead ostriches in January, adding the district has not received any information on when a possible cull would happen.\nA poster advertises a convoy to Universal Ostrich to protest the ordered cull in February 2025. (Facebook/B.C. Rising)\n“In response to the need to manage avian influenza disease, the Regional District of Central Kootenay has received an operational certificate from the provincial Ministry of Environment and Parks to handle the disposal of the avian influenza-infected waste if the culling of the ostriches goes ahead,” Elliott says.\nMeanwhile, an animal law group has urged the federal government to pause the cull and consider “whether killing the birds still makes sense considering how much time has passed since the initial order was issued.”\n“Avian flu is a devastating disease that must be taken seriously, but these ostriches shouldn’t be forced to pay for the failures of a broken system,” says Animal Justice director of legal advocacy Kaitlyn Mitchell. “Avian flu outbreaks are exacerbated by rampant factory farming, yet it’s the individual birds who pay the ultimate price.”\nAgency says cull needed to protect Canadian poultry industry\nThe CFIA, though, says its policy of killing all animals in domestic flocks where avian flu has been detected is necessary in order to contain the disease, which has the potential to mutate and spread to other animals and even humans, as when a teenager in B.C. was hospitalized for several weeks after being infected.\nB.C. ostrich farm gets stay of execution for birds ordered killed due to avian flu fears\nThis ostrich farm survived wildfires. Now, avian flu means 400 birds need to be culled\n“Allowing a domestic poultry flock known to be exposed to HPAI to remain alive allows a potential source of the virus to persist. It would increase the possibility of reassortment or mutation, particularly with birds raised in open pasture where there is ongoing exposure to wildlife. This could also increase the human health risk,” the statement says.\n“Our disease response aims to protect both public and animal health, as well as minimize impacts on the $6.8 billion domestic poultry industry, and the Canadian economy.”\nIn the court ruling, it was noted that Universal Ostrich is entitled to up to $3,000 per animal killed.\nJudge not convinced by farm’s arguments\nThe ruling also notes that it is not up to the courts to weigh in on the scientific evidence for and against the cull, with Justice Russell Zinn writing, “courts generally stay out of scientific debates,” and instead it is the place of “technical bodies,” such as the CFIA to “make judgments on complex, expertise-driven matters.”\nIn the ruling, which is by his own admission, “lengthy” at more than 100 pages, Zinn goes into detail about the decision-making around the cull and the arguments against it made by Universal Ostrich.\nThe ruling also lays out the steps that had been taken in ordering the cull, starting with an inspection of Universal Ostrich after the CFIA received an anonymous tip that dead ostriches had been seen at the farm in December 2024. It was later confirmed that between 25 and 30 ostriches had died in December, a number that would rise to 69 by mid-January. \nCFIA inspectors visited the farm in late December and collected samples from two dead birds that were later confirmed to have avian flu. At the same time, the ruling states, the inspectors took note of the fact that wild birds, including ducks, were interspersed with the ostriches at both an outdoor farm and in the ostrich feeding area, which could result in the further transmission of diseases.\nSupporters of Universal Ostrich pose outside the farm in B.C.’s West Kootenay region. (Katie Pasitney/Facebook)\nAs a result of the positive test, the farm was given notice that its entire flock would have to be quarantined and later killed, following CFIA policy.\nAt the same time, Zinn found, the CFIA also provided the farm with information on how to apply for an exemption to the cull, which would involve proof that the birds were considered rare or unique enough to be spared. Methods of proving this included breeding books, recognition from a certified breed association or the poultry industry, or specific genomic testing. \nThough the farm did submit its case that it had business plans to research ostrich antibodies and its flock’s genetic lines, the CFIA did not find it met its standards for exemption, and that the cull would proceed as ordered.\nThe ruling went on to note that the CFIA’s decision-making is based on public health and economic decisions, including Canada’s ability to participate in international trade, which is why those impacted by cull orders are given financial compensation.\nDecision can’t be changed in hindsight: judge\nZinn also noted that so far, only one exemption has been granted, in a 2022 case of a turkey farm where avian flu had been detected in two barns but not others on the premises, because those animals had been kept separate and safety measures had been taken to prevent the possible spread of disease between the different structures — conditions that do not exist at Universal Ostrich where inspectors observed wild birds, weasels and “unauthorized individuals” walking among infected animals, in violation of quarantine policy.\nThe ruling also took issue with the farm’s argument that the CFIA lacks the expertise to make rulings on ostriches as its policies are designed for more common poultry such as chickens and turkey, noting that the agency has a long history of regulating ostriches and emus, as well.\nAnd it dismissed the argument that, because the ostriches that have survived may not be infected or contagious, the order to cull, given in December, should be overturned.\n“Judicial review must never be conducted with the benefit of hindsight,” Zinn wrote. “Although the infection had later abated with many ostriches surviving, that could not have been foreseen at the time. The Stamping-Out Policy guided the Agency to depopulate the entire exposed epidemiological unit without delay.”","markdown":"# Protesters gather at B.C. farm as ostriches set to be killed over bird flu fears, CBC News\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/image.png)\n\n[**CBC News**](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/universal-ostrich-protest-1.7535367) | May 14, 2025\n\nUniversal Ostrich lost court case seeking to overturn order from Canadian Food Inspection Agency\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) says the cull of a flock of ostriches in southwest B.C. will move forward in order to fight the threat of avian flu, but it won’t be providing details of the operation in advance.\n\nThe notice comes as supporters of the farm are gathering in Edgewood, B.C., to try to stop it.\n\nThe CFIA says it is moving ahead with the cull following a [court ruling issued May 13](https://decisions.fct-cf.gc.ca/fc-cf/decisions/en/item/528164/index.do) that found the agency had followed the proper procedures for making the decision to order the procedure, and that it has a broad mandate to make the decisions on behalf of the Canadian government.\n\nThough the judge in the case said he sympathized with the farm for the economic and emotional toll the loss of its birds would have, he also wrote in his decision that must be balanced against the greater public good associated with the CFIA’s mandate of working to stop the spread and mutation of the deadly bird disease.\n\nIn a response to the ruling, the CFIA confirmed in a [written statement](https://inspection.canada.ca/en/animal-health/terrestrial-animals/diseases/reportable/avian-influenza/latest-bird-flu-situation/investigations-and-orders/british-columbia-ostrich-farm/judicial-review) that it will move ahead with the “humane depopulation and disposal of birds at the infected premises with veterinary oversight.”\n\nThe statement said, “Operational plans and dates will not be shared with the public in advance.”\n\n## Owner urges supporters to ‘surround’ farm\n\nMeanwhile, supporters of Universal Ostrich have begun gathering around the property to show their solidarity with the owners in the hopes of stopping the cull from moving forward.\n\nThe case has attracted significant attention from groups saying they believe the cull order is government overreach and has even received the attention of U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, who was asked about it during an interview on a New York radio show last month and told the host he was “horrified by the idea that they are going to kill these animals.”\n\nKatie Pasitney, whose mother is co-owner of the farm, has called for a peaceful protest and said they are looking for legal measures that can be taken to try to stop the decision from being carried out.\n\nIn a video message posted on Facebook, Pasitney’s mother, Karen Espersen, urged supporters to “come surround the farm” and “don’t let them do this to these beautiful animals.”\n\n![Several ostriches are seen behind a fence. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7531194.1747265959!/cpImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/avian-flu-ostrich-20250508.jpg?im=)\n\nA herd of ostriches is seen on a remote farm in Edgewood, B.C., in an undated photo supplied by Universal Ostrich Farms Inc. (Katie Pasitney/Canadian Press)\n\n“We’ve taken years to be able to pet these guys, walk among these guys,” she said, walking through the herd. “We love these guys. They’re all happy and healthy. If we don’t stand for this … then what kind of world have we become?”\n\nThe family says the animals that survived the outbreak have recovered and are happy and healthy, having developed what Pasitney claims is “herd immunity” to the virus, which makes the birds more valuable to researchers alive than dead.\n\n*   [B.C ostrich farm ‘devastated’ after federal judge rules cull of nearly 400 birds can proceed](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/ostriches-killed-avian-flu-1.7534114)\n*   [3 MLAs are supporting a B.C. farming family whose 400 ostriches are to be culled](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/bc-mlas-ostrich-cull-1.7531162)\n\nShe has argued that the birds who remain should be retested to see if they still have the disease and, if not, should be allowed to live and be studied.\n\n“Let’s take their blood. Let’s do an analysis. Let’s do a control study,” she said in an interview with CBC News.\n\n“As long as we have migratory birds, we will have avian influenza, so eradicating all of our livestock and hurting our farmers… is not the solution.”\n\nOn Wednesday, she said about 40 supporters had already arrived, with the possibility of more to come.\n\n## Animal rights group weighs in\n\nThe farm is also supporting a letter-writing campaign targeted at the Regional District of Central Kootenay, urging it not to accept dead ostriches at local landfills.\n\nRegional District of Central Kootenay spokesman Dan Elliott says it received the landfill certificate to possibly handle the dead ostriches in January, adding the district has not received any information on when a possible cull would happen.\n\n![A poster showing pictures of ostriches that reads 'Save Our Ostriches.'](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7446799.1744663577!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/save-our-ostriches-convoy.jpg?im=)\n\nA poster advertises a convoy to Universal Ostrich to protest the ordered cull in February 2025. (Facebook/B.C. Rising)\n\n“In response to the need to manage avian influenza disease, the Regional District of Central Kootenay has received an operational certificate from the provincial Ministry of Environment and Parks to handle the disposal of the avian influenza-infected waste if the culling of the ostriches goes ahead,” Elliott says.\n\nMeanwhile, an animal law group has urged the federal government to pause the cull and consider “whether killing the birds still makes sense considering how much time has passed since the initial order was issued.”\n\n“Avian flu is a devastating disease that must be taken seriously, but these ostriches shouldn’t be forced to pay for the failures of a broken system,” says Animal Justice director of legal advocacy Kaitlyn Mitchell. “Avian flu outbreaks are exacerbated by rampant factory farming, yet it’s the individual birds who pay the ultimate price.”\n\n## Agency says cull needed to protect Canadian poultry industry\n\nThe CFIA, though, says its policy of killing all animals in domestic flocks where avian flu has been detected is necessary in order to contain the disease, which has the potential to mutate and spread to other animals and even humans, as when a teenager in B.C. was hospitalized for several weeks after being infected.\n\n*   [B.C. ostrich farm gets stay of execution for birds ordered killed due to avian flu fears](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/universal-ostrich-kill-cull-avian-flu-1.7446768)\n*   [This ostrich farm survived wildfires. Now, avian flu means 400 birds need to be culled](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/bc-ostrich-farm-edgewood-1.7429394)\n\n“Allowing a domestic poultry flock known to be exposed to HPAI to remain alive allows a potential source of the virus to persist. It would increase the possibility of reassortment or mutation, particularly with birds raised in open pasture where there is ongoing exposure to wildlife. This could also increase the human health risk,” the statement says.\n\n“Our disease response aims to protect both public and animal health, as well as minimize impacts on the $6.8 billion domestic poultry industry, and the Canadian economy.”\n\nIn the court ruling, it was noted that Universal Ostrich is entitled to up to $3,000 per animal killed.\n\n## Judge not convinced by farm’s arguments\n\nThe ruling also notes that it is not up to the courts to weigh in on the scientific evidence for and against the cull, with Justice Russell Zinn writing, “courts generally stay out of scientific debates,” and instead it is the place of “technical bodies,” such as the CFIA to “make judgments on complex, expertise-driven matters.”\n\nIn the ruling, which is by his own admission, “lengthy” at more than 100 pages, Zinn goes into detail about the decision-making around the cull and the arguments against it made by Universal Ostrich.\n\nThe ruling also lays out the steps that had been taken in ordering the cull, starting with an inspection of Universal Ostrich after the CFIA received an anonymous tip that dead ostriches had been seen at the farm in December 2024. It was later confirmed that between 25 and 30 ostriches had died in December, a number that would rise to 69 by mid-January. \n\nCFIA inspectors visited the farm in late December and collected samples from two dead birds that were later confirmed to have avian flu. At the same time, the ruling states, the inspectors took note of the fact that wild birds, including ducks, were interspersed with the ostriches at both an outdoor farm and in the ostrich feeding area, which could result in the further transmission of diseases.\n\n![A group of people with a sign that reads 'Save Our Ostriches.'](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7446804.1747178410!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/ostrich-rally.jpg?im=)\n\nSupporters of Universal Ostrich pose outside the farm in B.C.’s West Kootenay region. (Katie Pasitney/Facebook)\n\nAs a result of the positive test, the farm was given notice that its entire flock would have to be quarantined and later killed, following CFIA policy.\n\nAt the same time, Zinn found, the CFIA also provided the farm with information on how to apply for an exemption to the cull, which would involve proof that the birds were considered rare or unique enough to be spared. Methods of proving this included breeding books, recognition from a certified breed association or the poultry industry, or specific genomic testing. \n\nThough the farm did submit its case that it had business plans to research ostrich antibodies and its flock’s genetic lines, the CFIA did not find it met its standards for exemption, and that the cull would proceed as ordered.\n\nThe ruling went on to note that the CFIA’s decision-making is based on public health and economic decisions, including Canada’s ability to participate in international trade, which is why those impacted by cull orders are given financial compensation.\n\n## Decision can’t be changed in hindsight: judge\n\nZinn also noted that so far, only one exemption has been granted, in a 2022 case of a turkey farm where avian flu had been detected in two barns but not others on the premises, because those animals had been kept separate and safety measures had been taken to prevent the possible spread of disease between the different structures — conditions that do not exist at Universal Ostrich where inspectors observed wild birds, weasels and “unauthorized individuals” walking among infected animals, in violation of quarantine policy.\n\nThe ruling also took issue with the farm’s argument that the CFIA lacks the expertise to make rulings on ostriches as its policies are designed for more common poultry such as chickens and turkey, noting that the agency has a long history of regulating ostriches and emus, as well.\n\nAnd it dismissed the argument that, because the ostriches that have survived may not be infected or contagious, the order to cull, given in December, should be overturned.\n\n“Judicial review must never be conducted with the benefit of hindsight,” Zinn wrote. “Although the infection had later abated with many ostriches surviving, that could not have been foreseen at the time. The Stamping-Out Policy guided the Agency to depopulate the entire exposed epidemiological unit without delay.”","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}
