During the visit, he met the owners of the farm, Karen and Dave, and Katie, the owner’s daughter and the public face of the ostrich farm. He also met with Constable Britton, Detachment Commander of Nakusp, who was in Edgewood on an unrelated matter and stopped by to say hello.\nAnderson’s team is currently working on a plan to save the ostriches while satisfying the requirements set by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA). He will be formally requesting that the CFIA delay the cull while we explore the possibility of saving the ostriches for further immunology research.\nShare This Story\nFacebook \nThis Facebook post is no longer available. It may have been removed or the privacy settings of the post may have changed.","markdown":"# Scott Anderson, Conservative MP, Visits Universal Ostrich Farms\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/25-05-14-scott-anderson-1024x768.png)\n\nMay 14, 2025 – [**Scott Anderson, Conservative MP**](https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/bc-ostrich-farm-cull) (Vernon—Lake Country—Monashee), visited the ostrich farm following the federal court decision upholding CFIA’s order to cull the ostriches. During the visit, he met the owners of the farm, Karen and Dave, and Katie, the owner’s daughter and the public face of the ostrich farm. He also met with Constable Britton, Detachment Commander of Nakusp, who was in Edgewood on an unrelated matter and stopped by to say hello.\n\nAnderson’s team is currently working on a plan to save the ostriches while satisfying the requirements set by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA). He will be formally requesting that the CFIA delay the cull while we explore the possibility of saving the ostriches for further immunology research.\n\n## Share This Story\n\nFacebook\n\nThis Facebook post is no longer available. Canadian Food Inspection Agency\nDear friends and supporters,\nWe are absolutely devastated to share today’s Federal Court decision, issued on May 13, 2025. The court ruled in favour of the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), upholding their order to destroy our beloved ostriches and rejecting our plea to save them.\nThe court’s decision accepted the CFIA’s justification under the Health of Animals Act and their use of the Stamping-Out Policy, which mandates the destruction of animals to control disease outbreaks, regardless of their health status. The court confirmed the CFIA’s approach, prioritizing trade obligations over the welfare of our animals.\nIn addition, we’ve been ordered to pay $15,000 in CFIA’s legal costs. \nDownload the full decision: (2025 FC 878) Court Decision 2024-05-13\nWe are heartbroken by this outcome and uncertain about the future of our farm. As we navigate this incredibly difficult time, we ask for your patience and continued support. If you are able, please consider making a donation to help us manage the financial and emotional toll this has taken.\nThank you,\nUniversal Ostrich Farm\nSaveOurOstriches.com\nFor Media Inquiries:\nKatie Pasitney\nDaughter of co-owner, Karen Espersen\nUniversal Ostrich Farms Inc.\nsaveourostriches@gmail.com\nShare This Story\nTwitter Embed\nOfficial Announcement: Federal Court Decision in Universal Ostrich Farms Inc. v. The court ruled in favour of the Canadian Show more","markdown":"# Federal Court Decision in Universal Ostrich Farms Inc v. Canadian Food Inspection Agency\n\n[![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/2025FC878-screenshot-1-1024x768.png)](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/JR-T-294-25-and-T-432-25-Final.pdf)\n\nDear friends and supporters,\n\nWe are absolutely devastated to share today’s Federal Court decision, issued on May 13, 2025. The court ruled in favour of the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), upholding their order to destroy our beloved ostriches and rejecting our plea to save them.\n\nThe court’s decision accepted the CFIA’s justification under the Health of Animals Act and their use of the Stamping-Out Policy, which mandates the destruction of animals to control disease outbreaks, regardless of their health status. The court confirmed the CFIA’s approach, prioritizing trade obligations over the welfare of our animals.\n\nIn addition, we’ve been ordered to pay $15,000 in CFIA’s legal costs.\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/25-05-13-screenshot-judgement.png)\n\nDownload the full decision: [**(2025 FC 878) Court Decision 2024-05-13**](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/JR-T-294-25-and-T-432-25-Final.pdf)\n\nWe are heartbroken by this outcome and uncertain about the future of our farm. As we navigate this incredibly difficult time, we ask for your patience and continued support. If you are able, please consider making a donation to help us manage the financial and emotional toll this has taken.\n\nThank you,  \nUniversal Ostrich Farm  \n[SaveOurOstriches.com](https://l.facebook.com/l.php?u=http%3A%2F%2FSaveOurOstriches.com%2F%3Ffbclid%3DIwZXh0bgNhZW0CMTAAYnJpZBExUTZyRHZ0YWpOdmE0cHZRagEe2yuYzFCW9O8QhSV9v9D4fp2vHy84X9SfK2IdHBTKeb8lcav4ON_IUOBzaUU_aem_guB3PuJLbfFNSmr-CD2GHQ&h=AT1gtza-ncVQtvitoBlNEUKItAWTJutL2Zw8kW6P3zXOqt29Ue1idnfBEg0SUVxoHElFVvmgew9VyHJW4cOIodK5uB7-2yQBIPxHLN0y--HV_oSC8UTupPPEy4cgSyR0XYi7LCoR7GeDsnso5dOmF7C6fc_OvBYsx8qo&__tn__=-UK-R&c[0]=AT0TEUeUyM4TOW_T5F8C1T0yo0kuFGfX5Cl6qp-Ng8v1jrD_ytpfx2XKs2vJiLOvhR4R52MyvelIU9X1It_y95VeCbf42JoVd6AKabWrIiA5bmfDFgmbtkHaWTEzxl7VC8B2EjLmOZK4uj51QY01gF2nl64uMUgcW3Kn7piyg1BJvBRf9m-_aXfgQXUNKsl0MYzQmiThZz69-UNYwbiNOCaxLi-48fYi)\n\n**For Media Inquiries:**  \nKatie Pasitney  \nDaughter of co-owner, Karen Espersen  \nUniversal Ostrich Farms Inc.  \nsaveourostriches@gmail.com\n\n## Share This Story\n\nTwitter Embed\n\n[](https://twitter.com/OstrichFarmBC/status/1922396708035821669?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1922396708035821669%7Ctwgr%5Ea82ce13b3fb5375c1caa69eaee0e868caf217af4%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fsaveourostriches.com%2Fupdates-from-the-farm%2Ffederal-court-decision-universal-ostrich-farms-cfia%2F)\n\nOfficial Announcement: Federal Court Decision in Universal Ostrich Farms Inc. v. Uhh, the day came, you know, we never thought we’d have this happen.\nIf we ever needed anybody’s help, it’s today. See all these guys behind me? These beautiful majestic birds. Do you see this? These are our pets. This is what CFIA says that they’re going to come, they’ve been approved, one to four days, to come kill them. We’ve taken years to be able to pet these guys, walk amongst these guys. We love these guys. They’re all happy and healthy. \nIf we don’t stand for this, and we don’t pull together, and we don’t save all of these beautiful, happy, healthy animals, then what kind of world have we become? \nWe’re asking for an SOS and we need people to come to our farm today to stand up and do something. We can make the change. We just have to do it together. We can’t let them do this. Please come to the farm. 301 Langille Road. Come surround the farm. rel=\"alternate\"; title=\"JSON\"; type=\"application/json\", <https://saveourostriches.com/?p=11523>; rel=shortlink","etag":"\"6924-1747988541;br\"","x-litespeed-cache":"hit","content-encoding":"br","vary":"Accept-Encoding","content-length":"26208","date":"Tue, 27 May 2025 06:35:34 GMT","server":"LiteSpeed","platform":"hostinger","panel":"hpanel","content-security-policy":"upgrade-insecure-requests","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"RDCK Regional District of Central Kootenay Board Meeting - Saving the Ostriches\nRDCK Board Meeting - Saving the Ostriches May 15, 2025 - YouTube\nRDCK Observer, May 15, 2025 \nTranscript:\nChair, Aidan McLaren-Caux: There’s nothing that we can do beyond advocacy. Because it’s not, I don’t want to be the person to say it’s not our problem, but it’s outside of our power. I know that might not be the answer you want to hear. Personally, I wish there was something I could do, but we are stuck with what we have, and we have to work within the bounds of our, we are a legislative body, so we have to respect the law. We are a country of laws, it went through all the courts.\nKatie Pasitney: I do have a question (Katie, owner of the farm). We just made it here just in time. I woke up and I had meetings all morning. We just said, we’re going, because I knew I needed to stand in front of all of you, from our farm, today. I do have a question, Chair. Will you publicly retract the false claim that UOF (Universal Ostrich Farms) lost two court cases and correct the record at this board? Because the record matters, and moving forward with disposal based on misinformation, without a legal mandate, is not just reckless—it makes this board liable for voluntary participation.\nI urge you all to take a step back, verify the facts, and act in truth.\nSorry, it’s been a journey. I’m here today to correct a serious falsehood that was entered into the public record of this board. It was stated that Universal Ostrich Farm has lost two court cases. That is not true. Let me absolutely be clear: Universal Ostrich Farm has not lost any legal case. What we did do was file for and win a judicial review granted by Justice Batista. That review was heard on April 15th and 16th in Vancouver, and the decision was released this week by Federal Court by Justice Zinn.\nBut here’s the part that matters to you: In paragraphs 7 and 8 of that ruling, Justice Zinn states that the court can only rule on decisions made by the CFIA before January 10th, 2025. The court was legally barred from considering any evidence after that date. That means the current health of our animals, the current health of our 400 healthy animals, any new test results, any recovery or scientific data—none of it could be considered. This ruling does not validate CFIA’s current actions; only that what they did at that time was, in the court’s view, reasonable based on what they knew then.\nWith respect, I ask you to please consider the now. Because we are in a fight for these animals that hold way more value alive than they do dead, by accepting their dead carcasses into this landfill. You can set a precedent because we have a recovered flock. We can set a precedent with all of your power in all of your seats, and everything that we stand for here today and all the voices from across our country, and the global attention that this issue is getting, we can set a precedent.\nOur animals are healthy, they’re laying eggs, they’re beautiful, and we are being restricted the chance from retesting our animals to prove to you as the public, that they are recovered. We are being threatened six months in jail and a $250,000 fine to bring you that evidence.\nSo where do we stop this? We stop it at Universal Ostrich Farm.\nChair, Aidan McLaren-Caux: I believe I we have a director who has a motion. Directors, please check your email, so you have a copy of it, it should have been sent out a few minutes ago. Director Lunn, would you like to make your motion?\nDirector Jessica Lunn: Sure, I would like to move that the RDCK board direct staff to withhold acceptance at any landfill ostrich carcasses originating from a farm in Edgewood, BC, planned to be culled and delivered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency, as a result of being exposed to highly pathogenic avian influenza, until the number of birds confirmed infected with HPAI and the number classified as exposed—based on testing performed after May 15, 2025—is confirmed by the CFIA and/or the Ministry of Agriculture and Food. Further, the RDCK requests that the CFIA provide this information directly to the public in a timely and transparent manner to support public understanding and trust.\nDirector Diana Lockwood: I’ll second that.\nDirector Andy Davidoff: I’ll second that.\nChair, Aidan McLaren-Caux: The motion has been duly moved and seconded. Do we have any discussion? Anything online? Alright, all those in favour? Oh, everybody. Motion carried. Thank you.\nKatie Pasitney: Thank you. Thank you.\nFacebook \n<iframe src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fkatie.espersenprentice%2Fvideos%2F1276287834064452%2F%3Fref%3Dembed_video&show_text=0&width=267\" width=\"267\" height=\"476\" style=\"border:none;overflow:hidden\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" allow=\"autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; picture-in-picture; web-share\" allowFullScreen=\"true\"></iframe>\nLearn more about embedding Facebook videos on our developer site.\nVideo Unavailable\nSorry, this video could not be played.\nShare This Story","markdown":"# RDCK Regional District of Central Kootenay Board Meeting - Saving the Ostriches\n\nRDCK Board Meeting - Saving the Ostriches May 15, 2025 - YouTube\n\n**[RDCK Observer](https://www.youtube.com/@RDCKObserver)**, May 15, 2025\n\n**Transcript**:  \n**Chair, Aidan McLaren-Caux:** There’s nothing that we can do beyond advocacy. Because it’s not, I don’t want to be the person to say it’s not our problem, but it’s outside of our power. I know that might not be the answer you want to hear. Personally, I wish there was something I could do, but we are stuck with what we have, and we have to work within the bounds of our, we are a legislative body, so we have to respect the law. We are a country of laws, it went through all the courts.\n\n**Katie Pasitney:** I do have a question (Katie, owner of the farm). We just made it here just in time. I woke up and I had meetings all morning. We just said, we’re going, because I knew I needed to stand in front of all of you, from our farm, today. I do have a question, Chair. Will you publicly retract the false claim that UOF (Universal Ostrich Farms) lost two court cases and correct the record at this board? Because the record matters, and moving forward with disposal based on misinformation, without a legal mandate, is not just reckless—it makes this board liable for voluntary participation.\n\nI urge you all to take a step back, verify the facts, and act in truth.\n\nSorry, it’s been a journey. I’m here today to correct a serious falsehood that was entered into the public record of this board. It was stated that Universal Ostrich Farm has lost two court cases. That is not true. Let me absolutely be clear: Universal Ostrich Farm has not lost any legal case. What we did do was file for and win a judicial review granted by Justice Batista. That review was heard on April 15th and 16th in Vancouver, and the decision was released this week by Federal Court by Justice Zinn.\n\nBut here’s the part that matters to you: In paragraphs 7 and 8 of that ruling, Justice Zinn states that the court can only rule on decisions made by the CFIA _before_ January 10th, 2025. The court was legally barred from considering any evidence _after_ that date. That means the current health of our animals, the current health of our 400 healthy animals, any new test results, any recovery or scientific data—none of it could be considered. This ruling does not validate CFIA’s current actions; only that what they did at that time was, in the court’s view, reasonable based on what they knew then.\n\nWith respect, I ask you to please consider the now. Because we are in a fight for these animals that hold way more value alive than they do dead, by accepting their dead carcasses into this landfill. You can set a precedent because we have a recovered flock. We can set a precedent with all of your power in all of your seats, and everything that we stand for here today and all the voices from across our country, and the global attention that this issue is getting, we can set a precedent.\n\nOur animals are healthy, they’re laying eggs, they’re beautiful, and we are being restricted the chance from retesting our animals to prove to you as the public, that they are recovered. We are being threatened six months in jail and a $250,000 fine to bring you that evidence.\n\nSo where do we stop this? We stop it at Universal Ostrich Farm.\n\n**Chair, Aidan McLaren-Caux:** I believe I we have a director who has a motion. Directors, please check your email, so you have a copy of it, it should have been sent out a few minutes ago. Director Lunn, would you like to make your motion?\n\n**Director Jessica Lunn:** Sure, I would like to move that the RDCK board direct staff to withhold acceptance at any landfill ostrich carcasses originating from a farm in Edgewood, BC, planned to be culled and delivered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency, as a result of being exposed to highly pathogenic avian influenza, until the number of birds confirmed infected with HPAI and the number classified as exposed—based on testing performed after May 15, 2025—is confirmed by the CFIA and/or the Ministry of Agriculture and Food. Further, the RDCK requests that the CFIA provide this information directly to the public in a timely and transparent manner to support public understanding and trust.\n\n**Director Diana Lockwood:** I’ll second that.\n\n**Director Andy Davidoff:** I’ll second that.\n\n**Chair, Aidan McLaren-Caux:** The motion has been duly moved and seconded. Do we have any discussion? Anything online? Alright, all those in favour? Oh, everybody. Motion carried. Thank you.\n\n**Katie Pasitney:** Thank you. Thank you.\n\nFacebook\n\n![](https://scontent-lga3-3.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t15.5256-10/496239704_989494089876095_5101211149670016239_n.jpg?stp=dst-jpg_p526x296_tt6&_nc_cat=108&ccb=1-7&_nc_sid=442ec5&_nc_ohc=uJa0pHhXvNUQ7kNvwGFoyIE&_nc_oc=AdkPB9MZPT9fhefZdXL55akIVpNhpT7anGFBraSk2gomMHgzIcdb1ecdOb6xIm1qLdM&_nc_zt=23&_nc_ht=scontent-lga3-3.xx&edm=AN6CN6oEAAAA&_nc_gid=Aq80aug-i-DnQgyUTVDObw&oh=00_AfI2FKtmOdclxt-cRYvXOI6DvFBVilinSNVzFuyISXJElg&oe=683B24B0)\n\n[\n\n![](https://scontent-lga3-3.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t39.30808-1/475465206_10171179593500554_1836193558414329230_n.jpg?stp=cp0_dst-jpg_s40x40_tt6&_nc_cat=106&ccb=1-7&_nc_sid=fe59b0&_nc_ohc=f10u8dp1p0gQ7kNvwFrKiFW&_nc_oc=AdkNO0lzsQpt5bzh-yUJWAsb8ReqClO_BBxV-gou1eDsZ1ZiFvuaqldgPMuXznVabho&_nc_zt=24&_nc_ht=scontent-lga3-3.xx&edm=AN6CN6oEAAAA&_nc_gid=Aq80aug-i-DnQgyUTVDObw&oh=00_AfLAfMKIZvc5MtrbIHczAlG1mR3ZEWzMecEq7clqszJcHg&oe=683B269C)\n\n\n\n](https://saveourostriches.com/stories/1489603941143803/?source=EMBED_VIDEO&ref=embed_video)\n\n<iframe src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fkatie.espersenprentice%2Fvideos%2F1276287834064452%2F%3Fref%3Dembed\\_video&show\\_text=0&width=267\" width=\"267\" height=\"476\" style=\"border:none;overflow:hidden\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" allow=\"autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; picture-in-picture; web-share\" allowFullScreen=\"true\"></iframe>\n\nLearn more about embedding Facebook videos on our [developer site.](https://developers.facebook.com/docs/plugins/embedded-video-player/)\n\nVideo Unavailable\n\nSorry, this video could not be played.\n\n## Share This Story","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

rel=\"alternate\"; title=\"JSON\"; type=\"application/json\", <https://saveourostriches.com/?p=10918>; rel=shortlink","etag":"\"6918-1747988341;br\"","x-litespeed-cache":"hit","content-encoding":"br","vary":"Accept-Encoding","content-length":"25644","date":"Tue, 27 May 2025 06:36:14 GMT","server":"LiteSpeed","platform":"hostinger","panel":"hpanel","content-security-policy":"upgrade-insecure-requests","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"Press Release – May 2, 2025: Planned Burial of 400 Ostrich Carcasses at Ootischenia Landfill Before Court Decision\nEdgewood, British Columbia — May 2, 2025 — Credible reports indicate that the Ootischenia Landfill, under the jurisdiction of the Regional District of Central Kootenay (RDCK), is preparing to bury approximately 400 ostrich carcasses, totaling 140,000 pounds of biological material, from a remote farm in Edgewood, British Columbia, before a judicial decision has been made. This action raises significant environmental, public health, and legal concerns.\nKey Issues:\nThe ostriches, each weighing approximately 350 pounds, have shown no signs of illness since January 15, 2025, despite two birds testing positive for a hybrid strain of avian influenza in December 2024.\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency’s (CFIA) plan to cull the herd is currently before the courts, yet preparations for burial at Ootischenia Landfill are reportedly underway.\nThe CFIA has reportedly contacted multiple gun shooter associations to carry out the culling, but they are refusing to participate in the killing of these healthy animals.\nNo environmental impact assessment (EIA) has been conducted to evaluate the risks of burying 140,000 pounds of biological material in the landfill.\nBurial of such a large volume of decomposing matter could release hazardous substances, including ammonia, hydrogen sulfide, methane, carbon dioxide, and pathogen-contaminated leachate, posing risks to groundwater, soil, air quality, and public health.\nProvincial and federal regulations mandate strict oversight for animal carcass disposal, including permitting and environmental safeguards, which have not been addressed.\nProceeding with burial before the court’s decision could expose the RDCK and other involved parties to legal, environmental, and reputational risks. The potential for long-term ecosystem contamination underscores the need for immediate action.\nCall to Action: We urgently request that the RDCK Board:\nImmediately investigate and confirm whether such disposal is being planned.\nRequire a comprehensive environmental impact assessment before any action is authorized.\nEnsure that all relevant community stakeholders are consulted and informed.\nSeek legal clarification given that the matter remains before the courts.\nFor media inquiries, please contact:\nKatie Pasitney\nDaughter of co-owner, Karen Espersen\nUniversal Ostrich Farms Inc.\nsaveourostriches@gmail.com\nSaveOurOstriches.com","markdown":"# Press Release – May 2, 2025: Planned Burial of 400 Ostrich Carcasses at Ootischenia Landfill Before Court Decision\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/25-05-02-landfill-1024x768.png)\n\nEdgewood, British Columbia — May 2, 2025 — Credible reports indicate that the **Ootischenia Landfill**, under the jurisdiction of the **Regional District of Central Kootenay (RDCK)**, is preparing to bury approximately 400 ostrich carcasses, totaling 140,000 pounds of biological material, from a remote farm in Edgewood, British Columbia, before a judicial decision has been made. This action raises **significant environmental, public health, and legal concerns.**\n\n**Key Issues:**\n\n*   The ostriches, each weighing approximately 350 pounds, have shown **no signs of illness since January 15, 2025**, despite two birds testing positive for a hybrid strain of avian influenza in December 2024.\n*   The **Canadian Food Inspection Agency’s (CFIA)** plan to cull the herd is currently before the courts, yet preparations for burial at **Ootischenia Landfill** are reportedly underway.\n*   The CFIA has reportedly contacted multiple **gun shooter associations** to carry out the culling, but they are [**refusing to participate in the killing of these healthy animals**](https://saveourostriches.com/news/no-cfia-hunters-wont-kill-400-ostriches-for-you/).\n*   **No environmental impact assessment (EIA)** has been conducted to evaluate the risks of burying 140,000 pounds of biological material in the landfill.\n*   Burial of such a large volume of decomposing matter could release hazardous substances, including **ammonia, hydrogen sulfide, methane, carbon dioxide, and pathogen-contaminated leachate**, posing risks to groundwater, soil, air quality, and public health.\n*   Provincial and federal regulations mandate **strict oversight** for animal carcass disposal, including permitting and environmental safeguards, which have not been addressed.\n\nProceeding with burial before the court’s decision could expose the RDCK and other involved parties to legal, environmental, and reputational risks. The potential for long-term ecosystem contamination underscores the need for immediate action.\n\n**Call to Action: We urgently request that the RDCK Board:**\n\n1.  Immediately investigate and confirm whether such disposal is being planned.\n2.  Require a comprehensive environmental impact assessment before any action is authorized.\n3.  Ensure that all relevant community stakeholders are consulted and informed.\n4.  Seek legal clarification given that the matter remains before the courts.\n\n**For media inquiries, please contact:**\n\nKatie Pasitney  \nDaughter of co-owner, Karen Espersen  \nUniversal Ostrich Farms Inc.  \nsaveourostriches@gmail.com  \n[SaveOurOstriches.com](https://l.facebook.com/l.php?u=http%3A%2F%2FSaveOurOstriches.com%2F%3Ffbclid%3DIwZXh0bgNhZW0CMTAAAR5vDAEKXvR8WoQT2J3uRNzcrM-nepSpZlzRr3-ZuHYpCjNmwVQ5wQ6v06sWTg_aem_2Hq1Q0hBtxcdakgbYgh5GQ&h=AT2O4S33Fb8PFBG4AF0JQRuLII9MNomxy-ojPgh02PemaDOubzFmxbqSgnW3uqI0Rl7myaorblU2qf4M9zN0qb_f7LgIY7OEYKr8qEyjwppSVOEDjE76IdADDO84Q9VAXaQNgmoPUGZVTwAYmeMgqvNJD7uen-Pn12yp&__tn__=-UK-R&c[0]=AT3p_m7BB0TIEBoKi5iYMOAUAXMmRXmWoccuDqCa_kl4QLlz4CXwENtT42O47dOfDbA3KTy04w5_MyTEYs8wsk-gB5AtWIeObPy_1GFrYFX3b2ggT9zLSpPzcKw6zGdzPqIRMuVWenFf8vySwpUgUaVuA11QRo7DQk6USGo2PXveLrz5IC1HatquIRfYY_e8kTf5p4_ppBmKuz8jYmOmtDyFUOPDeg)","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

This action raises significant environmental, public health, and legal concerns.\nShare This Story\nTwitter Embed","markdown":"# Three MLAs are supporting a B.C. farming family whose 400 ostriches are to be culled\n\n[![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/25-05-08-CTV-News-2-1024x768.png)](https://www.ctvnews.ca/vancouver/article/three-mlas-are-supporting-a-bc-farming-family-whose-400-ostriches-are-to-be-culled/)\n\n[**CTV News**](https://www.ctvnews.ca/vancouver/article/three-mlas-are-supporting-a-bc-farming-family-whose-400-ostriches-are-to-be-culled/) | [The Canadian Press](https://www.ctvnews.ca/team/the-canadian-press/), May 8, 2025\n\nThe battle over a B.C. farm facing a mandated cull made its way to the legislature Thursday.\n\nVICTORIA — A member of an ostrich farming family held back tears as she called on the provincial government to help stop the cull of their 400 birds.\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency ordered the cull in late 2024 after an avian flu outbreak, but family spokesperson Katie Pasitney says the animals living on her parents’ farm in Edgewood, B.C., are “healthy” and “happy” now and pose no risk.\n\nPasitney says the birds are her family’s livelihood and having to kill them would be catastrophic.\n\nPasitney is in Victoria meeting provincial officials, including B.C. Agriculture Minister Lana Popham, and is receiving support from three former Conservative MLAs, who are now sitting as independents.\n\nThe family and the Canadian Food Inspection Agency are waiting on a Federal Court judge to rule on the fate of the animals.\n\nCredible reports indicate that the **Ootischenia Landfill**, under the jurisdiction of the **Regional District of Central Kootenay (RDCK)**, is preparing to bury approximately 400 ostrich carcasses, totaling 140,000 pounds of biological material, from a remote farm in Edgewood, British Columbia, before a judicial decision has been made. This action raises **significant environmental, public health, and legal concerns.**\n\n## Share This Story\n\nTwitter Embed\n\n[](https://twitter.com/OstrichFarmBC/status/1921768699448689043?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1921768699448689043%7Ctwgr%5E6fd2a8eab1af2370d4d1b4ef3c87e6ceaecd49e7%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fsaveourostriches.com%2Fnews%2Fthree-mlas-are-supporting-a-bc-farming-family-whose-400-ostriches-are-to-be-culled%2F)\n\n[\n\n![Image](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Gqt99hMbUAAcIXL?format=jpg&name=small)\n\n\n\n](https://x.com/OstrichFarmBC/status/1921768699448689043/photo/1)","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

These ostriches are part of important antiviral research and are helping develop treatments for avian flu and other viruses.\nMeanwhile, wild birds are spreading disease across North America—but the government is doing nothing to stop the spread from wildlife.\nWe need an exemption for this farm—NOW.\nIf we truly want to support farmers and foster innovation, outdated regulations must be changed.\nThis is time-sensitive—the CFIA could come to cull the birds at any moment.\nPLEASE LIKE, SHARE, and SPEAK OUT in support.\nThis farm is not a threat—it’s a valuable part of our future.\nShare This Story\nFacebook \n<iframe src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FSaveOurOstriches%2Fvideos%2F1351698015940185%2F%3Fref%3Dembed_video&show_text=0&width=560\" width=\"560\" height=\"306\" style=\"border:none;overflow:hidden\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" allow=\"autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; picture-in-picture; web-share\" allowFullScreen=\"true\"></iframe>\nLearn more about embedding Facebook videos on our developer site.\nVideo Unavailable\nSorry, this video could not be played.\nWatch on Facebook","markdown":"# Jordan Kealy, MLA for Peace River North Visits the Ostrich Farm\n\n[**Jordan Kealy, MLA**](https://wabcradio.com/episode/ostrich-farmer-katie-pasitney-on-ostrich-well-being-in-canada-5-min/)⋅May 2, 2025\n\nThe Universal Ostrich Farm needs your help to get this message out and put pressure on the Federal Government and the CFIA.\n\nThe CFIA is planning to kill all their ostriches, even though the birds are healthy and not used for human consumption. These ostriches are part of important antiviral research and are helping develop treatments for avian flu and other viruses.\n\nMeanwhile, wild birds are spreading disease across North America—but the government is doing nothing to stop the spread from wildlife.\n\n![👉](https://static.xx.fbcdn.net/images/emoji.php/v9/tf0/2/16/1f449.png) We need an exemption for this farm—NOW.\n\nIf we truly want to support farmers and foster innovation, outdated regulations must be changed.\n\n![⏰](https://static.xx.fbcdn.net/images/emoji.php/v9/tb5/2/16/23f0.png) This is time-sensitive—the CFIA could come to cull the birds at any moment.\n\nPLEASE LIKE, SHARE, and SPEAK OUT in support.\n\nThis farm is not a threat—it’s a valuable part of our future.\n\n## Share This charset=UTF-8","x-pingback":"https://saveourostriches.com/xmlrpc.php","link":"<https://saveourostriches.com/wp-json/>; rel=\"https://api.w.org/\", <https://saveourostriches.com/wp-json/wp/v2/posts/10358>; rel=\"alternate\"; title=\"JSON\"; type=\"application/json\", <https://saveourostriches.com/?p=10358>; rel=shortlink","etag":"\"6900-1747985226;br\"","x-litespeed-cache":"hit","content-encoding":"br","vary":"Accept-Encoding","content-length":"28071","date":"Tue, 27 May 2025 06:36:31 GMT","server":"LiteSpeed","platform":"hostinger","panel":"hpanel","content-security-policy":"upgrade-insecure-requests","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"April 16, 2025 - Judicial Review Update (Day 2)\nKatie Pasitney from Universal Ostrich Farms \nDay 2 of the Judicial Review @ 701 West Georgia Street, Vancouver BC.\nKatie provides an update from Federal Court, where the case of Universal Ostrich Farms against the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) is underway.\nGood morning everybody. Day Two in Vancouver and we just want to thank you for all your love and support, kind messages again. Thank you to everybody at the farm for being there, showing your support, and watching over our animals. \nPlease give us lots of prayers for today, that we have a really good rebuttal and please pray over the Department of Defence and the judge. Just pray over them for the most positive outcome, and that we do deserve the right to have policy to be changed. \nThis is a very drastic measure to take on all farms, is the stamping out policy. We’re not just stamping out these animals and viruses but we’re stamping out natural immunity. And if it doesn’t play a role in our judicial system, we can recognize that natural immunity plays a pivotal role in our ecosystem and how we care for our animals. If we don’t give some power back to the farmers who, where their hands have touched these animals, in our case for over 35 years, that our hands have touched all those animals for this long. \nThis all deserves a place in our judicial system and this should be a fair fight and fought with fairness. \nWe love you all very much, thank you for your continued love and support. Remember, if you’re able to, share and keep this discussion going, just keep your prayers with us today. We love you all very very much. Thanks for being there. \nCourtroom Notes provided by Kari Simpson\nUpdate #1\nCourt convened at 9:32. Justice Zinn began the hearing by raising troubling conduct experienced by staff from certain people attending the hearing.\nJustice Zinn informed those attending that court staff were subject to “rude and racist comments.” Justice Zinn rightly chastised those responsible and informed those attending that the court maintains a polite and harassment free service.\n(Writer’s comments- Judges as you can see, are vigilant and informed about what is transpiring in and out of the courtroom. Please conduct yourself in a manner that is helpful and allows the focus to remain on the important matter before the court.)\nJustice Zinn then delved right into the case and raised concerns about the applicants failure to raise the issue of the Avian Flu pathogen being high or low transmission. He stated that the Respondent CFIA “quite rightly raised this issue as it was not an issue raised in the memorandum.”\nThe Ostrich farm lawyers assured Justice Zinn that they would address this in reply.\nCFIA lawyer Jones then began her attack on the expert reports submitted in support of the ostrich farm.\nUpdate #2\nIt is the role of opposing counsel to try to destroy the Applicant’s case. Tax payer funded, Dept of Justice lawyer Ms. Jones acting for CFIA has a tricky way of making untrue statements that seemingly undermine the Ostrich farm but then she adds a twist of truth. so shecreally isnt misleading the court but raising doubt. Here’s an example.\nLawyer Jones began her assault on the Ostrich farm experts right out of the gate. First target is highly respected scientists Dr. Stephen Pelech. First citing the test for what constitutes an expert report, relevance, necessity, absence of exclusionary rule…\nTurning to Dr Pelech’s credentials Jones tries to pain a picture that Dr Pelech has no experience with animals, Then she says his only experience is with animals in a laboratory, then she states he has “no experience in animal health.” She uses these tactics to undermine 4 out of the 5 Ostrich farm experts.\nUpdate #3\nCFIA lawyer Saunders has taken over from his co counsel.\nSaunders is trying to educate the judge on matters involving stamping out vs exempting specific epidemiological units. Weaving in the WHOA policies and procedures.\nClearly this line of submissions is to counter the fiasco involving the designating the farm as exempted due to the valuable and rare genetics and then 8 days later revoking that distinction.\nUpdate #4\nMorning break and then through to the lunch interesting discussion on CFIAs position on vaccination.\nLawyer Saunders advances CFIAs preference to combating Avian flu is through the stamping out policy, stating that CFIA vaccination policy is continually under review.\nAt 11:16 Saunders makes this bizarre declaration referring to cases where CFIA would vaccinate. He says, “I want to stress that is that it is for prevention of being infected. That’s what it’s being used for in the policy you don’t vaccinate after the infection for the same reason you wouldn’t get the flu shot after you’ve already got the flu shot for that year.”\n(Writers comment- totally different claim the government made during COVID!)\nNext discussion was on how WHOA protects trade, lots of time spent on this.\nJudge interjects with a question about how zones are defined.\nSaunders didn’t seem to understand his question and goes into a long winded response that didn’t answer the question.\nNext issues involves exemptions and selective killing vs stamping out. Saunders claims Canadian Poultry associations support stamping out over selective killing because of trade implications but does cite any authority or letter.\nNext Saunders refers to legal authorities that address issues of what is fair and reasonable.\nLunch break. \nUpdate 5\n1:35 pm – CFIA lawyer Jones is going thru the process CFIA followed to determine the need to kill all the ostriches.\nAt 1:42 ish lawyer Michael Carter informs the court that there is a problem with the zoom feed.\nJudge addresses the problem with clerks, discussions take place as to continue or not. Justice Zinn, adds a much needed moment of levity to this very serious case and asks, “Maybe Trump imposed a tariff on zoom.”\nJustice Zinn’s clever and perfectly delivered zinger was well received by those quietly trying not to laugh too loudly.\nIt is soon determined that the zoom is working for most and those who can’t connect should retry link.\nBack to the submission by Ms Jones.\nShe starts at the time there was an anonymous call to the sick bird call line. Her account isn’t correct.\nShe spends a lot of time trying to prove that the CFIA acted in a fair and reasonable manner.\nUpdate 6\nCFIA lawyer is spending a lot of time trying to present a narrative that the farm owners were fully informed in understanding what information was required to be designated as having rare and valuable genetics.\nSparks flying in the court! Shortly after lawyer for CFIA concluded her submissions judge raised issues that have ignited some spirited submissions, happening now!\nUpdate 7\nCourt time has been extended. CFIA lawyers took extra time leaving the Ostrich farm lawyers with less time for reply.\nLawyer Lee Turner has informed the court that he is not available to stay for an extended time.\nTension is high. Lawyer for CFIA keeps interrupting, lecture judge again that his job is not based of findings of fact but only whether CFIA acted in a reasonable and fair manner.\nUpdate 8\nOstrich farm lawyer Lee Turner corrected the misinformation given to the court by CFIA lawyers.\nNow Ostrich farm lawyer Michael Carter focusing on the deficiencies in the decision making by CFIA. The evidence proves they made decisions on incomplete information. Didn’t take into consideration the fact the older birds didn’t get sick.\nNow reviewing with the court other case precedents that apply to what is irrational decision making. Court must review the reasonableness.\nShare This Story\nFacebook \n<iframe src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FSaveOurOstriches%2Fvideos%2F1454701385513303%2F%3Fref%3Dembed_video&show_text=0&width=267\" width=\"267\" height=\"476\" style=\"border:none;overflow:hidden\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" allow=\"autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; picture-in-picture; web-share\" allowFullScreen=\"true\"></iframe>\nLearn more about embedding Facebook videos on our developer site.\nVideo Unavailable\nSorry, this video could not be played.","markdown":"# April 16, 2025 - Judicial Review Update (Day 2)\n\n**Katie Pasitney from Universal Ostrich Farms**\n\nDay 2 of the Judicial Review @ 701 West Georgia Street, Vancouver BC.\n\nKatie provides an update from Federal Court, where the case of Universal Ostrich Farms against the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) is underway.\n\n> Good morning everybody. Day Two in Vancouver and we just want to thank you for all your love and support, kind messages again. Thank you to everybody at the farm for being there, showing your support, and watching over our animals.\n\n> Please give us lots of prayers for today, that we have a really good rebuttal and please pray over the Department of Defence and the judge. Just pray over them for the most positive outcome, and that we do deserve the right to have policy to be changed.\n> \n> This is a very drastic measure to take on all farms, is the stamping out policy. We’re not just stamping out these animals and viruses but we’re stamping out natural immunity. And if it doesn’t play a role in our judicial system, we can recognize that natural immunity plays a pivotal role in our ecosystem and how we care for our animals. If we don’t give some power back to the farmers who, where their hands have touched these animals, in our case for over 35 years, that our hands have touched all those animals for this long. \n> \n> This all deserves a place in our judicial system and this should be a fair fight and fought with fairness. \n> \n> We love you all very much, thank you for your continued love and support. Remember, if you’re able to, share and keep this discussion going, just keep your prayers with us today. We love you all very very much. Thanks for being there. \n\n* * *\n\n## Courtroom Notes provided by Kari Simpson\n\n## ![🌟](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/1f31f.svg) Update #1\n\nCourt convened at 9:32. Justice Zinn began the hearing by raising troubling conduct experienced by staff from certain people attending the hearing.\n\nJustice Zinn informed those attending that court staff were subject to “rude and racist comments.” Justice Zinn rightly chastised those responsible and informed those attending that the court maintains a polite and harassment free service.\n\n_(Writer’s comments- Judges as you can see, are vigilant and informed about what is transpiring in and out of the courtroom. Please conduct yourself in a manner that is helpful and allows the focus to remain on the important matter before the court.)_\n\nJustice Zinn then delved right into the case and raised concerns about the applicants failure to raise the issue of the Avian Flu pathogen being high or low transmission. He stated that the Respondent CFIA “quite rightly raised this issue as it was not an issue raised in the memorandum.”\n\nThe Ostrich farm lawyers assured Justice Zinn that they would address this in reply.\n\nCFIA lawyer Jones then began her attack on the expert reports submitted in support of the ostrich farm.\n\n* * *\n\n## ![🌟](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/1f31f.svg) Update #2\n\nIt is the role of opposing counsel to try to destroy the Applicant’s case. Tax payer funded, Dept of Justice lawyer Ms. Jones acting for CFIA has a tricky way of making untrue statements that seemingly undermine the Ostrich farm but then she adds a twist of truth. so shecreally isnt misleading the court but raising doubt. Here’s an example.\n\nLawyer Jones began her assault on the Ostrich farm experts right out of the gate. First target is highly respected scientists Dr. Stephen Pelech. First citing the test for what constitutes an expert report, relevance, necessity, absence of exclusionary rule…\n\nTurning to Dr Pelech’s credentials Jones tries to pain a picture that Dr Pelech has no experience with animals, Then she says his only experience is with animals in a laboratory, then she states he has “no experience in animal health.” She uses these tactics to undermine 4 out of the 5 Ostrich farm experts.\n\n* * *\n\n## ![🌟](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/1f31f.svg) Update #3\n\nCFIA lawyer Saunders has taken over from his co counsel.\n\nSaunders is trying to educate the judge on matters involving stamping out vs exempting specific epidemiological units. Weaving in the WHOA policies and procedures.\n\nClearly this line of submissions is to counter the fiasco involving the designating the farm as exempted due to the valuable and rare genetics and then 8 days later revoking that distinction.\n\n* * *\n\n![🌟](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/1f31f.svg) **Update #4**\n\nMorning break and then through to the lunch interesting discussion on CFIAs position on vaccination.\n\nLawyer Saunders advances CFIAs preference to combating Avian flu is through the stamping out policy, stating that CFIA vaccination policy is continually under review.  \n\nAt 11:16 Saunders makes this bizarre declaration referring to cases where CFIA would vaccinate. He says, “I want to stress that is that it is for prevention of being infected. That’s what it’s being used for in the policy you don’t vaccinate after the infection for the same reason you wouldn’t get the flu shot after you’ve already got the flu shot for that year.”\n\n_(Writers comment- totally different claim the government made during COVID!)_\n\nNext discussion was on how WHOA protects trade, lots of time spent on this.  \nJudge interjects with a question about how zones are defined.\n\nSaunders didn’t seem to understand his question and goes into a long winded response that didn’t answer the question.\n\nNext issues involves exemptions and selective killing vs stamping out. Saunders claims Canadian Poultry associations support stamping out over selective killing because of trade implications but does cite any authority or letter.\n\nNext Saunders refers to legal authorities that address issues of what is fair and reasonable.\n\nLunch break.\n\n* * *\n\n## ![🌟](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/1f31f.svg) Update 5\n\n1:35 pm – CFIA lawyer Jones is going thru the process CFIA followed to determine the need to kill all the ostriches.\n\nAt 1:42 ish lawyer Michael Carter informs the court that there is a problem with the zoom feed.\n\nJudge addresses the problem with clerks, discussions take place as to continue or not. Justice Zinn, adds a much needed moment of levity to this very serious case and asks, “Maybe Trump imposed a tariff on zoom.”\n\nJustice Zinn’s clever and perfectly delivered zinger was well received by those quietly trying not to laugh too loudly.\n\nIt is soon determined that the zoom is working for most and those who can’t connect should retry link.\n\nBack to the submission by Ms Jones.\n\nShe starts at the time there was an anonymous call to the sick bird call line. Her account isn’t correct.\n\nShe spends a lot of time trying to prove that the CFIA acted in a fair and reasonable manner.\n\n* * *\n\n## ![🌟](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/1f31f.svg) **Update 6**\n\nCFIA lawyer is spending a lot of time trying to present a narrative that the farm owners were fully informed in understanding what information was required to be designated as having rare and valuable genetics.\n\nSparks flying in the court! Shortly after lawyer for CFIA concluded her submissions judge raised issues that have ignited some spirited submissions, happening now!\n\n* * *\n\n## ![🌟](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/1f31f.svg) **Update 7**\n\nCourt time has been extended. CFIA lawyers took extra time leaving the Ostrich farm lawyers with less time for reply.\n\nLawyer Lee Turner has informed the court that he is not available to stay for an extended time.\n\nTension is high. Lawyer for CFIA keeps interrupting, lecture judge again that his job is not based of findings of fact but only whether CFIA acted in a reasonable and fair manner.\n\n* * *\n\n## ![🌟](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/1f31f.svg) **Update 8**\n\nOstrich farm lawyer Lee Turner corrected the misinformation given to the court by CFIA lawyers.\n\nNow Ostrich farm lawyer Michael Carter focusing on the deficiencies in the decision making by CFIA. The evidence proves they made decisions on incomplete information. Didn’t take into consideration the fact the older birds didn’t get sick.\n\nNow reviewing with the court other case precedents that apply to what is irrational decision making. Court must review the reasonableness.\n\n## Share This Story\n\nFacebook\n\n![](https://scontent-lga3-3.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t15.5256-10/491687341_957061059963114_3662237876861527067_n.jpg?stp=dst-jpg_p403x403_tt6&_nc_cat=110&ccb=1-7&_nc_sid=442ec5&_nc_ohc=2fUDaaq-ib4Q7kNvwHOiRfc&_nc_oc=AdlsJTT8mTej2BEeq47C_3UtZJQ3S8AheI4pr_rvhj7eelY66IcBOl8PycyIG2ErFeQ&_nc_zt=23&_nc_ht=scontent-lga3-3.xx&edm=AGo2L-IEAAAA&_nc_gid=8WKlhYl2aP7RQEo3wAcIFA&oh=00_AfJZ1FUNmRqCMHl_QJhpYFB8VY9bunuqUzeNnrqZqZSmEg&oe=683B1CBF)\n\n[\n\n![](https://scontent-lga3-3.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t39.30808-1/476745112_122093157644772897_1449603359353336363_n.jpg?stp=cp0_dst-jpg_s40x40_tt6&_nc_cat=110&ccb=1-7&_nc_sid=f907e8&_nc_ohc=w0tbyxCHRnMQ7kNvwFCExTv&_nc_oc=Admx9zG_K_EDo_8_DfKseLLq9QZ3ORy-zPRbuyLAhG_VowbkvkwWu7niUDTkoCpU4t8&_nc_zt=24&_nc_ht=scontent-lga3-3.xx&edm=AGo2L-IEAAAA&_nc_gid=8WKlhYl2aP7RQEo3wAcIFA&oh=00_AfJfcilbhmDtpv7ig68uTS7KuuA5vaENBh2gLNisshmdYw&oe=683B358F)\n\n](https://saveourostriches.com/watch/SaveOurOstriches/?ref=embed_video)\n\n<iframe src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FSaveOurOstriches%2Fvideos%2F1454701385513303%2F%3Fref%3Dembed\\_video&show\\_text=0&width=267\" width=\"267\" height=\"476\" style=\"border:none;overflow:hidden\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" allow=\"autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; picture-in-picture; web-share\" allowFullScreen=\"true\"></iframe>\n\nLearn more about embedding Facebook videos on our [developer site.](https://developers.facebook.com/docs/plugins/embedded-video-player/)\n\nVideo Unavailable\n\nSorry, this video could not be played.","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

CBC News\nUniversal Ostrich in Edgewood had faced Feb. 1 deadline to cull birds after H5N1 was detected on farm \nCBC News · Akshay Kulkarni · Posted: Apr 15, 2025\nLawyers for a B.C. ostrich farm, which has been ordered to cull its entire flock over avian flu concerns, told a Federal Court judge on Tuesday that officials’ order to depopulate the flock was unreasonable and unfair.\nBut a lawyer for the Canadian Food Inspection Agency, which ordered the cull, said that it is legislated to protect Canadians and other animals from avian flu and its order is part of a global response to a virus which has killed millions of birds in B.C. alone.\nUniversal Ostrich is located on a rural road near Edgewood, in B.C.’s West Kootenay region, an approximately 175-kilometre drive east from Kelowna along a winding highway.\nIts entire flock of about 400 birds was ordered culled in February by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency after H5N1 avian flu was detected in December — but the farm managed to get its birds a stay of execution until the court could rule on the merits of the cull order.\nThe two-day hearing, which began Tuesday, is the latest development in a case that has pitted public opinion in favour of the birds against officials who say that a cull would be in the best interests of public health.\nWATCH | Ostriches get stay of execution: \nCourt pauses cull order on B.C. ostriches ordered killed over avian flu fears\n3 months ago\nDuration2:31The owners of an ostrich farm in the Kootenays have won a court injunction against the cull of hundreds of their birds. A federal agency ordered the farmers to kill off their herd after avian flu was detected at the site in December, but the owners are pushing back. Brady Strachan reports.\nMichael Carter, Universal Ostrich’s lawyer, argued in court on Tuesday that the CFIA was not following its own policies in refusing to grant an exemption to the farm. He said the detection of avian flu on the remote farm would not inhibit any other poultry operations in the area.\n“I say that the decision is not reasonable … and it was not procedurally fair,” he told the court.\nNumber of domestic birds impacted by H5-subtype avian flu per province\nBut the lawyer for the CFIA said that Universal Ostrich was taking a narrow view of a singular policy decision and that the ostriches were exposed to wild birds and other animals, who could further spread the virus and cause further mutations.\n“[These] decisions have to be made in light of the agency’s broad mandate, which is to help protect all animals and all Canadians from both the health risks of avian flu and its impact on the national poultry industry and the Canadian economy,” she told the court.\nCFIA cites new variant of flu\nUniversal Ostrich’s owners have argued that its birds have achieved herd immunity after a few dozen died in December, and its birds do not pose a public health risk — even as the agency argues that depopulation is required regardless of the remaining birds’ immunity status.\n“The National Centre for Foreign Animal Disease (NCFAD) identified that the current HPAI infection in these ostriches is a new variant of the virus not seen elsewhere in Canada,” a CFIA spokesperson wrote in a statement sent to CBC News last month.\n“Continued transmission of avian influenza virus in animals and sporadic cases in people may increase the chance of changes to the virus itself that could lead to a human-to-human transmission scenario and/or more severe strains of avian influenza virus for humans.”\nOver 400 ostriches at Universal Ostrich were ordered culled over avian influenza fears. B.C. is the province that has been most affected by highly pathogenic avian flu. (Brady Strachan/CBC) \nThe CFIA pointed to the first case of H5N1 avian flu in a B.C. teen last November, as well as a death attributed to the virus in the U.S., as proof the virus can cause severe disease.\n“Under Canada’s stamping out policy, all domestic birds at an infected premises are depopulated to control the risk of further spread,” the spokesperson wrote.\nThe federal Health Ministry has also expressed support for the cull, saying the CFIA’s legal team has asked for an expedited hearing and decision from the courts.\nBirds not being bred for meat\nThe farm’s operators have said that a small percentage of its around 400 birds — 69 in total — have died of avian flu. But they say the rest of the flock has not shown any symptoms of the disease for months.\nIndeed, Universal Ostrich says its birds are being studied as part of a partnership with Japan’s Kyoto Prefectural University, which has previously made headlines for its work with ostrich eggs and detecting COVID-19.\nThe farm says its ostriches pose little risk to the broader population, as they are flightless birds that are not being used for meat. (Submitted by Katie Pasitney) \nSupporters say a cull fails to account for the specifics of the situation being faced by the farm’s owners, Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski, who have raised some of the birds facing death for decades.\nThe risks of flu spread from the ostriches is minimized, according to the farm’s owners, because Universal Ostrich does not sell its birds for meat, and they cannot fly.\n“What’s at stake? It’s our food security. It’s our agricultural industry,” Katie Pasitney, Espersen’s daughter and farm spokesperson, told CBC News ahead of the court hearing. “Our ostriches are just a catalyst in the movement for some change and correction of policy.”\nWATCH | Ostriches faced widespread cull: \nCBC Player \nOstrich farm faces Feb. 1 cull\nKatie Pasitney of Universal Ostrich introduces some of her Facebook followers to the ostriches who have been ordered killed by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency after avian flu was detected at the farm.\nThe cull order and officials’ assertions about the infected birds have become a flashpoint for a set of supporters who view the order to kill the birds, who can live for 30 or even 40 years, as an example of government overreach.\nTensions have been high, with the RCMP saying they were investigating after one of the farm’s ostriches was shot and killed on March 21.\nB.C. ostrich farm gets stay of execution for birds ordered killed due to avian flu fears\nThis ostrich farm survived wildfires. Now, avian flu means 400 birds need to be culled\nUltimately, the CFIA’s original cull order on Feb. 1 was halted by Federal Court Justice Michael Battista, who said he was satisfied by the arguments made that the farm would suffer “irreparable harm” should the cull have gone ahead, and that it had raised reasonable questions about whether a cull was necessary in the first place.\nResearchers contacted by CBC News say there is limited information on whether ostriches can develop immunity to avian flu.","markdown":"# Federal Court reviews avian flu cull order for B.C. ostrich farm - CBC News\n\nUniversal Ostrich in Edgewood had faced Feb. 1 deadline to cull birds after H5N1 was detected on farm\n\nCBC News · [**Akshay Kulkarni**](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/author/akshay-kulkarni-1.6031235) · Posted: Apr 15, 2025\n\nLawyers for a B.C. ostrich farm, which has been ordered to cull its entire flock over avian flu concerns, told a Federal Court judge on Tuesday that officials’ order to depopulate the flock was unreasonable and unfair.\n\nBut a lawyer for the Canadian Food Inspection Agency, which ordered the cull, said that it is legislated to protect Canadians and other animals from avian flu and its order is part of a global response to a virus which has killed millions of birds in B.C. alone.\n\nUniversal Ostrich is located on a rural road near Edgewood, in B.C.’s West Kootenay region, an approximately 175-kilometre drive east from Kelowna along a winding highway.\n\nIts entire flock of about 400 birds was [ordered culled](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/bc-ostrich-farm-edgewood-1.7429394) in February by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency after H5N1 avian flu was detected in December — but the farm managed to get its birds [a stay of execution](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/universal-ostrich-kill-cull-avian-flu-1.7446768) until the court could rule on the merits of the cull order.\n\nThe two-day hearing, which began Tuesday, is the latest development in a case that has pitted public opinion in favour of the birds against officials who say that a cull would be in the best interests of public health.\n\n**_WATCH | Ostriches get stay of execution:_** \n\n![](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/6405202a-62ae-487a-b2f3-46ee3adefe25,1738377009127/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D620)\n\nCourt pauses cull order on B.C. ostriches ordered killed over avian flu fears\n\n**3 months ago**\n\nDuration2:31The owners of an ostrich farm in the Kootenays have won a court injunction against the cull of hundreds of their birds. A federal agency ordered the farmers to kill off their herd after avian flu was detected at the site in December, but the owners are pushing back. Brady Strachan reports.\n\nMichael Carter, Universal Ostrich’s lawyer, argued in court on Tuesday that the CFIA was not following its own policies in refusing to grant an exemption to the farm. He said the detection of avian flu on the remote farm would not inhibit any other poultry operations in the area.\n\n“I say that the decision is not reasonable … and it was not procedurally fair,” he told the court.\n\n**Number of domestic birds impacted by H5-subtype avian flu per province**\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/25-04-15-number-of-domestic-birds-1024x578.png)\n\nBut the lawyer for the CFIA said that Universal Ostrich was taking a narrow view of a singular policy decision and that the ostriches were exposed to wild birds and other animals, who could further spread the virus and cause further mutations.\n\n“\\[These\\] decisions have to be made in light of the agency’s broad mandate, which is to help protect all animals and all Canadians from both the health risks of avian flu and its impact on the national poultry industry and the Canadian economy,” she told the court.\n\n## CFIA cites new variant of flu\n\nUniversal Ostrich’s owners have argued that its birds have achieved herd immunity after a few dozen died in December, and its birds do not pose a public health risk — even as the agency argues that depopulation is required regardless of the remaining birds’ immunity status.\n\n“The National Centre for Foreign Animal Disease (NCFAD) identified that the current HPAI infection in these ostriches is a new variant of the virus not seen elsewhere in Canada,” a CFIA spokesperson wrote in a statement sent to CBC News last month.\n\n“Continued transmission of avian influenza virus in animals and sporadic cases in people may increase the chance of changes to the virus itself that could lead to a human-to-human transmission scenario and/or more severe strains of avian influenza virus for humans.”\n\n![Ostriches in a snow-filled yard behind a fence.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7447783.1744663407!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/universal-ostrich.jpg?im=)\n\nOver 400 ostriches at Universal Ostrich were ordered culled over avian influenza fears. B.C. is the province that has been most affected by highly pathogenic avian flu. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\n\nThe CFIA pointed to the first case of H5N1 avian flu [in a B.C. teen](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/b-c-doctor-treats-h5n1-teen-1.7430242) last November, as well as a death attributed to the virus [in the U.S.](https://www.cbc.ca/news/health/h5n1-death-louisiana-1.7424277), as proof the virus can cause severe disease.\n\n“Under Canada’s stamping out policy, all domestic birds at an infected premises are depopulated to control the risk of further spread,” the spokesperson wrote.\n\nThe federal Health Ministry has also expressed support for the cull, saying the CFIA’s legal team has asked for an expedited hearing and decision from the courts.\n\n## Birds not being bred for meat\n\nThe farm’s operators have said that a small percentage of its around 400 birds — 69 in total — have died of avian flu. But they say the rest of the flock has not shown any symptoms of the disease for months.\n\nIndeed, Universal Ostrich says its birds are being studied as part of a partnership with Japan’s Kyoto Prefectural University, which has [previously made headlines for its work with ostrich eggs and detecting COVID-19](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/dec/10/scientists-ostrich-cells-glowing-covid-detection-masks).\n\n![A herd of ostriches is seen in a snowy field.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7429424.1744663456!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/universal-ostrich.jpg?im=)\n\nThe farm says its ostriches pose little risk to the broader population, as they are flightless birds that are not being used for meat. (Submitted by Katie Pasitney)\n\nSupporters say a cull fails to account for the specifics of the situation being faced by the farm’s owners, Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski, who have raised some of the birds facing death for decades.\n\nThe risks of flu spread from the ostriches is minimized, according to the farm’s owners, because Universal Ostrich does not sell its birds for meat, and they cannot fly.\n\n“What’s at stake? It’s our food security. It’s our agricultural industry,” Katie Pasitney, Espersen’s daughter and farm spokesperson, told CBC News ahead of the court hearing. “Our ostriches are just a catalyst in the movement for some change and correction of policy.”\n\n**_WATCH | Ostriches faced widespread cull:_** \n\n    CBC Player\n\n![](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/5e537679-b568-469d-839d-2b0cfa5d4a50,1738289721040/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D1180)\n\nOstrich farm faces Feb. 1 cull\n\nKatie Pasitney of Universal Ostrich introduces some of her Facebook followers to the ostriches who have been ordered killed by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency after avian flu was detected at the farm.\n\nThe cull order and officials’ assertions about the infected birds have become a flashpoint for a set of supporters who view the order to kill the birds, who can live for 30 or even 40 years, as an example of government overreach.\n\nTensions have been high, with the RCMP saying they were investigating after one of the farm’s ostriches was shot and killed on March 21.\n\n*   [B.C. ostrich farm gets stay of execution for birds ordered killed due to avian flu fears](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/universal-ostrich-kill-cull-avian-flu-1.7446768)\n*   [This ostrich farm survived wildfires. Now, avian flu means 400 birds need to be culled](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/bc-ostrich-farm-edgewood-1.7429394)\n\nUltimately, the CFIA’s original cull order on Feb. 1 was halted by Federal Court Justice Michael Battista, who said he was satisfied by the arguments made that the farm would suffer “irreparable harm” should the cull have gone ahead, and that it had raised reasonable questions about whether a cull was necessary in the first place.\n\nResearchers contacted by CBC News say there is limited information on whether ostriches can develop immunity to avian flu.","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

What is the goal here? To save healthy animals from an inhumane and unjustified death.Our shared mission is simple and powerful: to protect healthy animals, and ultimately people, from an unnecessary,...\nFederal Court Decision in Universal Ostrich Farms Inc v. This appeal is in addition to the motion for clarification and an expedited Judicial Review hearing already before the court.\nThe Department of Justice lawyers, acting on behalf of the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) filed more court documents yesterday.\nLate this morning Universal Ostrich farm owners Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski were informed by their legal counsel Michael Carter, that the CFIA is now “appealing” the injunction granted by Justice Battista on January 31, 2025, prohibiting the execution of the now healthy ostriches. They are also seeking an expedited hearing of the judicial review and a clarification of the injunction order.\nSpeaking for the family farm Katie Pasitney states “It is obvious, in addition to the emotional assault, the deliberate infliction of psychological pain and suffering, bankrupting us by destroying our business, the CFIA is now amping up their legal assault against us in the hope we will finally break. We will fight.”\nSupporters from around the world have joined the effort of the Save Our Ostriches campaign. A team of volunteers has ignited the newly established social media platforms with videos of CFIA agents, in hazmat suits, admitting the ostriches “look healthy’ but must be “eradicated.” These videos went viral.\nWatch CFIA Inspection Videos here.\nThank you to all of you who keep helping us fight for what’s right and to protect our farmers, our animals and science.\nLove Universal Ostrich Family","markdown":"# Press Release – Feb 11, 2025: Department of Justice Lawyers File Appeal\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/image-1024x578.png)\n\n**PRESS RELEASE** Feb 11, 2025\n\n**DOJ Lawyers File Appeal! This appeal is in addition to the motion for clarification and an expedited Judicial Review hearing already before the court.**\n\nThe Department of Justice lawyers, acting on behalf of the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) filed more court documents yesterday.\n\nLate this morning Universal Ostrich farm owners Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski were informed by their legal counsel Michael Carter, that the CFIA is now “appealing” the injunction granted by Justice Battista on January 31, 2025, prohibiting the execution of the now healthy ostriches. They are also seeking an expedited hearing of the judicial review and a clarification of the injunction order.\n\nSpeaking for the family farm Katie Pasitney states “It is obvious, in addition to the emotional assault, the deliberate infliction of psychological pain and suffering, bankrupting us by destroying our business, the CFIA is now amping up their legal assault against us in the hope we will finally break. We will fight.”\n\nSupporters from around the world have joined the effort of the Save Our Ostriches campaign. A team of volunteers has ignited the newly established social media platforms with videos of CFIA agents, in hazmat suits, admitting the ostriches “look healthy’ but must be “eradicated.” These videos went viral.\n\n[![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/25-01-24-CFIA-Inspection-1024x768.png)](https://saveourostriches.com/cfia-inspection-videos/)\n\nWatch CFIA Inspection Videos **[here](https://saveourostriches.com/cfia-inspection-videos/)**.\n\nThank you to all of you who keep helping us fight for what’s right and to protect our farmers, our animals and science.\n\nLove Universal Ostrich Family","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

rel=\"alternate\"; title=\"JSON\"; type=\"application/json\", <https://saveourostriches.com/?p=10188>; rel=shortlink","etag":"\"7046-1748063517;br\"","x-litespeed-cache":"hit","content-encoding":"br","vary":"Accept-Encoding","content-length":"24188","date":"Tue, 27 May 2025 06:41:23 GMT","server":"LiteSpeed","platform":"hostinger","panel":"hpanel","content-security-policy":"upgrade-insecure-requests","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"Feb 19, 2025 Update From the Farm\nWe are in a huge battle to save our animals, and in turn, they could help save yours.\nLet’s not allow this to become another mistake made by the government. Help us protect the science that supports natural immunity, which could be key to both animal and human survival.\nWe are prepared to fight with everything we have, but we need legal support to continue. Please consider donating and sharing our story to help protect science, our farmers, our food, our freedom, and our animals.\nThis money goes directly to our farm and the legal costs, which are climbing quickly in this fight.\nYesterday we received a written response from Justice Battista. Here is a brief explanation:\nBackground\nOn December 31, 2024, CFIA issued a Notice ordering Universal Ostrich Farms to cull (kill) its ostriches because some tested positive for Avian Influenza.\nThe farm challenged this decision by filing an application for judicial review on January 30, 2025.\nOn January 31, 2025, the court issued a Stay Order, meaning the culling was paused until the court reviews the case.\nThe CFIA appealed the Stay Order to the Federal Court of Appeal.\nCurrent Motion (CFIA’s Request):\nCFIA asked the court to clarify whether the Stay Order also prevents the Minister from using their authority under the Health of Animals Act to KILL the ostriches.\nCFIA also requested an expedited hearing for the judicial review, arguing that this is a matter of public health.\nThe CFIA wants all of the healthy ostriches still killed without allowing any further testing other than the 2 PCR tests 50 days ago on 2 dead ostriches. They emailed us stating even if we tested negative they want the ostriches destroyed.\nCourt’s Decision\nThe judge rejected CFIA’s request for clarification, stating that the Stay Order is clear and already prevents the culling until a final decision is made. However we are nervous that they still find themselves above the current ruling.\nHowever, the judge agreed to expedite the hearing and this will be heard in the next 10 days and we have until the end of this week to have our documents and case submitted.\nWe are now waiting to hear which Judge will be hearing our Judicial Review and an exact date this will be heard.\nKey Takeaways:\nThe Stay Order remains in place.\nThe judicial review hearing will be expedited in the next 10 days\nThe CFIA’s request for clarification was denied\nMany Blessings\nUniversal Ostrich Family","markdown":"# Feb 19, 2025 Update From the Farm\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/image-1-1024x578.png)\n\nWe are in a huge battle to save our animals, and in turn, they could help save yours.\n\nLet’s not allow this to become another mistake made by the government. Help us protect the science that supports natural immunity, which could be key to both animal and human survival.\n\nWe are prepared to fight with everything we have, but we need legal support to continue. Please consider donating and sharing our story to help protect science, our farmers, our food, our freedom, and our animals.\n\nThis money goes directly to our farm and the legal costs, which are climbing quickly in this fight.\n\nYesterday we received a written response from Justice Battista. Here is a brief explanation:\n\n### Background\n\nOn December 31, 2024, CFIA issued a Notice ordering Universal Ostrich Farms to cull (kill) its ostriches because some tested positive for Avian Influenza.\n\nThe farm challenged this decision by filing an application for judicial review on January 30, 2025.\n\nOn January 31, 2025, the court issued a Stay Order, meaning the culling was paused until the court reviews the case.\n\nThe CFIA appealed the Stay Order to the Federal Court of Appeal.\n\n### Current Motion (CFIA’s Request):\n\nCFIA asked the court to clarify whether the Stay Order also prevents the Minister from using their authority under the Health of Animals Act to KILL the ostriches.\n\nCFIA also requested an expedited hearing for the judicial review, arguing that this is a matter of public health.\n\nThe CFIA wants all of the healthy ostriches still killed without allowing any further testing other than the 2 PCR tests 50 days ago on 2 dead ostriches. They emailed us stating even if we tested negative they want the ostriches destroyed.\n\n### Court’s Decision\n\nThe judge rejected CFIA’s request for clarification, stating that the Stay Order is clear and already prevents the culling until a final decision is made. However we are nervous that they still find themselves above the current ruling.\n\nHowever, the judge agreed to expedite the hearing and this will be heard in the next 10 days and we have until the end of this week to have our documents and case submitted.\n\nWe are now waiting to hear which Judge will be hearing our Judicial Review and an exact date this will be heard.\n\n### Key Takeaways:\n\n*   The Stay Order remains in place.\n*   The judicial review hearing will be expedited in the next 10 days\n*   The CFIA’s request for clarification was denied\n\nMany Blessings  \nUniversal Ostrich Family","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

It’s about standing up against government overreach, demanding transparency, protecting the livelihoods of hardworking people, and defending the right to test and treat your own animals.\nThis battle goes beyond politics. This is about standing up for what’s right — for change the world desperately needs.\nWith love, Karen","markdown":"# Feb 6, 2025 Update From the Farm\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/KarenWithOstriches-1024x768.png)\n\n**ROUND 2!!!**\n\nThe ostriches are still not safe. The CFIA is still pushing for them to be killed.\n\nThis fight isn’t just about the future of 400 birds — it’s about something much bigger. It’s about standing up against government overreach, demanding transparency, protecting the livelihoods of hardworking people, and defending the right to test and treat your own animals.\n\nThis battle goes beyond politics. It’s about coming together as a global community to protect what truly matters: life, truth, and sovereignty.\n\nThese next 30 days aren’t just a countdown — they’re a **call to action**. For everyone who believes in justice, in transparency, and in preserving farms, animals, and the people who care for them. ![❤️](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/2764.svg)\n\nThis fight is for:\n\n*   The future of natural immunity and scientific freedom\n*   The families who pour everything into their land and animals\n*   The communities that depend on them\n*   A better future for all of us ![✨](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/2728.svg)\n\n**Don’t stop now.**\n\nYour voice matters.  \nYour actions matter.  \nYour strength matters.\n\nThis is bigger than just our 400 ostriches.
