The Canadian Press\nTORONTO — A federal judge has granted a temporary reprieve to about 400 ostriches that were facing a deadline on Saturday for them to be killed at a British Columbia farm hit by an outbreak of avian flu.\nBy: Hannah Alberga, The Canadian Press\nJan 31, 2025\nA federal judge has granted a temporary reprieve to about 400 ostriches that were facing a deadline on Saturday for them to be killed at a British Columbia farm hit by an outbreak of avian flu.\nJustice Michael Battista ruled Friday to stay the cull order imposed by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency while the farm seeks a judicial review of the case.\nBattista said in a written decision that going ahead with Saturday’s order before the matter could be further examined “would expose the applicant to irreparable harm.”\nA lawyer for Universal Ostrich Farms Inc. had argued in a Friday hearing in Toronto Federal Court that the ostriches should be exempt from the order because their genetics are the subject of an antibody research study, making them rare and valuable.\nMichael Carter said his clients — farm co-owners Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski — had “happy tears” when they learned the news after watching the proceedings virtually from Edgewood, B.C., about 200 kilometres east of Kelowna.\n“Next we will be proceeding with the hearing to look at the CFIA’s decision to have the birds culled and whether it was reasonable,” Carter said in a phone call after the decision.\nEspersen’s daughter, Katie Pasitney, said everyone involved with the farm was “ecstatic” after learning about Friday’s decision.\n“It’s been a lot of sleepless nights, and it’s been a lot of long days, not knowing if we were looking at having to see 35 years of 400 animals get unnecessarily murdered, killed,” she said in a phone interview.\nPasitney said supporters would be gathering on Saturday to celebrate the “huge win,” while respecting a quarantine notice on the farm.\n“Ostriches love people. They’re very curious. They’re very interested in people and they love music, so I’m sure everybody is going to see the ostriches all lined up along the road, at the fence, watching what’s going on tomorrow.”\nStill, Pasitney said Universal Ostrich knows there is a long road ahead. They had not been informed of a date for a hearing in the judicial review, she added.\nThe CFIA issued the cull order after avian flu was detected in two dead ostriches Dec. 30 and its lawyer argued Friday that public health concerns outweighed the farm’s position.\nThe federal agency’s lawyer, Paul Saunders, told the hearing that it required farms to cull entire herds because there was a risk that the virus could incubate, mutate and create new variants, even in healthy animals.\n“There is a risk of human transmission. There is a risk of illness and death,” Saunders said.\nThe farm initially applied for a CFIA exemption for animals with rare genetics, but the federal agency denied their application Jan. 10.\nIn his ruling, Battista said that allowing the cull to proceed would mean irreparable harm in the form of “the closure of (a) 25-year-old business and the loss of the applicant’s decades-long efforts in cultivating a unique herd of ostriches.”\nThe disposal order is stayed until a decision in the judicial review.\nBattista denied a request to amend the quarantine notice on the farm.\nThe farm’s ostriches have been the subject of a research project in collaboration with Dr. Yasuhiro Tsukamoto, president of Kyoto Prefectural University in Japan.\nThe scientist, also known as Dr. Ostrich, has been extracting COVID-19 antibodies from ostrich eggs in B.C., building on his decades of research on the antibodies in ostrich egg yolk that can block infectious diseases.\nTsukamoto has said his research could be applied to avian flu.\nCarter had argued that the ostriches’ genetics were irreplaceable and they should be treated and researched.\n“They treated the ostriches like chickens in a chicken barn,” Carter said of the CFIA decision that considered the birds poultry.\nCourt documents show 69 of the 450 ostriches on the farm died between mid-December and Jan. 15 after showing 2025\n\nA federal judge has granted a temporary reprieve to about 400 ostriches that were facing a deadline on Saturday for them to be killed at a British Columbia farm hit by an outbreak of avian flu.\n\nJustice Michael Battista ruled Friday to stay the cull order imposed by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency while the farm seeks a judicial review of the case.\n\nBattista said in a written decision that going ahead with Saturday’s order before the matter could be further examined “would expose the applicant to irreparable harm.”\n\nA lawyer for Universal Ostrich Farms Inc. had argued in a Friday hearing in Toronto Federal Court that the ostriches should be exempt from the order because their genetics are the subject of an antibody research study, making them rare and valuable.\n\nMichael Carter said his clients — farm co-owners Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski — had “happy tears” when they learned the news after watching the proceedings virtually from Edgewood, B.C., about 200 kilometres east of Kelowna.\n\n“Next we will be proceeding with the hearing to look at the CFIA’s decision to have the birds culled and whether it was reasonable,” Carter said in a phone call after the decision.\n\nEspersen’s daughter, Katie Pasitney, said everyone involved with the farm was “ecstatic” after learning about Friday’s decision.\n\n“It’s been a lot of sleepless nights, and it’s been a lot of long days, not knowing if we were looking at having to see 35 years of 400 animals get unnecessarily murdered, killed,” she said in a phone interview.\n\nPasitney said supporters would be gathering on Saturday to celebrate the “huge win,” while respecting a quarantine notice on the farm.\n\n“Ostriches love people. They’re very curious. They’re very interested in people and they love music, so I’m sure everybody is going to see the ostriches all lined up along the road, at the fence, watching what’s going on tomorrow.”\n\nStill, Pasitney said Universal Ostrich knows there is a long road ahead. They had not been informed of a date for a hearing in the judicial review, she added.\n\nThe CFIA issued the cull order after avian flu was detected in two dead ostriches Dec. 30 and its lawyer argued Friday that public health concerns outweighed the farm’s position.\n\nThe federal agency’s lawyer, Paul Saunders, told the hearing that it required farms to cull entire herds because there was a risk that the virus could incubate, mutate and create new variants, even in healthy animals.\n\n“There is a risk of human transmission. There is a risk of illness and death,” Saunders said.\n\nThe farm initially applied for a CFIA exemption for animals with rare genetics, but the federal agency denied their application Jan. 10.\n\nIn his ruling, Battista said that allowing the cull to proceed would mean irreparable harm in the form of “the closure of (a) 25-year-old business and the loss of the applicant’s decades-long efforts in cultivating a unique herd of ostriches.”\n\nThe disposal order is stayed until a decision in the judicial review.\n\nBattista denied a request to amend the quarantine notice on the farm.\n\nThe farm’s ostriches have been the subject of a research project in collaboration with Dr. Yasuhiro Tsukamoto, president of Kyoto Prefectural University in Japan.\n\nThe scientist, also known as Dr. Ostrich, has been extracting COVID-19 antibodies from ostrich eggs in B.C., building on his decades of research on the antibodies in ostrich egg yolk that can block infectious diseases.\n\nTsukamoto has said his research could be applied to avian flu.\n\nCarter had argued that the ostriches’ genetics were irreplaceable and they should be treated and researched.\n\n“They treated the ostriches like chickens in a chicken barn,” Carter said of the CFIA decision that considered the birds poultry.\n\nCourt documents show 69 of the 450 ostriches on the farm died between mid-December and Jan. 15 after showing symptoms of avian influenza.","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

rel=\"alternate\"; title=\"JSON\"; type=\"application/json\", <https://saveourostriches.com/?p=9678>; rel=shortlink","etag":"\"7116-1748142090;br\"","x-litespeed-cache":"hit","content-encoding":"br","vary":"Accept-Encoding","content-length":"31659","date":"Tue, 27 May 2025 06:41:39 GMT","server":"LiteSpeed","platform":"hostinger","panel":"hpanel","content-security-policy":"upgrade-insecure-requests","x-firefox-spdy":"h2"}},"screenshotUrl":null,"text":"B.C. ostrich farm gets stay of execution for birds ordered killed due to avian flu fears - CBC News\nCBC News · Andrew Kurjata · \nFederal Court judge staves off Feb. 1 cull deadline as convoy of supporters embraces their cause. \nDave Bilinski and Karen Espersen of Universal Ostrich pose with a portion of their flock of birds after learning a deadline to have them killed over avian flu concerns has been put off by a federal judge. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\nA flock of B.C. ostriches ordered killed after avian flu was detected on their farm have been granted a stay of execution by a Federal Court judge.\nIn a ruling shared Friday afternoon, Justice Michael Battista said that the Feb. 1 deadline for the birds to be killed should be suspended until after a hearing on the original order from the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) can be reviewed by the courts.\nBattista wrote he was satisfied by the arguments made that the farm would suffer “irreparable harm” should the cull go ahead on Saturday and that it had raised reasonable questions about whether a cull is necessary in the first place, which will be the subject of a future court ruling.\n“We’re going to bring change,” said Katie Pasitney, before exchanging hugs with supporters gathered in the kitchen of the house on the farm, which is co-owned by her mother, Karen Espersen, who broke down in tears after getting the news, saying “God is good today.”\nWATCH | Judge issues pause on federal cull order:\nCBC Player \nCourt pauses cull order on B.C. ostriches ordered killed over avian flu fears\nThe owners of an ostrich farm in the Kootenays have won a court injunction against the cull of hundreds of their birds. A federal agency ordered the farmers to kill off their herd after avian flu was detected at the site in December, but the owners are pushing back. Brady Strachan reports.\nIt’s the latest development in a saga of the farm in the B.C. Interior whose owners have turned to the courts and the court of public opinion to save what it says are roughly 400 birds in their care. \nUniversal Ostrich is located on a rural road near Edgewood, in B.C.’s West Kootenay region. Getting there is an approximately 175 kilometre drive from Kelowna along a winding highway, or about 360 kilometres northeast of Vancouver as the crow flies.\nAnd for the past several weeks, it has been the site of a growing set of supporters who view the order to kill the birds, who can live for 30 or even 40 years, as an example of government overreach that fails to account for the specifics of the situation being faced by the farm’s owners, Espersen and Dave Bilinski, who have raised some of the birds facing death for decades.\n“We just want transparency,” said Pasitney, who has been acting as a spokesperson for her mother’s farm.\nKatie Pasitney hugs supporters after learning the ostriches on her mother’s farm will not have to be killed until after a court hearing ruling on an order from the Canadian Food Inspection Agency to cull the entire herd. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\nPasitney said that while some ostriches on the farm have indeed died of avian flu — 69 in total — they are just a small percentage of the overall flock. And, she said, all of those who have died were younger, while the remaining older ostriches are in good health.\n“We’re at herd immunity,” she argued, saying there have been no new deaths since Jan. 14, and telling CBC News that of the birds who are still alive, none are exhibiting symptoms of the illness. (Researchers contacted by CBC News say there is limited information on whether ostriches can develop immunity to avian flu.)\nThis ostrich farm survived wildfires. Now, avian flu means 400 birds need to be culled\nThe risks of spread are also minimized, Espersen said, because Universal Ostrich does not sell its birds for meat.\nInstead, the farm has in recent years pivoted to raising the ostriches to research their ability to fight diseases, saying they have a partnership with Japan’s Kyoto Prefectural University, which has previously made headlines for its work with ostrich eggs and detecting COVID-19.\nCBC News has reached out to the university, but has not heard back. \nSupporters and media have been told to keep their distance from ostriches at Universal Ostrich as the farm follows quarantine rules. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\nSo far, the assurances from Universal Ostrich have not been able to reverse a decision from the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), which told CBC News it was reviewing its options following Friday’s court ruling.\nThe agency issued a cull order on Dec. 31 after detecting avian flu at the farm earlier that month, and gave the owners a deadline of Feb. 1 — this Saturday — to have the ostriches eliminated.\nWidespread disease\nThough that initial deadline is no longer in place, the herd may still have to be killed, depending on the outcome of the upcoming court case. If that happens, the herd will join the close to nine million domestic birds in B.C. and more than 14 million Canada-wide that have either been culled or died on their own after being infected with the current H5N1 strain of avian flu — which the CFIA is referring to as highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI), first detected in the province in 2022.\nThe death count includes poultry on more than 200 current and previously infected premises in B.C., mostly farms and processing facilities, but also extends to at least one petting zoo, whose owner described the heartbreaking process of saying goodbye to more than four dozen chickens and ducks who “each had names and were more than just ‘livestock,'” according to a post from the zoo’s owner.\nThat’s much the same as how Universal Ostrich describes its animals — who Pasitney has been introducing on social media to drum up support.\nWATCH | Pasitney tours her mother’s farm, naming individual ostriches: \nCBC Player \nOstrich farm faces Feb. 1 cull\nKatie Pasitney of Universal Ostrich introduces some of her Facebook followers to the ostriches who have been ordered killed by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency after avian flu was detected at the farm.\nIn a statement posted this week, the CFIA acknowledged the emotional toll the death of animals can take but said its job is to minimize the risk of the virus spreading, including potentially to humans.\n“Our disease response has aimed to protect public and animal health, minimize impacts on the domestic poultry industry, and the Canadian economy.… In domestic poultry, including ostriches, this is accomplished through the timely depopulation of domestic birds on infected premises.”\nThe duty to do this, the agency said, is outlined in its mandate under the Health of Animals Act and the World Organisation for Animal Health, of which Canada is a member.\nOstriches at Universal Ostrich in Edgewood, B.C. on Jan. 31, 2025. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\nRisks vs. benefits in culling decisions\nAvian flu can spread rapidly between domestic and wild birds, whose long migration patterns give even more opportunity for the disease to be passed on between communities and into other animal populations, including humans.\nSpeaking in a video court session Friday, the legal counsel for the CFIA emphasized the agency’s position and job in minimizing that risk.\n“Whether or not the birds recover and appear healthy is not the concern when implementing a cull policy,” said lawyer Paul Saunders. \n“That concern also includes the potential for the mutation of the virus among healthy birds…. an infection in birds could be a precursor to a human flu pandemic. Regardless of how likely that is, once it happens, it’s happened, so that is a concern motivating the CFIA’s response.”\nUniversal Ostrich’s case was argued by lawyer Michael Carter, who said that both the courts and the CFIA should take into account the “unique circumstances” of the ostrich farm, including its remote location and the difference between the large, flightless birds and the poultry farms where most of the culls so far have taken place.\nHe said the CFIA had other options at its disposal which should be considered, including ongoing quarantine and monitoring of the birds, and he criticized the agency’s “automatic stamping out” policy.\nBoth sides agreed that one of the key questions before the court was that of the relative risks the public should have to bear when it comes to allowing the birds to live — a question not easily answered, according to veterinary experts.\nIn an email to CBC News, J. Scott Weese, a professor at the Ontario Veterinary College, said the practice makes sense in general “when there’s widespread infection, risk to people around the animals, limited other exposure risk,” and in cases where there’s limited value — be it economic, personal or for conservation purposes — of the animals being killed.\nThe entrance to Universal Ostrich in Edgewood, B.C. on Jan. 31, 2025. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\nHe urged caution around claims that the remaining ostriches on the farm might be immune to avian flu, noting that research in the field is weak, but said there is less of an argument in favour of a cull from a disease-control standpoint now that the H5N1 strain of avian flu has been well-established. \n“An individual group of birds is a drop in the bucket now,” he said. “Culling probably has little population benefit.” \nHe added, though, that from a “risk aversion standpoint,” a cull is the “easiest thing” to do.\nAnd the risks of allowing avian flu to spread are especially pronounced in B.C. where, last year, a 13-year-old girl was the first in Canada to be domestically infected with H5N1. She spent several weeks in intensive care at B.C. Children’s Hospital after experiencing respiratory failure and pneumonia.\nElsewhere, including in the United States, human death following infection has been reported and there are fears that if avian flu is allowed to spread and mutate, it could happen in Canada, too.\n“The CFIA takes the responsibility to protect the health of animals and Canadians extremely seriously as we conduct these necessary disease control measures to protect public health,” the CFIA said in its statement.\nPasitney says her ostriches pose little risk to the wider population, as they are flightless birds who are not being used for meat. (Submitted by Katie Pasitney)\nThe agency also said it has veterinarians and inspectors who work with farmers to come up with a humane plan for the killing of their birds, and that if the farms do not comply they can face fines and jail time.\nIt added that owners can be compensated — up to $3,000 per bird in the case of ostriches — with supporting documentation.\n“While compensation may not offset the emotional toll of depopulation, it can provide resources to recover and reestablish operations,” CFIA said.\nBut that’s not feasible for Universal Ostrich, Pasitney said. Her mother is in her 60s, her business partner in his 70s, and they don’t feel they can start over with a new set of birds, especially ones as finicky as ostriches.\n“They’re in the pecking order,” Pasitney said. “They know them.”\nGrowing support\nSupporters camp out at Universal Ostrich on January 31, 2025. Some have come from cities as much as 400 kilometers away to show their support. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\nAnd the farm owners have found a sympathetic audience for their story.\nRights group Animal Justice has become involved, arguing that rather than mass culls, Canada should focus on improving conditions at large-scale poultry farms where birds are kept in more confined conditions.\nThe cause has also been picked up by groups and individuals previously associated with protesting public health measures surrounding COVID-19, in part because of the farm’s insistence that their ostriches have “natural antibodies” and should be studied to find out if they may help in fighting diseases in humans or other animals.\nA poster advertises a convoy to Universal Ostrich to protest the ordered cull. (Facebook/B.C. Rising)\nChief among those groups is B.C. Rising, whose website includes a section arguing that COVID-19 was part of a United Nations-led plot to take control of vast swaths of land and that 15-minute cities, an urban planning tool aimed at creating walkable neighbourhoods, is actually a plot to trap people in individual sectors of their city.\nThe site now has a section titled “Save Our Ostriches” with plans to convoy to Universal Ostrich on Saturday to protest and observe, urging participants to bring cameras but to leave “political signs or flags” at home and reminding members to remain peaceful.\nAsked about the post, which Pasitney has shared, she said while she doesn’t endorse every idea from her family’s supporters, she does welcome the public outcry on behalf of their ostriches.\n“We’re just trying to do what’s right,” she said. “I’m blown away.”\nWith files from Sarah Penton, Yvette Brend, Brady Strachan and Akshay Kulkarni","markdown":"# B.C. ostrich farm gets stay of execution for birds ordered killed due to avian flu fears - CBC News\n\nCBC News · [**Andrew Kurjata**](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/author/andrew-kurjata-1.3947097) ·\n\nFederal Court judge staves off Feb. 1 cull deadline as convoy of supporters embraces their cause.\n\n![Two people wearing masks stand outside with ostriches.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7447864.1738365222!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpeg_gen/derivatives/16x9_1180/universal-ostrich.jpeg?im=Resize%3D780)\n\nDave Bilinski and Karen Espersen of Universal Ostrich pose with a portion of their flock of birds after learning a deadline to have them killed over avian flu concerns has been put off by a federal judge. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\n\nA flock of B.C. ostriches ordered killed after avian flu was detected on their farm have been granted a stay of execution by a Federal Court judge.\n\nIn a ruling shared Friday afternoon, Justice Michael Battista said that the Feb. 1 deadline for the birds to be killed should be suspended until after a hearing on the original order from the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) can be reviewed by the courts.\n\nBattista wrote he was satisfied by the arguments made that the farm would suffer “irreparable harm” should the cull go ahead on Saturday and that it had raised reasonable questions about whether a cull is necessary in the first place, which will be the subject of a future court ruling.\n\n“We’re going to bring change,” said Katie Pasitney, before exchanging hugs with supporters gathered in the kitchen of the house on the farm, which is co-owned by her mother, Karen Espersen, who broke down in tears after getting the news, saying “God is good today.”\n\n_**WATCH | Judge issues pause on federal cull order:**_\n\n    CBC Player\n\n![](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/6405202a-62ae-487a-b2f3-46ee3adefe25,1738377009127/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D1180)\n\nCourt pauses cull order on B.C. ostriches ordered killed over avian flu fears\n\nThe owners of an ostrich farm in the Kootenays have won a court injunction against the cull of hundreds of their birds. A federal agency ordered the farmers to kill off their herd after avian flu was detected at the site in December, but the owners are pushing back. Brady Strachan reports.\n\nIt’s the latest development in a saga of the farm in the B.C. Interior whose owners have turned to the courts and the court of public opinion to save what it says are roughly 400 birds in their care. \n\nUniversal Ostrich is located on a rural road near Edgewood, in B.C.’s West Kootenay region. Getting there is an approximately 175 kilometre drive from Kelowna along a winding highway, or about 360 kilometres northeast of Vancouver as the crow flies.\n\nAnd for the past several weeks, it has been the site of a growing set of supporters who view the order to kill the birds, who can live for 30 or even 40 years, as an example of government overreach that fails to account for the specifics of the situation being faced by the farm’s owners, Espersen and Dave Bilinski, who have raised some of the birds facing death for decades.\n\n“We just want transparency,” said Pasitney, who has been acting as a spokesperson for her mother’s farm.\n\n![People hug.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7447832.1738363615!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/katie-pasitney.jpg?im=)\n\nKatie Pasitney hugs supporters after learning the ostriches on her mother’s farm will not have to be killed until after a court hearing ruling on an order from the Canadian Food Inspection Agency to cull the entire herd. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\n\nPasitney said that while some ostriches on the farm have indeed died of avian flu — 69 in total — they are just a small percentage of the overall flock. And, she said, all of those who have died were younger, while the remaining older ostriches are in good health.\n\n“We’re at herd immunity,” she argued, saying there have been no new deaths since Jan. 14, and telling CBC News that of the birds who are still alive, none are exhibiting symptoms of the illness. (Researchers contacted by CBC News say there is limited information on whether ostriches can develop immunity to avian flu.)\n\n*   [This ostrich farm survived wildfires. Now, avian flu means 400 birds need to be culled](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/bc-ostrich-farm-edgewood-1.7429394)\n\nThe risks of spread are also minimized, Espersen said, because Universal Ostrich does not sell its birds for meat.\n\nInstead, the farm has in recent years pivoted to raising the ostriches to research their ability to fight diseases, saying they have a partnership with Japan’s Kyoto Prefectural University, which has [previously made headlines for its work with ostrich eggs and detecting COVID-19](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/dec/10/scientists-ostrich-cells-glowing-covid-detection-masks).\n\nCBC News has reached out to the university, but has not heard back. \n\n![A sign that says Environmental Farm Plan, Universal Ostrich Inc. Ostriches behind a fence are in the background.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7447781.1738361232!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/universal-ostrich.jpg?im=)\n\nSupporters and media have been told to keep their distance from ostriches at Universal Ostrich as the farm follows quarantine rules. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\n\nSo far, the assurances from Universal Ostrich have not been able to reverse a decision from the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), which told CBC News it was reviewing its options following Friday’s court ruling.\n\nThe agency issued a cull order on Dec. 31 after detecting avian flu at the farm earlier that month, and gave the owners a deadline of Feb. 1 — this Saturday — to have the ostriches eliminated.\n\n## Widespread disease\n\nThough that initial deadline is no longer in place, the herd may still have to be killed, depending on the outcome of the upcoming court case. If that happens, the herd will join the close to nine million domestic birds in B.C. and more than 14 million Canada-wide that have either been culled or died on their own after being infected with the current H5N1 strain of avian flu — which the CFIA is referring to as highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI), first detected in the province in 2022.\n\nThe death count includes poultry on more than 200 current and previously infected premises in B.C., mostly farms and processing facilities, but also extends to at least one [petting zoo](https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/avian-flu-vancouver-island-petting-farm-1.7374291), whose owner described the heartbreaking process of saying goodbye to more than four dozen chickens and ducks who “each had names and were more than just ‘livestock,'” according to a post from the zoo’s owner.\n\nThat’s much the same as how Universal Ostrich describes its animals — who Pasitney has been introducing on social media to drum up support.\n\n**_WATCH | Pasitney tours her mother’s farm, naming individual ostriches:_** \n\n    CBC Player\n\n![](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/5e537679-b568-469d-839d-2b0cfa5d4a50,1738289721040/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D1180)\n\nOstrich farm faces Feb. 1 cull\n\nKatie Pasitney of Universal Ostrich introduces some of her Facebook followers to the ostriches who have been ordered killed by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency after avian flu was detected at the farm.\n\nIn a [statement posted this week](https://inspection.canada.ca/en/animal-health/terrestrial-animals/diseases/reportable/avian-influenza/latest-bird-flu-situation/investigations-and-orders/hpai-ostrich-farm), the CFIA acknowledged the emotional toll the death of animals can take but said its job is to minimize the risk of the virus spreading, including potentially to humans.\n\n“Our disease response has aimed to protect public and animal health, minimize impacts on the domestic poultry industry, and the Canadian economy.… In domestic poultry, including ostriches, this is accomplished through the timely depopulation of domestic birds on infected premises.”\n\nThe duty to do this, the agency said, is outlined in its mandate under the Health of Animals Act and the [World Organisation for Animal Health](https://inspection.canada.ca/en/animal-health/chief-veterinary-officer/woah), of which Canada is a member.\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/image-1-1024x576.png)\n\nOstriches at Universal Ostrich in Edgewood, B.C. on Jan. 31, 2025. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\n\n**Risks vs. benefits in culling decisions**\n\nAvian flu can spread rapidly between domestic and wild birds, whose long migration patterns give even more opportunity for the disease to be passed on between communities and into other animal populations, including humans.\n\nSpeaking in a video court session Friday, the legal counsel for the CFIA emphasized the agency’s position and job in minimizing that risk.\n\n“Whether or not the birds recover and appear healthy is not the concern when implementing a cull policy,” said lawyer Paul Saunders. \n\n“That concern also includes the potential for the mutation of the virus among healthy birds…. an infection in birds could be a precursor to a human flu pandemic. Regardless of how likely that is, once it happens, it’s happened, so that is a concern motivating the CFIA’s response.”\n\nUniversal Ostrich’s case was argued by lawyer Michael Carter, who said that both the courts and the CFIA should take into account the “unique circumstances” of the ostrich farm, including its remote location and the difference between the large, flightless birds and the poultry farms where most of the culls so far have taken place.\n\nHe said the CFIA had other options at its disposal which should be considered, including ongoing quarantine and monitoring of the birds, and he criticized the agency’s “automatic stamping out” policy.\n\nBoth sides agreed that one of the key questions before the court was that of the relative risks the public should have to bear when it comes to allowing the birds to live — a question not easily answered, according to veterinary experts.\n\nIn an email to CBC News, J. Scott Weese, a professor at the Ontario Veterinary College, said the practice makes sense in general “when there’s widespread infection, risk to people around the animals, limited other exposure risk,” and in cases where there’s limited value — be it economic, personal or for conservation purposes — of the animals being killed.\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/image-2-1024x576.png)\n\nThe entrance to Universal Ostrich in Edgewood, B.C. on Jan. 31, 2025. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\n\nHe urged caution around claims that the remaining ostriches on the farm might be immune to avian flu, noting that research in the field is weak, but said there is less of an argument in favour of a cull from a disease-control standpoint now that the H5N1 strain of avian flu has been well-established. \n\n“An individual group of birds is a drop in the bucket now,” he said. “Culling probably has little population benefit.” \n\nHe added, though, that from a “risk aversion standpoint,” a cull is the “easiest thing” to do.\n\nAnd the risks of allowing avian flu to spread are especially pronounced in B.C. where, last year, a 13-year-old girl was the first in Canada to be domestically infected with H5N1. She spent several weeks in intensive care at B.C. Children’s Hospital after experiencing respiratory failure and pneumonia.\n\nElsewhere, including in the United States, human death following infection has been reported and there are fears that if avian flu is allowed to spread and mutate, it could happen in Canada, too.\n\n“The CFIA takes the responsibility to protect the health of animals and Canadians extremely seriously as we conduct these necessary disease control measures to protect public health,” the CFIA said in its statement.\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/image-3-1024x576.png)\n\nPasitney says her ostriches pose little risk to the wider population, as they are flightless birds who are not being used for meat. (Submitted by Katie Pasitney)\n\nThe agency also said it has veterinarians and inspectors who work with farmers to come up with a humane plan for the killing of their birds, and that if the farms do not comply they can face fines and jail time.\n\nIt added that owners can be compensated — up to $3,000 per bird in the case of ostriches — with supporting documentation.\n\n“While compensation may not offset the emotional toll of depopulation, it can provide resources to recover and reestablish operations,” CFIA said.\n\nBut that’s not feasible for Universal Ostrich, Pasitney said. Her mother is in her 60s, her business partner in his 70s, and they don’t feel they can start over with a new set of birds, especially ones as finicky as ostriches.\n\n“They’re in the pecking order,” Pasitney said. “They know them.”\n\n## Growing support\n\n![People at a campfire.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7447787.1738361357!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/universal-ostrich.jpg?im=)\n\nSupporters camp out at Universal Ostrich on January 31, 2025. Some have come from cities as much as 400 kilometers away to show their support. (Brady Strachan/CBC)\n\nAnd the farm owners have found a sympathetic audience for their story.\n\nRights group Animal Justice has become involved, arguing that rather than mass culls, Canada should focus on improving conditions at large-scale poultry farms where birds are kept in more confined conditions.\n\nThe cause has also been picked up by groups and individuals previously associated with protesting public health measures surrounding COVID-19, in part because of the farm’s insistence that their ostriches have “natural antibodies” and should be studied to find out if they may help in fighting diseases in humans or other animals.\n\n![A poster showing pictures of ostriches that reads 'Save Our Ostriches.'](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7446799.1738294954!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/original_1180/save-our-ostriches-convoy.jpg?im=)\n\nA poster advertises a convoy to Universal Ostrich to protest the ordered cull. (Facebook/B.C. Rising)\n\nChief among those groups is B.C. Rising, whose website includes a section arguing that COVID-19 was part of a United Nations-led plot to take control of vast swaths of land and that 15-minute cities, an urban planning tool aimed at creating walkable neighbourhoods, is actually a plot to trap people in individual sectors of their city.\n\nThe site now has a section titled “Save Our Ostriches” with plans to convoy to Universal Ostrich on Saturday to protest and observe, urging participants to bring cameras but to leave “political signs or flags” at home and reminding members to remain peaceful.\n\nAsked about the post, which Pasitney has shared, she said while she doesn’t endorse every idea from her family’s supporters, she does welcome the public outcry on behalf of their ostriches.\n\n“We’re just trying to do what’s right,” she said. “I’m blown away.”\n\n* * *\n\n_With files from Sarah Penton, Yvette Brend, Brady Strachan and Akshay Kulkarni_","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

We’ve won an injunction to stop the cull while a judicial review looks into the CFIA’s handling of this order. Thank you to everyone who shared, wrote, called, supported, and donated.\nThis month has been incredibly hard, with more heartbreak than we ever expected — but we were never alone. Now we finally have space to breathe.\nWe’ve always believed that if this was ever properly reviewed, it would be stopped. The fact that it took this long, and that our own government worked so hard to block us is both disturbing and shameful.\nThis weekend we can breathe and recharge, and then February is for justice.\nUniversal Ostrich lives to fight another day!\nUniversal Ostrich lives to fight another day! - YouTube","markdown":"# Jan 31, 2025 Update From the Farm\n\n Jan 31, 2025 – We successfully won our temporary injunction which means our ostriches get to stay alive.\n\nKatie Pasitney @ Universal Ostrich Farms\n\n**Jan 31, 2025** – Today is a good day! We’ve won an injunction to stop the cull while a judicial review looks into the CFIA’s handling of this order. Thank you to everyone who shared, wrote, called, supported, and donated.\n\nThis month has been incredibly hard, with more heartbreak than we ever expected — but we were never alone. Now we finally have space to breathe.\n\nWe’ve always believed that if this was ever properly reviewed, it would be stopped. The fact that it took this long, and that our own government worked so hard to block us is both disturbing and shameful.\n\nThis weekend we can breathe and recharge, and then February is for justice.\n\n**Universal Ostrich lives to fight another day!**\n\nUniversal Ostrich lives to fight another day! - YouTube\n\n[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nuoZDS1NHU0&embeds_referring_euri=https%3A%2F%2Fsaveourostriches.com%2F)","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

Ostrich Farm to SLAUGHTER 400 Healthy Birds - YouTube\nViva Frei, Jan 26, 2025 \nThis is an absolute must watch and share. My interview with Katie from Universal Ostrich Farm in British Columbia. \nThe Canadian government, via CFIA – Canadian Food Inspection Agency – has given Katie’s mother (owner of the farm) until February 1 to SLAUGHTER over 400 HEALTHY ostriches on her mother’s ostrich farm because two deceased ostriches allegedly tested positive (via oral and anal PCR tests) for avian flu. \nThe farm has until February 1 to slaughter over 400 healthy animals (which can weigh up to 300 lbs each and have been in the family for as long and 35 years!), and bury them in multiple pits 9 meters deep, which Katie’s is supposed to dig on her own property. \nI ask all the questions. You can come to your own conclusions and determine if this is the outrage I think it is. If you agree, please share.\nShare This Story\nTwitter Embed\nThis is an absolute must watch and share. For over three decades, Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski have devoted their lives to raising up to 500 ostriches on their farm, which is known for its groundbreaking research on the robust immune systems of these remarkable creatures.\nThe farm is home to a herd of non-commercial ostriches, some of which have been with the farmers for over 34 years. Karen’s daughter, Katie Pasitney, grew up with these ostriches and considers them more like family. Each has its own name and personality, like Frank, Lulu, and Q-Tip. \nHowever, an illness in December 2024 led to drastic government interventions, threatening both the lives of the ostriches and the livelihoods of the farmers who care for them.\nWhat Happened?\nThe situation began on December 10, 2024, when a three-year-old ostrich showed pneumonia-like symptoms. Although it recovered, some younger ostriches and those introduced to the farm after 2020 also became ill, resulting in 69 deaths out of 468 ostriches, or 15% of the original herd, over 36 days.\nThe farmers observed that ostriches previously exposed to a bacterial infection in 2020 showed no new symptoms or deaths, suggesting they had achieved herd immunity. Despite the losses, the remaining ostriches fully recovered, and as of January 15, 2025, no further illnesses or deaths have occurred.\nThough the ostriches are not being raised for food, it didn’t take long for the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) to get involved. \nOn December 28, the farm received a phone call from the CFIA, stating that they had received an anonymous tip that there was suspicion of avian flu on the farm and that they would be coming to take samples.\nOn December 30, CFIA agents arrived at the farm and conducted two PCR tests (oral and rectal) on two dead ostriches that had been deceased for over 24 hours. The farmers asked the attending CFIA agents if they would also test a couple of their healthy ostriches, and they were denied this request.\nThe next day, on December 31, the PCR results came back positive for H5N1 avian influenza, and a cull order was issued for the family to destroy all of their ostriches by February 1, 2025. The farmers were also given a set of quarantine requirements with instructions on how to dispose and bury their animals, along with a link to mental health support.\nDownload: CFIA Cull Order 2024-12-30 \nRequest for Additional Testing\nEspersen and Bilinski were shocked and requested further testing to confirm the results. They asked for tissue samples to be taken, as this is considered the gold standard for diagnosing any illness. They wanted to determine whether it was avian flu or something else, possibly a bacterial infection, as the symptoms resembled those that affected the farm in 2020. At that time, an autopsy and tissue sampling were conducted, and the vet identified it as pseudomonas, a bacteria commonly found in soil and water.\nThe farmers asked for the same testing protocol to be applied in order to confirm the results, but CFIA denied their request. Espersen and Bilinski were also informed that they were prohibited from testing or treating their animals, including independent evaluations from their vet, under the threat of a $200,000 fine and six months in jail.\nA Glimmer of Hope\nOn January 2, the farmers received an email from a CFIA agent stating their animals qualified for a depopulation exemption due to their rare and valuable genetics. The email included a Distinct Unit Request Package with a depopulation exemption form, which they were asked to complete to prevent the ostriches from being culled. \nDownload: 25-01-02-CFIA-email \nHowever, the form was intended for commercial poultry farms and did not apply to their situation. Espersen explained that the form couldn’t be filled out properly, as nearly every question was unrelated to ostriches. The CFIA agent warned that answering “no” or leaving questions unanswered would lead to the exemption being denied.\nThe following day, a five-hour meeting took place between top CFIA officials and the farmers. The CFIA expressed interest in learning more about the farm and its operations, requesting detailed information on their business plans and supporting research. Espersen and Bilinski freely shared this information, hoping it would demonstrate a unique and valuable opportunity for collaboration in studying and potentially funding important natural antibody research in Canada.\nThe Promise of Natural Antibodies\nThe ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms are valued not only for their genetic traits but also for their strong, robust immune systems, which have attracted the interest of researchers worldwide. After the farm stopped producing ostrich meat in 2020, Espersen and Bilinski shifted their focus to studying natural antibodies, collaborating with Dr. Yasuhiro Tsukamoto of Kyoto University, Japan, and Dr. Stu Greenberg from Boston. This joint research examines the unique properties of antibodies found in ostrich eggs and their potential applications across various fields of study.\nThe farmers believes their farm has the potential to provide critical insights into managing and controlling diseases in wild populations, such as migratory ducks and other wildlife species. “Why isn’t the CFIA working with us to come up with a solution?” Pasitney wonders. “Why are they so determined to destroy our healthy ostriches and stamp out their natural immunity?”\nExemption Request Denied\nOn January 10, the farmers received official correspondence from CFIA denying their request for a depopulation exemption, stating they did not meet the criteria for unique and rare genetics. They were also reminded that the cull order remained in effect, requiring them to destroy and dispose of all ostriches by February 1. In their email, the CFIA stated, “This decision is final and not subject to appeal.”\nDownload: 25-01-02-CFIA-letter-exemption-depopulation \nThis was a huge blow to the family, who felt this was their last chance to stop the unnecessary killing of their beloved ostriches.\nA Growing Movement to Save the Ostriches\nPasitney remembers the early days of feeling desperate for help. She reached out to friends, family, her community, and local news agencies and did as many interviews as possible with independent journalists, various media outlets, and podcasters. The story of the ostriches quickly spread, with people from all across Canada, the U.S., and now the world showing support.\nOn January 21, the day before the CFIA was scheduled for inspection, Pasitney and a group of community leaders held an emergency meeting. Within hours, the campaign “Save Our Ostriches” was launched. A website was set up, posters were designed, and social media posts were shared. People quickly mobilized, gathering at the farm the following morning to show their support.\nUpon hearing about the gathering, the CFIA cancelled its inspection an hour before it was scheduled, stating it was aware of protestors and would bring the RCMP next time. The 10 peaceful supporters holding handmade “Save Our Ostriches” signs on the side of the road weren’t surprised. It was yet another example of the government’s heavy-handed approach.\nThe next day, the CFIA sent another email at the end of the day that they would be returning the following morning. This gave the supporters little time to organize, but they still managed to gather 15 concerned citizens to quietly witness, film, and photograph the visit. As expected, the RCMP arrived, along with four CFIA agents dressed in full hazmat suits, to conduct a protocol check and ensure compliance with quarantine measures. This time, the farmers were ready, capturing footage, asking questions, and recording their interactions on social media.\nWatch CFIA Inspection Videos here. \nLegal Support\nDuring this time, the farmers garnered legal support from advocates and lawyers. A legal team quickly came together and worked around the clock to secure an emergency injunction on January 31, just one day before the scheduled cull order. \nFederal Judge Justice Michael Battista ruled to stay the cull order imposed by the CFIA, granting the farmers time to seek a judicial review of the case. \nThis brought happy tears to the family, who were watching the proceedings virtually from their Edgewood farm. Pasitney shared that everyone involved with the farm was “ecstatic” upon hearing the judge’s ruling. “It’s been a lot of sleepless nights and long days, not knowing if we would have to watch 35 years of hard work and 400 ostriches be unjustly killed.” \nThe farmers recognize that the judge’s ruling is only a temporary reprieve, and they face a long legal battle ahead. \nThe CFIA continues to put pressure on the farm, imposing 19 new quarantine measures on February 6, including separating the males and females to prevent breeding, covering frozen ponds with netting, and requiring additional barns and double fencing. “It feels like we’re being set up for failure,” Pasitney says. The CFIA also filed an appeal against Justice Battista’s ruling, claiming the judge “erred in law and in principle, and/or seriously misapprehended the facts.”\nWhat’s at Stake \nThe facts are that if the ostriches are culled, it would not only be a tragic loss of life but also a loss of valuable genetic material and groundbreaking research. These ostriches may revolutionize disease research and contribute to humanity in ways that have yet to be fully realized. \n“These ostriches have the ability to do something truly remarkable,” Pasitney says, choking up as she recalls her mother’s words from childhood.\n“My mom always said these ostriches would do something amazing for humanity one day. Maybe that time is now.”","markdown":"# About the \"Save our Ostriches\" Campaign and the Farm\n\nWhat would you do if, after thirty years of raising and caring for animals on your farm, the government suddenly showed up and ordered you to slaughter them?\n\nThis is the heartbreaking reality for the farmers of Universal Ostrich Farms, located in the remote town of Edgewood, British Columbia. For over three decades, Karen Espersen and Dave Bilinski have devoted their lives to raising up to 500 ostriches on their farm, which is known for its groundbreaking research on the robust immune systems of these remarkable creatures.\n\nThe farm is home to a herd of non-commercial ostriches, some of which have been with the farmers for over 34 years. Karen’s daughter, Katie Pasitney, grew up with these ostriches and considers them more like family. Each has its own name and personality, like Frank, Lulu, and Q-Tip. \n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/FrankLuluQ-Tip.png)\n\nHowever, an illness in December 2024 led to drastic government interventions, threatening both the lives of the ostriches and the livelihoods of the farmers who care for them.\n\n### **What Happened?**\n\nThe situation began on December 10, 2024, when a three-year-old ostrich showed pneumonia-like symptoms. Although it recovered, some younger ostriches and those introduced to the farm after 2020 also became ill, resulting in 69 deaths out of 468 ostriches, or 15% of the original herd, over 36 days.\n\nThe farmers observed that ostriches previously exposed to a bacterial infection in 2020 showed no new symptoms or deaths, suggesting they had achieved herd immunity. Despite the losses, the remaining ostriches fully recovered, and as of January 15, 2025, no further illnesses or deaths have occurred.\n\nThough the ostriches are not being raised for food, it didn’t take long for the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) to get involved. \n\nOn December 28, the farm received a phone call from the CFIA, stating that they had received an anonymous tip that there was suspicion of avian flu on the farm and that they would be coming to take samples.\n\nOn December 30, CFIA agents arrived at the farm and conducted two PCR tests (oral and rectal) on two dead ostriches that had been deceased for over 24 hours. The farmers asked the attending CFIA agents if they would also test a couple of their healthy ostriches, and they were denied this request.\n\nThe next day, on December 31, the PCR results came back positive for H5N1 avian influenza, and a **[cull order](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/CFIA-cull-order-2024-12-30.pdf)** was issued for the family to destroy all of their ostriches by February 1, 2025. The farmers were also given a set of quarantine requirements with instructions on how to dispose and bury their animals, along with a link to mental health support.\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/CFIA-cull-order-screenshot.png)\n\nDownload: **[CFIA Cull Order 2024-12-30](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/CFIA-cull-order-2024-12-30.pdf)** \n\n### **Request for Additional Testing**\n\nEspersen and Bilinski were shocked and requested further testing to confirm the results. They asked for tissue samples to be taken, as this is considered the gold standard for diagnosing any illness. They wanted to determine whether it was avian flu or something else, possibly a bacterial infection, as the symptoms resembled those that affected the farm in 2020. At that time, an autopsy and tissue sampling were conducted, and the vet identified it as pseudomonas, a bacteria commonly found in soil and water.\n\nThe farmers asked for the same testing protocol to be applied in order to confirm the results, but CFIA denied their request. Espersen and Bilinski were also informed that they were prohibited from testing or treating their animals, including independent evaluations from their vet, under the threat of a [**$200,000 fine and six months in jail.**](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/Health-of-Animals-Act-Section-66.png)\n\n### **A Glimmer of Hope**\n\nOn January 2, the farmers received an email from a CFIA agent stating their animals qualified for a depopulation exemption due to their rare and valuable genetics. The email included a Distinct Unit Request Package with a depopulation exemption form, which they were asked to complete to prevent the ostriches from being culled. \n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/25-01-16-Cassandra-West-AI-Case-Office-7-Email-to-Karen.png)\n\nDownload: **[25-01-02-CFIA-email](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/25-01-02-CFIA-email.pdf)** \n\nHowever, the form was intended for commercial poultry farms and did not apply to their situation. Espersen explained that the form couldn’t be filled out properly, as nearly every question was unrelated to ostriches. The CFIA agent warned that answering “no” or leaving questions unanswered would lead to the exemption being denied.\n\nThe following day, a five-hour meeting took place between top CFIA officials and the farmers. The CFIA expressed interest in learning more about the farm and its operations, requesting detailed information on their business plans and supporting research. Espersen and Bilinski freely shared this information, hoping it would demonstrate a unique and valuable opportunity for collaboration in studying and potentially funding important natural antibody research in Canada.\n\n### **The Promise of Natural Antibodies**\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/OstrichEggs-300x225.png)The ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms are valued not only for their genetic traits but also for their strong, robust immune systems, which have attracted the interest of researchers worldwide. After the farm stopped producing ostrich meat in 2020, Espersen and Bilinski shifted their focus to studying natural antibodies, collaborating with Dr. Yasuhiro Tsukamoto of Kyoto University, Japan, and Dr. Stu Greenberg from Boston. This joint research examines the unique properties of antibodies found in ostrich eggs and their potential applications across various fields of study.\n\nThe farmers believes their farm has the potential to provide critical insights into managing and controlling diseases in wild populations, such as migratory ducks and other wildlife species. “Why isn’t the CFIA working with us to come up with a solution?” Pasitney wonders. “Why are they so determined to destroy our healthy ostriches and stamp out their natural immunity?”\n\n### **Exemption Request Denied**\n\nOn January 10, the farmers received official correspondence from CFIA denying their request for a depopulation exemption, stating they did not meet the criteria for unique and rare genetics. They were also reminded that the cull order remained in effect, requiring them to destroy and dispose of all ostriches by February 1. In their email, the CFIA stated, “This decision is final and not subject to appeal.”\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/25-01-10-CFIA_Letter_Exemption_Depopulation.png)\n\nDownload: **[25-01-02-CFIA-letter-exemption-depopulation](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/25-01-10-CFIA_Letter_Exemption_Depopulation.pdf)** \n\nThis was a huge blow to the family, who felt this was their last chance to stop the unnecessary killing of their beloved ostriches.\n\n### **A Growing Movement to Save the Ostriches**\n\nPasitney remembers the early days of feeling desperate for help. She reached out to friends, family, her community, and local news agencies and did as many interviews as possible with independent journalists, various media outlets, and podcasters. The story of the ostriches quickly spread, with people from all across Canada, the U.S., and now the world showing support.\n\nOn January 21, the day before the CFIA was scheduled for inspection, Pasitney and a group of community leaders held an emergency meeting. Within hours, the campaign **“Save Our Ostriches”** was launched. A website was set up, posters were designed, and social media posts were shared. People quickly mobilized, gathering at the farm the following morning to show their support.\n\nUpon hearing about the gathering, the CFIA cancelled its inspection an hour before it was scheduled, stating it was aware of protestors and would bring the RCMP next time. The 10 peaceful supporters holding handmade “Save Our Ostriches” signs on the side of the road weren’t surprised. It was yet another example of the government’s heavy-handed approach.\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/25-01-22-Supporters_Day1.png)\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/25-01-24-CFIA-Inspection.png)\n\nThe next day, the CFIA sent another email at the end of the day that they would be returning the following morning. This gave the supporters little time to organize, but they still managed to gather 15 concerned citizens to quietly witness, film, and photograph the visit. As expected, the RCMP arrived, along with four CFIA agents dressed in full hazmat suits, to conduct a protocol check and ensure compliance with quarantine measures. This time, the farmers were ready, capturing footage, asking questions, and recording their interactions on social media.\n\nWatch CFIA Inspection Videos **[here](https://saveourostriches.com/cfia-inspection-videos/)**. \n\n### **Legal Support**\n\nDuring this time, the farmers garnered legal support from advocates and lawyers. A legal team quickly came together and worked around the clock to secure an emergency injunction on January 31, just one day before the scheduled cull order. \n\nFederal Judge Justice Michael Battista ruled to stay the cull order imposed by the CFIA, granting the farmers time to seek a judicial review of the case. \n\nThis brought happy tears to the family, who were watching the proceedings virtually from their Edgewood farm. Pasitney shared that everyone involved with the farm was “ecstatic” upon hearing the judge’s ruling. “It’s been a lot of sleepless nights and long days, not knowing if we would have to watch 35 years of hard work and 400 ostriches be unjustly killed.” \n\nThe farmers recognize that the judge’s ruling is only a temporary reprieve, and they face a long legal battle ahead. \n\nThe CFIA continues to put pressure on the farm, imposing 19 new quarantine measures on February 6, including separating the males and females to prevent breeding, covering frozen ponds with netting, and requiring additional barns and double fencing. “It feels like we’re being set up for failure,” Pasitney says. The CFIA also filed an appeal against Justice Battista’s ruling, claiming the judge “erred in law and in principle, and/or seriously misapprehended the facts.”\n\n### **What’s at Stake** \n\nThe facts are that if the ostriches are culled, it would not only be a tragic loss of life but also a loss of valuable genetic material and groundbreaking research. These ostriches may revolutionize disease research and contribute to humanity in ways that have yet to be fully realized. \n\n“These ostriches have the ability to do something truly remarkable,” Pasitney says, choking up as she recalls her mother’s words from childhood.\n\n> “My mom always said these ostriches would do something amazing for humanity one day. Maybe that time is now.”","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

We Need Your Support\nUrgent 14 days till our Judicial Review\n76 Days – No Symptomatic Deaths\n91 Days – Under Quarantine\nWhat began as a fight to protect our herd and highlight natural immunity, has become something much bigger. This is no longer just about one farm—this is about the future of agriculture, the role of science, and the rights of those who live and work with animals every day.\nDespite mounting evidence and evolving science, the CFIA continues to push forward with a mandate that refuses to adapt or listen. They are moving farm to farm, ignoring the growing data, determined to destroy rather than understand.\nWe’ve worked tirelessly to provide groundbreaking data, including recent antibody tests conducted by a leading Canadian researcher in biochemistry. His findings show that our ostriches had previous exposure to H5N1 and developed strong natural immunity. We’ve even tested positive ourselves for antibodies to this same strain—while remaining perfectly healthy.\nStill, CFIA refuses to acknowledge any of this. We are now filing a motion to test a small, controlled egg yolk sample to demonstrate that the virus is no longer present—proof that could save not only our herd, but inform global understanding of H5N1 resilience and response.\nBut we cannot do this alone. Legal costs are rising quickly, and this fight—if successful—will set precedent for many others. Slowing financial support directly weakens our ability to stand up against this.\nWe’re also laying the groundwork for a foundation that will support other farmers facing similar threats, long after this case is over.\nWe are asking, urgently, for your continued support. This is not just about our farm—it’s about defending truth, science, and the people who feed and care for this country.\nApril 15–16: Judicial Review in Vancouver\nIf we lose, the CFIA will return to destroy our herd.\nTo our supporters, thank you. We see you, and we are deeply grateful.\nTo those who continue to stand with us, know that your support is not just seen; it is felt in the deepest way. Together, we hold the line. Together, we demand better. Together, we fight for the truth and science to be respected.\nIf your business would like to support and be recognized with a promotional poster, please reach out directly.\nKatie Pasitney\nNow is the moment. It’s truly now or never.\nBlessings,\nFrom our farm, our family and of course our beautifully strong and healthy Ostriches.","markdown":"# Help us Save our Ostriches! We Need Your Support\n\n**Urgent 14 days till our Judicial Review**\n\n76 Days – No Symptomatic Deaths\n\n91 Days – Under Quarantine\n\nWhat began as a fight to protect our herd and highlight natural immunity, has become something much bigger. This is no longer just about one farm—this is about the future of agriculture, the role of science, and the rights of those who live and work with animals every day.\n\nDespite mounting evidence and evolving science, the CFIA continues to push forward with a mandate that refuses to adapt or listen. They are moving farm to farm, ignoring the growing data, determined to destroy rather than understand.\n\nWe’ve worked tirelessly to provide groundbreaking data, including recent antibody tests conducted by a leading Canadian researcher in biochemistry. His findings show that our ostriches had previous exposure to H5N1 and developed strong natural immunity. We’ve even tested positive ourselves for antibodies to this same strain—while remaining perfectly healthy.\n\nStill, CFIA refuses to acknowledge any of this. We are now filing a motion to test a small, controlled egg yolk sample to demonstrate that the virus is no longer present—proof that could save not only our herd, but inform global understanding of H5N1 resilience and response.\n\nBut we cannot do this alone. Legal costs are rising quickly, and this fight—if successful—will set precedent for many others. Slowing financial support directly weakens our ability to stand up against this.\n\nWe’re also laying the groundwork for a foundation that will support other farmers facing similar threats, long after this case is over.\n\nWe are asking, urgently, for your continued support. This is not just about our farm—it’s about defending truth, science, and the people who feed and care for this country.\n\nApril 15–16: Judicial Review in Vancouver\n\nIf we lose, the CFIA will return to destroy our herd.\n\nTo our supporters, thank you. We see you, and we are deeply grateful.\n\nTo those who continue to stand with us, know that your support is not just seen; it is felt in the deepest way. Together, we hold the line. Together, we demand better. Together, we fight for the truth and science to be respected.\n\nIf your business would like to support and be recognized with a promotional poster, please reach out directly.\n\nKatie Pasitney\n\nNow is the moment. It’s truly now or never.\n\nBlessings,\n\nFrom our farm, our family and of course our beautifully strong and healthy Ostriches.","debug":{"requestHandlerMode":"browser"}}

You can donate below.\n\n### Help Save Frank\n\nHelp Fund Legal Costs & Operational Expenses\n\nUniversal Ostrich Farms, a small remote farm in the beautiful Kootenays of British Columbia, has been ordered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) to cull their entire herd of 400 healthy ostriches—animals they have raised for over 30 years. You can donate below.\n\n### Help Save Precious\n\nHelp Fund Legal Costs & Operational Expenses\n\nUniversal Ostrich Farms, a small remote farm in the beautiful Kootenays of British Columbia, has been ordered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) to cull their entire herd of 400 healthy ostriches—animals they have raised for over 30 years. The farm urgently needs support to cover legal and operational costs as they challenge this decision in Federal Court.\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/Ostrich-Precious-frame-400x400-1.png \"Ostrich-Precious-frame-400×400\")\n\n#### Change Your Profile Picture\n\nHelp spread the word by changing your profile picture to this framed image. What makes matters even worse for the CFIA is that the ostriches are not getting sick or dying, contradicting every expectation from officials. The four CFIA agents were suited up in full hazmat gear, whereas the farm’s caretakers since day one simply wore their approved attire of farm coveralls.\nThe global attention and support from the public, scientists, media, and politicians presents a significant problem for the CFIA, who are determined to slaughter these majestic birds and ignore the scientific opportunity they represent. Join us as we uncover the devastating impact of this order and explore why their fight matters to all of us. \nSpecial Guests Include:\nSteven Pelech, a renowned biochemist and President of Kinexus Bioinformatics Corporation, explaining the incredible potential of ostrich antibodies.\nChris Shaw, a neuroscientist and professor, breaking down the bigger picture of policy decisions on families and communities.\nJack McLeod, President of Land Keepers Society, standing up for farmers’ rights and the fight for food security.\nAnd hear directly from the family’s daughter as she shares their story, their struggle, and their hope to save their birds. \nThis is more than a farm story-it’s about standing up to injustice, protecting livelihoods, and demanding better for all families. Join us as we uncover the devastating impact of this order and explore why their fight matters to all of us.\n\n![🎙️](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/1f399.svg) Special Guests Include:\n\n*   Steven Pelech, a renowned biochemist and President of Kinexus Bioinformatics Corporation, explaining the incredible potential of ostrich antibodies.\n*   Chris Shaw, a neuroscientist and professor, breaking down the bigger picture of policy decisions on families and communities.\n*   Jack McLeod, President of Land Keepers Society, standing up for farmers’ rights and the fight for food security.\n\nAnd hear directly from the family’s daughter as she shares their story, their struggle, and their hope to save their birds.\n\n![💡](https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/15.1.0/svg/1f4a1.svg) This is more than a farm story-it’s about standing up to injustice, protecting livelihoods, and demanding better for all families. Instead of studying and protecting them, the authorities are choosing to destroy them under a broken mandate:\nTEST\nQUARANTINE \nKILL\nCOMPENSATE\nThis isn’t just about ostriches, next could be 400 cows or pigs. Instead of studying and protecting them, the authorities are choosing to destroy them under a broken mandate.\n\n**Jan 20, 2025** – These ostriches have just 10 days left before they’re culled—even though they are showing powerful natural resistance to avian flu. Instead of studying and protecting them, the authorities are choosing to destroy them under a broken mandate:\n\n*   TEST\n*   QUARANTINE\n*   KILL\n*   COMPENSATE\n\nThis isn’t just about ostriches, next could be 400 cows or pigs. We’re risking food shortages and destroying farms based on outdated protocols, not real solutions. Farmers aren’t even allowed to test or treat their own animals—it’s illegal to confirm health or provide care.\n\nWe have a duty to our animals. Ignoring their needs isn’t just wrong—it’s inhumane.\n\nPlease stand with us. All farmers stand up, rise up, speak out. If they can order a cull based on an anonymous tip, no farm is safe. This affects all of us—our food, our rights, our future.\n\nPlease share. Stand united. Peaceful protests are welcome. However, this decision is not based on sound science and could have serious consequences for both food security and medical research.\nBackground on the Culling Order\nUniversal Ostrich Farm is a research facility focused on studying the unique antibody-producing capabilities of ostriches. Their research has demonstrated potential in neutralizing viruses, bacteria, and even COVID-19, making it an important contribution to medical science.\nIn December 2024, the CFIA claimed that two deceased ostriches—which had been lying outside for over 16 hours—tested positive for H5N1 via PCR testing. Just 41 minutes after receiving these results, the CFIA signed an order to cull the entire flock.\nConcerns Over This Decision\nInconsistent Policy Changes – The CFIA initially granted the farm an exemption, recognizing the birds as “genetically important.” Later, without clear justification, they reversed this decision, ordering their destruction.\nLack of Transparency and Scientific Process – Despite the importance of this research, the CFIA has refused to conduct further testing on the birds and has banned the farm from conducting its own tests, under threat of heavy fines and possible imprisonment. Why is the Canadian government refusing to study the potential antibodies ostriches have developed against H5N1 bird flu?\nLegal Challenges and the Fight to Save the Ostriches\nTemporary Legal Victory – On January 31, 2025, a court granted a temporary stay of execution, halting the cull. However, the CFIA is appealing this decision, which means the culling could still proceed.\nFinal Court Hearing in April – The final judicial review is scheduled for April 17, 2025. This will be a pivotal moment in determining whether the farm will be allowed to continue its work or if the culling order will be upheld.\nWhy This Matters\nThis case is not just about one farm—it raises important questions about how governments handle disease outbreaks, the role of independent scientific research, and the future of food security.\nIf ostrich antibodies hold medical promise, why aren’t they being studied further?\nWhy is the CFIA restricting independent testing instead of working with the farm?\nWhat precedent does this set for other farms and researchers facing similar government actions?\nThis case marks a pivotal moment in the discussion on natural immunity, agricultural independence, and the future of disease management. Halting this culling order is essential to prevent reckless mass culling policies from continuing unchecked.\nH5N1 bird flu is now widespread among migratory waterfowl, ensuring that farms will continue to face reinfection despite mass culling efforts. Governments must recognize this reality and put an end to the “Mass Culling Cycle of Devastation”, which only exacerbates the problem rather than solving it:\nIn this interview, Katie Pasitney of Universal Ostrich and Connie Shields discuss the alarming implications of the CFIA’s culling order and the urgent fight to save the ostriches.\nVideo link: https://www.thefocalpoints.com/p/canada-orders-mass-culling-of-400\nTo Help With Their Legal Fees\nE-transfer: saveourostriches.gmail.com\nGiveSendGo: https://www.givesendgo.com/save-our-ostriches\nGoFundMe: https://www.gofundme.com/f/help-ostrich-farmers-fight-to-save-herd-from-avian-flu\nWebsite: SaveOurOstriches.com\nShare This Story:\nTwitter Embed\nCanada Orders Mass Culling of 400 Research Ostriches Over Bird Flu, Refuses to Test Surviving Birds for Natural Immunity Farmers face fines and jail time for seeking independent testing as the Canadian Food Inspection Agency pushes to reinstate the culling order of prized birds. Show more","markdown":"# Canada Orders Mass Culling of 400 Research Ostriches Over Bird Flu, Refuses to Test Surviving Birds for Natural Immunity\n\nFarmers face fines and jail time for seeking independent testing as the Canadian Food Inspection Agency fights to reinstate the culling order.\n\n![](https://saveourostriches.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/GlxlvMKXMAAEEGc-1024x636.png)\n\nSource: [Focal Points](https://www.thefocalpoints.com/p/canada-orders-mass-culling-of-400)\n\nNicolas Hulscher, MPH  \nMar 11, 2025\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) has ordered the culling of 400 ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farm in British Columbia, citing concerns over H5N1 bird flu. However, this decision is not based on sound science and could have serious consequences for both food security and medical research.\n\n### **Background on the Culling Order**\n\nUniversal Ostrich Farm is a research facility focused on studying the unique antibody-producing capabilities of ostriches. Their research has demonstrated potential in neutralizing viruses, bacteria, and even COVID-19, making it an important contribution to medical science.\n\nIn December 2024, the CFIA claimed that two deceased ostriches—which had been lying outside for over 16 hours—tested positive for H5N1 via PCR testing. Just 41 minutes after receiving these results, the CFIA signed an order to cull the entire flock.\n\n### **Concerns Over This Decision**\n\n**Inconsistent Policy Changes** – The CFIA initially granted the farm an exemption, recognizing the birds as “genetically important.” Later, without clear justification, they reversed this decision, ordering their destruction.\n\n**Lack of Transparency and Scientific Process** – Despite the importance of this research, the CFIA has refused to conduct further testing on the birds and has banned the farm from conducting its own tests, under threat of heavy fines and possible imprisonment. Why is the Canadian government refusing to study the potential antibodies ostriches have developed against H5N1 bird flu?\n\n### **Legal Challenges and the Fight to Save the Ostriches**\n\n**Temporary Legal Victory** – On January 31, 2025, a court granted a temporary stay of execution, halting the cull. However, the CFIA is appealing this decision, which means the culling could still proceed.\n\n**Final Court Hearing in April** – The final judicial review is scheduled for April 17, 2025. This will be a pivotal moment in determining whether the farm will be allowed to continue its work or if the culling order will be upheld.\n\n### **Why This Matters**\n\nThis case is not just about one farm—it raises important questions about how governments handle disease outbreaks, the role of independent scientific research, and the future of food security.\n\n*   **If ostrich antibodies hold medical promise, why aren’t they being studied further?**\n*   **Why is the CFIA restricting independent testing instead of working with the farm?**\n*   **What precedent does this set for other farms and researchers facing similar government actions?**\n\nThis case marks a pivotal moment in the discussion on natural immunity, agricultural independence, and the future of disease management. Halting this culling order is essential to prevent reckless mass culling policies from continuing unchecked.\n\nH5N1 bird flu is now widespread among migratory waterfowl, ensuring that farms will continue to face reinfection despite mass culling efforts. Governments must recognize this reality and put an end to the “Mass Culling Cycle of Devastation”, which only exacerbates the problem rather than solving On Friday, March 21, 2025, Sarah, a healthy and cherished member of our herd, was shot and killed on our property.\nThe RCMP were immediately notified, and we are now awaiting their investigation into the circumstances surrounding this violent act. At this time, we do not know who is responsible for Sarah’s death, but we are fully committed to working with law enforcement to uncover the truth and ensure those responsible are held accountable.\nKatie Pasitney, daughter of co-owner Karen Espersen, said “The loss of Sarah is not just a tragedy for our farm, but for everyone who values the safety of animals. We are focused on finding justice and preventing something like this from happening again.”\nIn addition to the emotional toll, we continue to incur significant legal costs as we work to prevent an unnecessary culling order issued by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA). We are incredibly grateful for the support we’ve received from our supporters, and we will continue to provide updates as new information becomes available.\nAbout Universal Ostrich Farms\nUniversal Ostrich Farms is home to nearly 400 ostriches and specializes in research on their robust immune systems, which are believed to offer valuable insights into both animal and human health. The farm remains dedicated to advancing this research while ensuring the health and safety of its animals. Despite the CFIA’s recent culling order, Universal Ostrich Farms is committed to challenging this decision and protecting its herd from unnecessary harm.\nFor media inquiries, please contact:\nKatie Pasitney\nDaughter of co-owner, Karen Espersen\nUniversal Ostrich Farms Inc.\nsaveourostriches@gmail.com\nSaveOurOstriches.com\nShare This Story:\nTwitter Embed\nOfficial statement from Universal Ostrich Farms: We are devastated to report that one of our elder hens, Sarah, was shot and killed on Friday, March 21st.
